Asked by a Fox News correspondent to expand on JD Vance‚Äôs comments about Good, the president said that the vice-president ‚Äúis generally very accurate‚Äù and then cited what he referred to as evidence that at least one person in Good‚Äôs vicinity when she was killed was ‚Äúprobably a paid agitator‚Äù.

item.title: Six protesters arrested in Portland after two people shot by border patrol agents
item.description:
Local leaders‚Äô appeal for non-violence largely holds despite growing outrage over US immigration enforcement in city

Six protesters were arrested by police in Portland, Oregon, late on Thursday, as an appeal for calm from local leaders largely held despite growing outrage over federal immigration enforcement in the city after two people were shot by US border patrol agents.

On Friday afternoon, dozens of protesters gathered again outside an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) facility in Portland, holding signs that denounced ICE agents as ‚Äúthugs‚Äù and ‚ÄúNazis‚Äù.

item.title: Federal immigration officers pull out of Louisiana to head to Minneapolis
item.description:
Move marks abrupt pivot from operation that drew protests in New Orleans and arrested 370 people of a planned 5,000

Federal immigration officers are pulling out of a Louisiana crackdown and heading to Minneapolis in an abrupt pivot from an operation that drew protests around New Orleans and aimed to make thousands of arrests, according to documents obtained by the Associated Press.

The shift appeared to signal a wind-down of the Louisiana deployment that was dubbed ‚ÄúCatahoula Crunch‚Äù and began in December with the arrival of more than 200 officers. The operation had been expected to last into February and swiftly raised fears in immigrant communities.

Continue reading...

A Maryland woman has been released and reunited with her family after spending 25 days in Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) custody ‚Äì despite her attorneys saying documentation showed she was born in the US and therefore is a citizen.

Dulce Consuelo D√≠az Morales and her legal team maintain she was born in the US and possess records supporting that claim. ICE, however, had disputed this, asserting she is a Mexican citizen who entered the US unlawfully.

item.title: Renee Nicole Good said ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not mad at you‚Äô before ICE agent shot her, video shows
item.description:
Clip first posted by partisan outlet Alpha News shows perspective of ICE agent as Good was fatally shot

Renee Nicole Good calmly said everything was ‚Äúfine‚Äù and ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not mad at you‚Äù seconds before an on-duty Immigration Customs Enforcement agent fatally shot her in Minneapolis as she drove away, according to a cellphone video shared on Friday by Donald Trump‚Äôs White House.

The partisan media outlet Alpha News first posted the video on X, a 47-second clip that showed the perspective of the ICE agent ‚Äì and captured a man‚Äôs voice calling Good a ‚Äúfucking bitch‚Äù after she was mortally wounded. It was then shared by the White House‚Äôs official Rapid Response X account as well as JD Vance, with the vice-president writing in part that he agreed with the notion that Good‚Äôs death was ‚Äúa tragedy‚Äù but accused the media of dishonestly covering the circumstances of her killing.

Continue reading...

item.title: The weak spot in this job market
item.description:
The rate of jobless Americans who‚Äôve been out of work for over 27 weeks ‚Äî also known as ‚Äúlong-term unemployed‚Äù ‚Äî hit 26% in December, according to the latest jobs report. That‚Äôs the highest it‚Äôs been since February 2022. In this episode, why the rate is rising and what it says about the broader economy. Plus: Businesses curb 2026 growth plans, a farmer discusses AI in agriculture, and we check in with an Asheville, North Carolina, tea company over a year since Hurricane Helene.

item.description:

The Washington National Opera (WNO) announced on Friday it is moving its performances out of the John F Kennedy Center, in what could be one of the most significant departures from the institution since Trump took control of it.

‚ÄúToday, the Washington National Opera announced its decision to seek an amicable early termination of its affiliation agreement with the Kennedy Center and resume operations as a fully independent nonprofit entity,‚Äù the opera said in a statement to the New York Times. A separate website appears to be set up for the opera.

item.title: Free agent outfielder Max Kepler hit with 80-game ban for positive drug test
item.description:
• Kepler banned after testing positive for epitrenbolone

  • Suspension applies if free agent signs in 2026

  • Veteran outfielder spent last season with Phillies

Free agent outfielder Max Kepler has been suspended for 80 games after testing positive for a banned performance-enhancing substance, Major League Baseball announced on Friday, a ruling that sidelines the veteran as he looks for his next club.

The suspension stems from a positive test for epitrenbolone, a metabolite of the prohibited steroid trenbolone prohibited under MLB‚Äôs Joint Drug Prevention and Treatment Program. The ban takes effect immediately and would apply if Kepler signs with a team during the 2026 season.

Continue reading...

item.title: Minneapolis mayor accuses federal authorities of ‚Äòhiding facts‚Äô in ICE killing
item.description:
Jacob Frey criticizes Trump administration‚Äôs response to shooting death of Renee Nicole Good

Officials in Minneapolis on Friday accused federal authorities of ‚Äúhiding the facts‚Äù over the killing of a US citizen by an officer with the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency, and demanded the inclusion of state investigators in the FBI inquiry.

Jacob Frey, the Minnesota city‚Äôs Democratic mayor, criticized the Trump administration‚Äôs response to the shooting, speaking at a press conference two days after the death of Renee Nicole Good in her car in a confrontation with federal officers amid protests and community scrutiny during an immigration crackdown.

Continue reading...

item.title: France taps out as G7 summit moved to avoid clash with White House UFC event
item.description:
Paris has shifted this year‚Äôs Group of 7 summit after Donald Trump confirmed plans for a UFC fight card on the White House lawn on 14 June, his 80th birthday

France has delayed this year‚Äôs Group of 7 summit by one day to avoid a scheduling conflict with an Ultimate Fighting Championship fight card planned at the White House on 14 June, according to two officials with direct knowledge of the G7‚Äôs preparations.

The summit, hosted by France in the Alpine resort town of Evian-les-Bains, was originally scheduled for 14 to 16 June, a date that coincides with US Flag Day and US president Donald Trump‚Äôs 80th birthday. It will now run from 15 to 17 June, a change that has been reflected on the G7‚Äôs official website.

Continue reading...

item.title: Tech titans divided over whether to pay billionaire tax or flee California
item.description:
State residents worth more than $1bn could face one-off, 5% tax to help fund education, food assistance and healthcare

A battle is brewing in California over a plan to tax billionaires ‚Äì with tech titans divided over whether they should pay up, or flee the state.

Under a tax proposal that could be put to voters this November, any California resident worth more than $1bn would have to pay a one-off, 5% tax on their assets to help cover education, food assistance and healthcare programs in the state.

Continue reading...

Under a [tax proposal](https://www.cabillionairetax.org/) that could be put to voters this November, any California resident worth more than $1bn would have to pay a one-off, 5% tax on their assets to help cover education, food assistance and healthcare programs in the state.

item.title: California is completely drought-free for the first time in 25 years
item.description:
Some wet years and recent winter storms have helped bring the state out of drought after years of insufficient rainfall

California is completely drought-free for the first time in a quarter of a century, a significant development in a state that endured grueling years with insufficient rainfall.

Over the last 25 years, drought conditions in California have intensified the state‚Äôs wildfire crisis and created challenges in its massive agricultural sector. But a few wet years, and a recent spate of winter storms, helped bring the state out of drought.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Some wet years and recent winter storms have helped bring the state out of drought after years of insufficient rainfall
[California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california) is completely drought-free for the first time in a quarter of a century, a significant development in a state that endured grueling years with insufficient rainfall.
Over the last 25 years, drought conditions in California have intensified the state‚Äôs [wildfire](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-wildfires) crisis and created challenges in its massive agricultural sector. But a few wet years, and a recent spate of winter storms, helped bring the state out of drought.

item.title: Pennsylvania man charged after alleged ‚Äòhorrific‚Äô grave robbing from cemetery
item.description:
Over 100 pieces of human remains including skulls and headless torsos found in car and home of Jonathan Gerlach

A Pennsylvania man suspected of desecrating a historic cemetery in his state is facing hundreds of charges pertaining to grave robbery after authorities recently found more than 100 pieces of human remains in his possession, prompting one official to call the case ‚Äúthe most horrific thing‚Äù.

Jonathan Gerlach, 34, had human skulls, bones, mummified feet, headless torsos and other corpse parts ‚Äì including in his car, home and storage locker ‚Äì after his arrest on Tuesday, according to a sworn police statement reported by NBC News.

Continue reading...

item.title: High costs, falling returns: what could go wrong for Trump‚Äôs Venezuela oil gamble?
item.description:
US faces big challenges in trying to unlock ‚Äòtremendous wealth‚Äô from Venezuela‚Äôs long-neglected oil industry

Donald Trump has laid claim to billions of dollars‚Äô worth of Venezuelan crude this week, which at a stroke has handed the world‚Äôs biggest consumer of oil up to 50m barrels ‚Äì but his ambitions are far greater.

The White House said Venezuela would be ‚Äúturning over‚Äù the nearly $3bn (¬£2.3bn) of crude stranded in tankers and storage facilities before it is sold on the international market and after that the US plans to control all the country‚Äôs oil sales ‚Äúindefinitely‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US faces big challenges in trying to unlock ‚Äòtremendous wealth‚Äô from Venezuela‚Äôs long-neglected oil industry

item.title: Elon Musk‚Äôs xAI tells investors it will build AI for Tesla Optimus, amid breach of fiduciary duty lawsuit
item.description:
In a move that completely undermines the ‚ÄúTesla is an AI company‚Äù narrative, Elon Musk‚Äôs private startup, xAI, has reportedly told investors that it plans to build the AI to power Tesla‚Äôs Optimus robot.

This new development comes from a Bloomberg report detailing xAI‚Äôs widening losses and massive cash burn. According to the report, xAI executives explicitly told investors that their goal is to ‚Äúdevelop self-sufficient AI to power robots like Tesla‚Äôs Optimus.‚Äù

This is a massive shift in the narrative and potentially the smoking gun in ongoing shareholder lawsuits regarding Musk‚Äôs breach of fiduciary duty.

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2026/01/Tesla-Optimus-xAI.png?w=1600)
In a move that completely undermines the ‚ÄúTesla is an AI company‚Äù narrative, Elon Musk‚Äôs private startup, xAI, has reportedly told investors that it plans to build the AI to power Tesla‚Äôs Optimus robot.
This new development comes from a [Bloomberg report](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-09/musk-s-xai-reports-higher-quarterly-loss-plans-to-power-optimus) detailing xAI‚Äôs widening losses and massive cash burn. According to the report, xAI executives explicitly told investors that their goal is to ‚Äúdevelop self-sufficient AI to power robots like Tesla‚Äôs Optimus.‚Äù
This is a massive shift in the narrative and potentially the smoking gun in ongoing shareholder lawsuits regarding Musk‚Äôs breach of fiduciary duty.

item.title: How independent journalism is a form of resistance: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not answering to anyone‚Äô
item.description:
Trump‚Äôs attacks on mainstream media have opened a window for journalists who want to operate independently

When Donald Trump retook office last January, many national newsrooms braced for what lay ahead. There was the expected firehose of news, with the president issuing dozens of executive orders in his first week alone. Then there was the fear and tension over the president‚Äôs history of attacking and suing news organizations over unfavorable coverage. Meanwhile, audience trust in media was at an all-time low.

While it was a turbulent time for traditional media, it opened a window for independent journalists like Marisa Kabas, who is not beholden to covering Trump‚Äôs every move, nor saddled with decades of institutional distrust. On 27 January, she received a massive scoop she published in her newsletter, the Handbasket: the US office of management and budget was freezing federal grants. Getting to that news first only led to more exclusives and subscribers.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trump‚Äôs attacks on mainstream media have opened a window for journalists who want to operate independently
When Donald Trump retook office last January, many national newsrooms braced for what lay ahead. There was the expected firehose of news, with the president issuing [dozens of executive orders](https://www.federalregister.gov/presidential-documents/executive-orders/donald-trump/2025) in his first week alone. Then there was the fear and tension over the president‚Äôs history of attacking and suing [news organizations over unfavorable coverage](https://firstamendmentwatch.org/tag/trump-suing-for-defamation/). Meanwhile, audience [trust in media](https://news.gallup.com/poll/651977/americans-trust-media-remains-trend-low.aspx) was at an all-time low.
While it was a turbulent time for traditional media, it opened a window for independent journalists like Marisa Kabas, who is not beholden to covering Trump‚Äôs every move, nor saddled with decades of institutional distrust. On 27 January, she received a massive scoop she published in her newsletter, [the Handbasket](https://www.thehandbasket.co/p/omb-memo-freeze-federal-grants-scoop): the US office of management and budget was freezing federal grants. Getting to that news first only led to more exclusives and subscribers.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/09/independent-journalism-resistance-trump)

item.title: Doge cuts cost US taxpayers $10bn to cover workers‚Äô paid leave, analysis finds
item.description:
Analysis estimates Trump administration ‚Äòwasted‚Äô billions to compensate over 154,000 federal employees on leave

The Trump administration ‚Äúwasted‚Äù $10bn on paid leave, or paying workers to stay home, as part of the ‚Äúdepartment of government efficiency‚Äôs‚Äù assault on the federal workforce, a new analysis by Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility (Peer) estimates.

In a letter sent to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), Peer estimates that more than 154,000 employees were put on paid leave in 2025, making up nearly 7% of the federal civilian workforce. That costs taxpayers approximately $10bn in compensation for workers who were staying home and not working.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Analysis estimates Trump administration ‚Äòwasted‚Äô billions to compensate over 154,000 federal employees on leave
The [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) ‚Äúwasted‚Äù $10bn [on paid leave](https://peer.org/letter-to-opm-acting-director-charles-ezell-federal-employee-administrative-leave/), or paying workers to stay home, as part of the ‚Äúdepartment of government efficiency‚Äôs‚Äù assault on the federal workforce, a new analysis by Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility (Peer) [estimates](https://peer.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/12_30_25-letter-to-GAO-and-attachments.pdf).
In a [letter sent to](https://peer.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/12_30_25-letter-to-GAO-and-attachments.pdf) the Government Accountability Office (GAO), Peer estimates that more than 154,000 employees were put on paid leave in 2025, making up nearly 7% of the federal civilian workforce. That costs taxpayers approximately $10bn in compensation for workers who were staying home and not working.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/09/doge-taxpayer-costs-federal-workers)

item.title: US border patrol agents shoot two people in Portland
item.description:
Police say pair are in hospital but condition not known, as mayor urges ICE to pause operations

US border patrol agents shot two people outside a hospital in Portland, Oregon, a day after an ICE officer shot and killed a woman in Minneapolis.

The Portland police bureau (PPB) said in a statement on Thursday afternoon that two people were in hospital after a shooting involving federal agents, adding that the conditions of those shot were not known.

Continue reading...

item.title: Thousands of New York City nurses set to strike amid contract disputes
item.description:
Nearly 16,000 nurses to join union-led strike on Monday to demand large hospitals across NYC ‚Äòput patients over profit‚Äô

Nearly 16,000 nurses in New York City are set to strike on Monday amid a battle over safe staffing, healthcare benefits, pay and workplace safety during contract negotiations.

The action, due to take place across five large hospitals, is being organized by the New York State Nurses Association (NYSNA), which is demanding the hospitals put patients over profit.

item.title: Federal officers blocked medics from scene of ICE shooting, witnesses say
item.description:
‚ÄòWe have our own medics,‚Äô bystanders were told after ICE agent fatally shot Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis

Witnesses to an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agent fatally shooting Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis on Wednesday say federal officers impeded the response of emergency medical personnel to the scene, blocking the road with their vehicles.

Emily Heller, a witness who lives near the intersection of 34th Street and Portland Avenue, recorded the scene as it unfolded. She told NBC News that agents blocked people from approaching Good‚Äôs vehicle. Her video shows a man who identified himself as a physician asking to check for a pulse and being rebuffed.

Continue reading...

item.title: Two people shot by US federal agents in Portland | First Thing
item.description:
Portland‚Äôs mayor called for ICE to pause operations in the city. Plus, Emmylou Harris on her unlikely life as a country star

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

US federal agents shot two people outside a hospital in Portland a day after an ICE officer fatally shot a woman in Minneapolis.

What do local officials say? Portland‚Äôs mayor, Keith Wilson said: ‚ÄúWe know what the federal government says happened here. There was a time when we could take them at their word. That time is long past.‚Äù He called for ICE to pause operations in Portland until the investigation was complete.

How are Democrats reacting to the shooting of Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis? Some are threatening to use the next funding deadline to forcibly restrain ICE.

The Guardian has debunked the false claims about Good‚Äôs killing here.

What did he say about Venezuela? When asked how long he would be ‚Äúrunning Venezuela‚Äù, Trump said for ‚Äúmuch longer‚Äù than a year.

What about Greenland? It ‚Äúmay be a choice‚Äù between obtaining Greenland or preserving the Nato alliance, he said.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Portland‚Äôs mayor called for ICE to pause operations in the city. Plus, Emmylou Harris on her unlikely life as a country star
- [**Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here**](https://www.theguardian.com/info/2018/sep/17/guardian-us-morning-briefing-sign-up-to-stay-informed)
Good morning.
US federal agents [shot two people outside a hospital in Portland](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/portland-federal-agents-shooting) a day after an ICE officer fatally shot a woman in Minneapolis.
**What** **do local officials** **say?** Portland‚Äôs mayor, Keith Wilson said: ‚ÄúWe know what the federal government says happened here. There was a time when we could take them at their word. That time is long past.‚Äù He called for ICE to pause operations in Portland until the investigation was complete.
**How are Democrats reacting to the shooting of Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis?** Some are threatening to [use the next funding deadline](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/democrats-homeland-security-renee-nicole-good) to forcibly restrain ICE.
**The Guardian has debunked** the false [claims about Good‚Äôs killing here.](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/09/white-house-minneapolis-ice-killing)
**What did he say about Venezuela?** When [asked how long](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/09/morality-military-might-and-a-sense-of-mischief-key-takeaways-from-trumps-new-york-times-interview) he would be ‚Äúrunning Venezuela‚Äù, Trump said for ‚Äúmuch longer‚Äù than a year.
**What about Greenland?** It ‚Äúmay be a choice‚Äù between obtaining Greenland or preserving the Nato alliance, he said.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/09/first-thing-two-people-shot-by-federal-agents-portland)

item.title: Bytes: Week in Review ‚Äì New year, new state AI laws, new showdown with Trump admin.
item.description:
X, formerly Twitter, is facing a global backlash because users are directing the platform's AI chatbot, Grok, to generate non-consensual intimate imagery. Users have been popping up in the replies of women ‚Äî and sometimes minors ‚Äî tagging Grok and asking it to generate images of them in bikinis or undressed.


The company and its owner, Elon Musk, have both clarified illegal content will not be tolerated on the platform.


Plus, President Donald Trump signed an executive order late last year aimed at blocking states from enforcing local AI regulations ‚Äî something a majority have adopted in some form.


And, Meta is a victim of its own success. Its new Ray-Ban smart glasses are selling too fast to keep up with demand.


Marketplace‚Äôs Meghan McCarty Carino spoke with Maria Curi, tech policy reporter at Axios, to discuss all these topics on this week‚Äôs Marketplace Tech Bytes: Week in Review.
item.source:markdown:
X, formerly Twitter, is facing a global backlash because users are directing the platform's AI chatbot, Grok, to generate non-consensual intimate imagery. Users have been popping up in the replies of women ‚Äî and sometimes minors ‚Äî tagging Grok and asking it to generate images of them in bikinis or undressed.
The company and its owner, Elon Musk, have both clarified illegal content will not be tolerated on the platform.
Plus, President Donald Trump signed an executive order late last year aimed at blocking states from enforcing local AI regulations ‚Äî something a majority have adopted in some form.
And, Meta is a victim of its own success. Its new Ray-Ban smart glasses are selling too fast to keep up with demand.
Marketplace‚Äôs Meghan McCarty Carino spoke with Maria Curi, tech policy reporter at Axios, to discuss all these topics on this week‚Äôs Marketplace Tech Bytes: Week in Review.

item.title: Trump administration unleashes torrent of untruths after woman shot dead by ICE
item.description:
Victim-blaming began almost as soon as Renee Nicole Good was killed ‚Äì we examine the claims and the reality

The killing of a US citizen by a federal immigration agent in Minneapolis was a five-alarm fire for the Trump administration. But a torrent of untruths, half-truths, smears and innuendo has been unleashed by the White House, and amplified by its social media and cable television acolytes, in an attempt to douse the flames.

Hakeem Jeffries, the Democratic House minority leader, called the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, a ‚Äústone cold liar‚Äù on Thursday for her efforts to falsely portray the victim, Renee Nicole Good, a 37-year-old mother of three and award-winning poet, as a ‚Äúdomestic terrorist‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Victim-blaming began almost as soon as Renee Nicole Good was killed ‚Äì we examine the claims and the reality
The killing of a US citizen by a federal immigration agent in [Minneapolis](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/minneapolis) was a five-alarm fire for the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration). But a torrent of untruths, half-truths, smears and innuendo has been unleashed by the White House, and amplified by its social media and cable television acolytes, in an attempt to douse the flames.
Hakeem Jeffries, the Democratic House minority leader, called the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, a ‚Äústone cold liar‚Äù on Thursday for her efforts to falsely portray the victim, [Renee Nicole Good](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/minnesota-ice-shooting-nicole-macklin-good), a 37-year-old mother of three and award-winning poet, as a ‚Äúdomestic terrorist‚Äù.

item.title: Blade Outboards launches affordable new electric boat motors
item.description:
Electric outboards have long been pitched as the cleaner, quieter alternative to gas motors. But according to Blade, ideology alone isn‚Äôt enough to convince boaters to switch. The numbers actually have to work, or folks won‚Äôt be able to make the switch.

more‚Ä¶

item.title: NFL playoff predictions: who will seize a wide-open Super Bowl race?
item.description:
The postseason kicks off on Saturday. Our writers pick the dark horses, players to watch and make their tips for the NFL‚Äôs championship game

Melissa is right about the Lions (see below), but how about the Dallas Cowboys? Their defense was nauseating, and nobody wants a playoff weekend spoiled watching that. But their offense was electric. They finished fifth in the league in EPA/play in the regular season. And with Dak Prescott, a solid o-line and George Pickens and CeeDee Lamb, they had the potential to drop 30 points on any playoff group. If they‚Äôd snuck in and managed to knock off a top seed, it would have convinced Jerry Jones that he was on the right path. And nothing is funnier than Jones failing to recognize that the reason why Dallas is stuck is the reflection in his mirror. Oliver Connolly

Continue reading...

item.title: Beck‚Äôs late scramble sends Miami past Ole Miss into College Football Playoff title game
item.description:
• Beck‚Äôs late TD run seals 31-27 CFP semi-final win

  • Ole Miss rallies late after coach Kiffin‚Äôs LSU departure

  • Miami to chase first title since 2001 on home field

Carson Beck scrambled for a three-yard touchdown with 18 seconds left, and Miami will head back home for a shot at their first national championship since 2001 after beating Mississippi 31-27 in an exhilarating College Football Playoff semi-final at the Fiesta Bowl on Thursday night.

‚ÄúWe never flinched,‚Äù said Beck, who threw for 268 yards and two touchdowns with an interception. ‚ÄúIn the face of adversity, when we had to respond, we responded.‚Äù

item.title: Democrats threaten to withhold funding after ICE killing in Minneapolis
item.description:
Lawmakers issue warning about homeland security budget after shooting death by federal agent of Renee Nicole Good

A day after an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer shot and killed a 37-year-old US citizen in Minneapolis, Democrats on Capitol Hill are demanding restraints on the agency Donald Trump has empowered to carry out his mass deportation campaign ‚Äì and some are threatening to use the next funding deadline to force those changes.

Democrats sharply condemned the Trump administration over the killing of Renee Nicole Good, demanding accountability after the president; JD Vancethe vice-president; and the secretary of homeland security, Kristi Noem repeatedly claimed that the officer acted in ‚Äúself-defense‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Lawmakers issue warning about homeland security budget after shooting death by federal agent of Renee Nicole Good
A day after an [Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ice-us-immigration-and-customs-enforcement) shot and killed a 37-year-old US citizen in Minneapolis, Democrats on Capitol Hill are demanding restraints on the agency Donald Trump has empowered to carry out his mass deportation campaign ‚Äì and some are threatening to use the next funding deadline to force those changes.
Democrats sharply condemned the Trump administration over [the killing of Renee Nicole Good](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/minneapolis-ice-renee-nicole-good), demanding accountability after the president; JD Vancethe vice-president; and the secretary of homeland security, Kristi Noem repeatedly claimed that the officer acted in ‚Äúself-defense‚Äù.

item.title: How Lime increased ridership over 60% by letting people sit down
item.description:
Sometimes innovation isn‚Äôt simply about going faster or adding more tech. Sometimes it‚Äôs as simple as giving people a seat.

That appears to be the case in Seattle, where Lime says its ridership jumped by an eye-opening 61% last year. According to the company, a major contributor to that growth was the LimeGlider ‚Äì a seated electric scooter that blends elements of scooters, bikes, and mopeds into a single, highly approachable form factor.

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2025/04/lime-glider-header.jpg?quality=82&strip=all&w=1600)
Sometimes innovation isn‚Äôt simply about going faster or adding more tech. Sometimes it‚Äôs as simple as giving people a seat.
That appears to be the case in Seattle, where [Lime](http://li.me) says its ridership jumped by an eye-opening 61% last year. According to the company, a major contributor to that growth was the [LimeGlider](https://electrek.co/2025/04/22/lime-officially-launches-new-e-bike-and-electric-moped-into-broader-sharing-fleets/) ‚Äì a seated electric scooter that blends elements of scooters, bikes, and mopeds into a single, highly approachable form factor.

Since early December, agents from Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Customs and Border Protection and Homeland Security Investigations ‚Äì many of them masked and brandishing rifles ‚Äì have grabbed people at hardware stores and gyms, or outside homes and schools around the cities.

They have violently tackled undocumented immigrants as well as US citizens, including advocates and protestors.

item.title: Tennessee university reinstates professor fired for post criticizing Charlie Kirk
item.description:
Austin Peay State University will also pay theater and dance professor Darren Michael $500,000 in settlement

Austin Peay State University has reinstated a professor who was fired for his social media post after the killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. The Tennessee school is also paying the teacher $500,000 in the settlement.

Austin Peay spokesperson Brian Dunn said Darren Michael returned to his position as a tenured faculty member at the public university in Clarksville effective 30 December. A copy of the settlement agreement obtained through a public records request includes a $500,000 payment and reimbursement of counseling, as reported earlier this week by WKRN-TV.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Austin Peay State University will also pay theater and dance professor Darren Michael $500,000 in settlement
Austin Peay State University has reinstated a professor who was fired for his social media post after the killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. The Tennessee school is also paying the teacher $500,000 in the settlement.
Austin Peay spokesperson Brian Dunn said Darren Michael returned to his position as a tenured faculty member at the public university in Clarksville effective 30 December. A copy of the settlement agreement obtained through a public records request includes a $500,000 payment and reimbursement of counseling, as [reported earlier this week](https://www.wkrn.com/news/local-news/clarksville/apsu-settles-with-professor-fired-over-charlie-kirk-post/) by WKRN-TV.

item.title: Productivity climbs ‚Äî without hiring to match
item.description:
Labor economists will tell ya, productivity growth leads to more hiring. The idea is, once a company is operating more efficiently, they‚Äôll try expanding, which usually comes with new jobs. But in this frustrating and bizarre economy, data show major productivity gains and a stagnant labor market ‚Ä¶ coexisting? Also in this episode: New York City expands a free child care program, one reporter tries to do the job(s) of the federal government, and economists expect a less-grim December jobs report.

Democrat Ro Khanna and Republican Thomas Massie seek to compel justice department to release full set of files

Two US House of Representatives members have asked a federal judge to appoint a special master to compel the justice department to release all files related to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier and convicted sex offender.

On Thursday, Democratic representative Ro Khanna of California and Republican representative Thomas Massie of Kentucky asked US district judge Paul Engelmayer to release the full Epstein files, as required by the Epstein Files Transparency Act.

item.title: US House breaks with Trump to revive Affordable Care Act subsidies
item.description:
Seventeen Republicans join Democrats to pass a three-year extension of tax credits cutting ACA premiums

The US House of Representatives on Thursday passed legislation to re-establish tax credits that lowered premiums for Affordable Care Act (ACA) health plans, after a small group of Republicans broke ranks and joined with Democrats to defy Donald Trump on a key healthcare issue that could sway voters ahead of the November midterm elections.

The chamber voted 230-196 to approve a bill that would extend for three years the credits, which were first created under Joe Biden but expired at the end of last year despite a concerted effort by the Democratic minority to continue them.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

The US House of Representatives on Thursday passed legislation to re-establish tax credits that lowered premiums for Affordable Care Act (ACA) health plans, after a small group of Republicans broke ranks and joined with Democrats to defy [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) on a key healthcare issue that could sway voters ahead of the November midterm elections.
The chamber voted 230-196 to approve a bill that would extend for three years the credits, which were first created under Joe Biden but expired at the end of last year despite a concerted effort by the Democratic minority to continue them.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/affordable-care-act-subsidies-vote)

item.title: ICE agent in Minneapolis killing identified as 10-year law enforcement veteran
item.description:
Court records point to Jonathan E Ross as officer in Renee Nicole Good‚Äôs death, amid protests and political fallout

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

The ICE agent involved in the lethal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Nicole Good during an immigration sweep in Minneapolis on Wednesday is Jonathan E Ross, according to court records that closely match the description of a June 2025 incident involving the agent in Bloomington, Minnesota, cited by the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, and JD Vance. Ross is a Minneapolis resident and 10-year veteran of the special response team of ICE‚Äôs enforcement and removal operation.

The death of Good, a mother of three, sparked outrage in Minneapolis and strident rebukes from Minnesota officials and on Capitol Hill. Thousands of people gathered in protest near the site of the shooting Wednesday night, and some Democrats on Capitol Hill have threatened to withhold funding to the Department of Homeland Security. Minneapolis mayor, Jacob Frey, said on Wednesday: ‚ÄúTo ICE: get the fuck out of Minneapolis.‚Äù

Continue reading...

Ross is a Minneapolis resident and 10-year veteran of the special response team of ICE‚Äôs enforcement and removal operation.
The death of Good, a mother of three, sparked outrage in Minneapolis and strident rebukes from Minnesota officials and on Capitol Hill. item.title: General Motors reports $7bn earnings loss after pulling back from EVs
item.description:
GM says end of tax incentives and less stringent emissions regulations slowed consumer demand for EVs in 2025

General Motors said on Thursday it will record a one-time earnings hit of $7.1bn in its quarterly financial results, mostly due to its pullback from electric vehicles in light of shifting US policies.

The Detroit auto giant‚Äôs fourth-quarter results will be dented by $6bn in charges connected to reversals on EV investments, according to a securities filing. The remaining $1.1bn includes costs from the company‚Äôs restructuring of its China operations.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
GM says end of tax incentives and less stringent emissions regulations slowed consumer demand for EVs in 2025
[General Motors](https://www.theguardian.com/business/generalmotors) said on Thursday it will record a one-time earnings hit of $7.1bn in its quarterly financial results, mostly due to its pullback from [electric vehicles](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/electric-cars) in light of shifting US policies.
The Detroit auto giant‚Äôs fourth-quarter results will be dented by $6bn in charges connected to reversals on EV investments, according to a securities filing. The remaining $1.1bn includes costs from the company‚Äôs restructuring of its China operations.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/08/general-motors-earnings-loss)

item.title: Chloe Kim‚Äôs Olympic three-peat bid in doubt after dislocated shoulder
item.description:
• Kim, 25, injured shoulder during training in Laax

  • MRI will determine Olympic availability for US star

  • Two-time champion chasing historic third gold

Chloe Kim‚Äôs pursuit of an unprecedented third straight Olympic gold medal has been thrown into uncertainty after the American snowboard star dislocated her shoulder during a training session in Switzerland.

Kim, the dominant force in women‚Äôs halfpipe snowboarding for nearly a decade, revealed the injury on Thursday, sharing video of the fall that caused the scare. The injury occured while Kim was training in Laax, a regular World Cup venue and a key pre-Olympic stop on the circuit. The 25-year-old landed a maneuver cleanly but lost her edge shortly afterward, sliding awkwardly across the pipe and into the wall.

Continue reading...

item.title: Venezuela and Trump's new Monroe Doctrine
item.description:
In the wake of U.S. military action in Venezuela, including the capture of the country‚Äôs leader Nicol√°s Maduro, we‚Äôre left with questions about what this moment could mean for the future of U.S. foreign policy and the global economy. On the show today, director of the Atlantic Council‚Äôs Adrienne Arsht Latin America Center Jason Marczak joins Kimberly to explain why the Trump administration is shifting its focus back toward the Western Hemisphere, harkening back to the Monroe Doctrine. Plus, what it would take to revitalize Venezuela‚Äôs economy.


Here‚Äôs everything we talked about today:


  • "Experts react: The US just captured Maduro. What‚Äôs next for Venezuela and the region?" from the Atlantic Council
  • "Donald Trump asserts control over Venezuela‚Äîand all the Americas" from The Economist
  • "For Big Oil, Venezuela's reserves show long-term promise" from Marketplace¬†¬†
  • "What Is the Monroe Doctrine, and How Is Trump Reasserting It?" from Time
  • "Dispatches from Venezuela: Red roofs and the new ogling" from Marketplace


Join us tomorrow for ‚ÄúEconomics on Tap.‚Äù The¬†YouTube livestream¬†starts at 3:30 p.m. Pacific time, 6:30 p.m. Eastern.

item.title: Senate advances war powers resolution to stop Trump from taking further military action in Venezuela
item.description:
Democratic-led resolution requires US president to seek Congress‚Äôs approval to use military against Venezuela

The US Senate on Thursday advanced a bipartisan war powers resolution to prevent Donald Trump from taking further military action against Venezuela, after he ordered a weekend raid to capture that country‚Äôs president, Nicol√°s Maduro, without giving Congress advance notice.

The measure passed with 52 senators in favor and 47 opposed. All Democrats voted for the resolution, as did Republicans Rand Paul, Todd Young, Lisa Murkowski, Josh Hawley and Susan Collins.

item.title: FBI takes over case of ICE agent killing US woman and cuts Minnesota‚Äôs access to evidence
item.description:
Minneapolis remains on edge, with several protests planned after shooting of Renee Nicole Good

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

The FBI has taken full control of the investigation into the fatal shooting of Renee Nicole Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency (ICE) officer in Minneapolis, it emerged on Thursday.

In a statement, the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) said it was initially called upon to help investigate the shooting before federal officials ‚Äúreversed course‚Äù and said the case would be ‚Äúsolely led by the FBI‚Äù. With its access to the case materials, witnesses and evidence revoked, the BCA said it had to ‚Äúreluctantly‚Äù withdraw from the investigation.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Minneapolis remains on edge, with several protests planned after shooting of Renee Nicole Good
- [US politics live ‚Äì latest updates](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2026/jan/08/minneapolis-shooting-ice-minnesota-protests-vigils-donald-trump-latest-news-updates)
The FBI has taken full control of the investigation into [the fatal shooting](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/07/minneapolis-shooting-immigration-crackdown) of Renee Nicole Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency (ICE) officer in Minneapolis, it emerged on Thursday.
In a [statement](https://dps.mn.gov/news/bca/bca-statement-regarding-investigation-ice-fatal-shooting-minneapolis), the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) said it was initially called upon to help investigate the shooting before federal officials ‚Äúreversed course‚Äù and said the case would be ‚Äúsolely led by the FBI‚Äù. With its access to the case materials, witnesses and evidencerevoked, the BCA said it had to ‚Äúreluctantly‚Äù withdraw from the investigation.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/minneapolis-school-class-canceled-ice-killed-woman)

item.title: ‚ÄòShadow fleet‚Äô ships moving sanctioned oil reflagged to Russia at rising rate
item.description:
Lloyd‚Äôs List analysis suggests 40 suspicious vessels joined Russian registry last year, with 17 reflagged last month

  • Two oil tankers under US sanctions sailing through Channel towards Russia

Forty ships accused of belonging to a large ‚Äúshadow fleet‚Äù moving sanctioned oil for Venezuela and others were reflagged to Russia last year in an apparent attempt to gain Kremlin protection from American seizure.

Analysis by the shipping intelligence publication Lloyd‚Äôs List suggests that of those, at least 17 suspicious vessels joined the Russian registry over the past month, compared with 15 ships in the previous five months of 2025.

item.title: Elon Musk moves goalpost again: admits Tesla needs 10 billion miles for ‚Äòsafe unsupervised‚Äô FSD
item.description:
We are barely a week into 2026, and we are already seeing a significant shift in the narrative regarding Tesla‚Äôs Full Self-Driving (FSD) timeline. After missing yet another high-profile deadline to achieve unsupervised autonomy by the ‚Äúend of the year‚Äù in 2025, Elon Musk has now dropped a new metric that explains a lot ‚Äî and raises even more questions.

In a new comment today, Musk has stated that Tesla needs to accumulate roughly 10 billion miles of data to achieve ‚Äúsafe unsupervised self-driving.‚Äù

The new statement raises the question: why did Musk claim that Tesla would be unsupervised in Austin just a few weeks ago, when he knew that Tesla was nowhere near 10 billion miles?

more‚Ä¶

item.title: US serial killer confesses to 1965 murder of 18-year-old woman in New Jersey
item.description:
Police close murder case of Alys Eberhardt after confession from Richard Cottingham, known as the ‚ÄòTorso Killer‚Äô

Richard Cottingham, a US serial killer widely known as the ‚ÄúTorso Killer‚Äù, has confessed to the 1965 killing of an 18-year-old woman in New Jersey.

On Tuesday, New Jersey police announced the closure of the murder case of Alys Eberhardt after Cottingham, 79, admitted to killing her nearly six decades ago. Eberhardt, then a nursing student, was found brutally beaten and dead in her family home in Fair Lawn.

Continue reading...

item.description:
Jessica Plichta faces misdemeanor charges, which locals say is a tactic of Grand Rapids, Michigan, police to suppress protests

Jessica Plichta was arrested on 3 January after a live interview with a local news station about a Grand Rapids, Michigan, protest against the Trump administration‚Äôs seizure of Nicol√°s Maduro, Venezuela‚Äôs president, in an attack with a reported death toll of 100. The clip went immediately viral, racking up millions of views across social media. While the headlines focused on Plichta‚Äôs age (22) and that she‚Äôs a preschool teacher, Plichta believes the reason for her arrest ‚Äì seemingly the only one among roughly 200 protesters ‚Äì went beyond the day‚Äôs events.

Plichta, who recently co-founded local group Grand Rapids Opponents of War, which helped organize Saturday‚Äôs protest, had visited the Venezuelan capital of Caracas just last month, amid the Trump administration‚Äôs blockade. She was a part of a delegation to the International People‚Äôs Assembly for Sovereignty and Peace of Our Americas. Activists from dozens of groups planned to attend. But after Trump ordered that Venezuelan airspace be ‚Äúclosed in its entirety‚Äù on 29 November, many canceled their trips.

This story was amended on 8 January 2025 to correct the spelling of Emerson Wolfe.

Continue reading...

Jessica Plichta was arrested on 3 January after a live interview with a [local news station](https://www.wzzm13.com/article/news/local/protesters-professor-react-to-us-strikes-venezuela-capture-president/69-2a8c465c-17d1-48d3-adb5-541c8f757ad9) about a Grand Rapids, Michigan, protest against the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration)‚Äôs seizure of Nicol√°s Maduro, Venezuela‚Äôs president, in an attack with a reported death toll of [100](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/07/europe-greenland-denmark-us-france-trade-weather-latest-news-updates?CMP=share_btn_url&page=with%3Ablock-695f0c0d8f08e0dc61f227d9#block-695f0c0d8f08e0dc61f227d9). The clip went immediately viral, racking up millions of views across social media. While the [headlines](https://www.thedailybeast.com/donald-trump-critic-arrested-on-camera-after-speaking-out-against-maduro-venezuela-capture/) focused on Plichta‚Äôs age (22) and that she‚Äôs a preschool teacher, Plichta believes the reason for her arrest ‚Äì seemingly the only one among roughly 200 protesters ‚Äì went beyond the day‚Äôs events.
Plichta, who recently co-founded local group Grand Rapids Opponents of War, which helped organize Saturday‚Äôs protest, had visited the Venezuelan capital of Caracas just last month, amid the Trump administration‚Äôs blockade. She was a part of a delegation to the International People‚Äôs Assembly for Sovereignty and Peace of Our Americas. Activists from dozens of groups planned to attend. But after Trump ordered that Venezuelan airspace be [‚Äúclosed in its entirety‚Äù on 29 November](https://www.politico.com/news/2025/11/29/trump-venezuelan-airspace-military-00670743), many canceled their trips.
This story was amended on 8 January 2025 to correct the spelling of Emerson Wolfe.

item.title: Internet access and telephone lines cut out after protests erupt in Iran
item.description: People in Iran's capital shouted from their homes and rallied in the street Thursday night after the country's exiled crown prince called for a mass demonstration, witnesses said, a new escalation in the protests that have spread nationwide across the Islamic Republic. Internet access and telephone lines in Iran cut out immediately after the protests began.

Staff warn that the homeland security secretary‚Äôs proposed cuts could weaken Fema‚Äôs disaster response

Current and former staff at the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) expressed outraged over reports that the agency has drafted plans to eliminate thousands of staff in 2026 ‚Äì part of a broader restructuring effort being overseen by the homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem.

‚ÄúThe Trump administration seems determined to continue weakening the agency‚Äôs efforts to help people before, during and after disasters,‚Äù said Jeremy Edwards, former spokesperson for Fema and the White House during Joe Biden‚Äôs presidency.

item.title: Senators claim UnitedHealth is withholding internal documents from inquiry
item.description:
UnitedHealth says it will ‚Äòcontinue to engage‚Äô with lawmakers who began investigating their involvement in nursing home care after Guardian investigation

UnitedHealth has refused to hand over key internal records to lawmakers investigating the company‚Äôs efforts to reduce hospital transfers for nursing home residents, according to a 7 January letter sent to the company by the US senators Ron Wyden and Elizabeth Warren.

The veteran lawmakers, both members of the powerful Senate finance committee, launched their inquiry last summer following a Guardian investigation into bonuses that UnitedHealth pays to nursing homes that reduce hospital transfers for their residents. Those are hospitalizations the insurance giant would otherwise have to pay for.

UnitedHealth did not directly respond to questions from the Guardian about the senators‚Äô assertion that the company had failed to turn over internal documents. But it said in a statement that it will ‚Äúcontinue to engage‚Äù with the senators and that its nursing home care program ‚Äúimproves outcomes‚Äù and ‚Äúreduces unnecessary hospitalizations‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
UnitedHealth says it will ‚Äòcontinue to engage‚Äô with lawmakers who began investigating their involvement in nursing home care after Guardian investigation
UnitedHealth has refused to hand over key internal records to lawmakers investigating the company‚Äôs [efforts to reduce hospital transfers](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2025/dec/17/unitedhealth-nursing-homes) for nursing home residents, according to a 7 January letter sent to the company by the US senators Ron Wyden and Elizabeth Warren.
The veteran lawmakers, both members of the powerful Senate finance committee, launched their inquiry last summer following a [Guardian investigation](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/may/21/unitedhealth-nursing-homes-payments-hospital-transfers) into bonuses that UnitedHealth pays to nursing homes that reduce hospital transfers for their residents. Those are hospitalizations the insurance giant would otherwise have to pay for.
UnitedHealth did not directly respond to questions from the Guardian about the senators‚Äô assertion that the company had failed to turn over internal documents. But it said in a statement that it will ‚Äúcontinue to engage‚Äù with the senators and that its nursing home care program ‚Äúimproves outcomes‚Äù and ‚Äúreduces unnecessary hospitalizations‚Äù.

item.title: Outrage as Trump withdraws from key UN climate treaty along with dozens of international organisations
item.description:
Experts decry move to leave UNFCCC as ‚Äòembarrassing‚Äô as president orders withdrawal from 66 international groups

Donald Trump has sparked outrage by announcing the US will exit the foundational international agreement to address the climate crisis, cementing the US‚Äôs utter isolation from the global effort to confront dangerously escalating temperatures.

In a presidential memorandum issued on Wednesday, Trump withdrew from the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), along with 65 other organizations, agencies and commissions, calling them ‚Äúcontrary to the interests of the United States‚Äù.

item.title: US actions in Venezuela put the 2026 World Cup in disgraceful company | Leander Schaerlaeckens
item.description:
In 1934 and 1978, Fifa‚Äôs big event was given over to authoritarian aims. There‚Äôs no more doubt that 2026 will be the same

By 1934, it was entirely evident what Benito Mussolini was up to. Italy‚Äôs dictator had already consolidated power, colonized Libya and annexed the city of Rijeka. He nevertheless got to stage the second-ever World Cup, managing it with a heavy hand and even supplanting the Jules Rimet trophy with a far larger one. Hosting and winning that World Cup didn‚Äôt sate his expansionist appetites. By the end of the decade, Mussolini would take Ethiopia, annex Albania and back Francisco Franco in the Spanish civil war.

It was equally well established in 1978 in Argentina that General Jorge Rafa√©l Videla‚Äôs military junta, which had taken over two years earlier, was maintaining its grip on power through systematic detention, torture and murder. Still, protestations from other nations were ignored and the World Cup kicked off.

Leander Schaerlaeckens‚Äô book on the United States men‚Äôs national soccer team, The Long Game, is out on May 12. You can preorder it here. He teaches at Marist University.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
In 1934 and 1978, Fifa‚Äôs big event was given over to authoritarian aims. There‚Äôs no more doubt that 2026 will be the same
By 1934, it was entirely evident what Benito Mussolini was up to. Italy‚Äôs dictator had already consolidated power, colonized Libya and annexed the city of Rijeka. He nevertheless got to stage the second-ever World Cup, [managing it with a heavy hand](https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/apr/01/world-cup-moments-1938-italy-benito-mussolini) and even supplanting the Jules Rimet trophy with a far larger one. Hosting and winning that World Cup didn‚Äôt sate his expansionist appetites. By the end of the decade, Mussolini would take Ethiopia, annex Albania and back Francisco Franco in the Spanish civil war.
It was equally well established in 1978 in Argentina that General Jorge Rafa√©l Videla‚Äôs military junta, which had taken over two years earlier, was maintaining its grip on power through [systematic detention, torture and murder](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/may/17/jorge-rafael-videla). Still, protestations from other nations were ignored and the World Cup kicked off.
_Leander Schaerlaeckens‚Äô book on the United States men‚Äôs national soccer team, The Long Game, is out on May 12. You can [preorder it here](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/722130/the-long-game-by-leander-schaerlaeckens/). He teaches at Marist University._

item.title: After LA fires, struggles for the homes still standing
item.description: The homes still left standing after last year‚Äôs Eaton Fire face their own set of questions and challenges. What types of structures stand up better to fire damage than others? item.title: Thousands protest in Colombia as Trump and Petro agree to meet ‚Äì¬†video
item.description:
President Gustavo Petro announced on Wednesday that he had agreed to meet Donald Trump after calling for Colombians to take to the streets in a 'day of national mobilisation' against the US president's military threats. Anger mounted in Colombia after the US intervention in Venezuela and the capture of Nicol√°s Maduro last week. On Sunday, when asked if there would be a US operation in Colombia, Trump replied: 'Sounds good to me. You know why? Because they kill a lot of people.'

  • ‚ÄòOut with the Yanks!‚Äô: Thousands protest in Colombia as anger builds over Trump‚Äôs intervention in Venezuela

  • US attack on Venezuela will decide direction of South America‚Äôs vast mineral wealth

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòCatastrophic‚Äô: fears for families after Trump officials cut $10bn in social funds
item.description:
Health department‚Äôs decision to freeze money for childcare and for families in need could lead to disaster, experts say

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

The Trump administration‚Äôs sudden decision to freeze $10bn worth of federal funding for childcare and needy families has not only already thrown the US childcare system into mass confusion, but could also lead to disaster for hundreds of thousands of families within weeks, experts say.

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) announced late on Tuesday it would block California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York from drawing down money from three major social safety programs over ‚Äúserious concerns about widespread fraud and misuse of taxpayer dollars in state-administered programs‚Äù. In order to access the funding, the Democratic-run states must provide the Trump administration with extensive documentation to allay the fears of fraud.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Health department‚Äôs decision to freeze money for childcare and for families in need could lead to disaster, experts say

The [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration)‚Äôs sudden decision to freeze $10bn worth of federal funding for [childcare](https://www.theguardian.com/money/childcare) and needy families has not only already thrown the US childcare system into mass confusion, but could also lead to disaster for hundreds of thousands of families within weeks, experts say.

In order to access the funding, the Democratic-run states must provide the Trump administration with extensive documentation to allay the fears of fraud.

item.title: US national parks staff say new $100 fee for non-residents risks ‚Äòalienating visitors for decades‚Äô
item.description:
Advocates suing to reverse administration‚Äôs surcharge system that has led to passport checks and angry visitors

A new $100 fee for foreign tourists entering US national parks has triggered chaos and frustrating waits, with staff reporting long entry lines as citizenship checks are made and irate visitors regularly ditching plans to patronize some of America‚Äôs most cherished landscapes.

The new fee system, introduced by the Trump administration from 1 January, has caught many visitors and National Park Service (NPS) staff off-guard, with checks now having to be undertaken to assess nationality and tourists often turning away from entrances rather than pay the surcharge. The Guardian heard accounts of problems from several NPS staff, speaking anonymously, who work at different parks across the country.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Advocates suing to reverse administration‚Äôs surcharge system that has led to passport checks and angry visitors
A new $100 fee for foreign tourists entering US [national parks](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/national-parks) has triggered chaos and frustrating waits, with staff reporting long entry lines as citizenship checks are made and irate visitors regularly ditching plans to patronize some of America‚Äôs most cherished landscapes.
The new fee system, [introduced](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/25/national-park-fee-non-residents) by the Trump administration from 1 January, has caught many visitors and National Park Service (NPS) staff off-guard, with checks now having to be undertaken to assess nationality and tourists often turning away from entrances rather than pay the surcharge. The Guardian heard accounts of problems from several NPS staff, speaking anonymously, who work at different parks across the country.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/08/trump-national-parks-international-visitor-fee)

item.title: Trump plans to use Venezuela‚Äôs huge crude reserves ‚Äòto cut US oil price to $50 a barrel‚Äô
item.description:
President reportedly hopes falling price will cut domestic consumer energy bills

  • Business live ‚Äì latest updates

Donald Trump plans to use Venezuela‚Äôs vast crude reserves to establish control of most of the western hemisphere‚Äôs oil in an attempt to drive the market price down to about $50 (¬£37) a barrel, according to reports.

The US president has repeatedly raised the prospect of producing enough crude from Venezuela‚Äôs oilfields to drive down the US oil price from more than $56 a barrel today to about $50 in an effort to cut energy costs for consumers, according to the Wall Street Journal, which cited senior Trump administration officials.

item.title: ‚ÄòThis is not normal‚Äô: Minneapolis on edge and angry after ICE killing of woman amid federal surge
item.description:
City targeted by Trump has seen swarm of immigration agents on the streets ‚Äì and residents say the tension is palpable

Edwin Torres DeSantiago received a text message on Wednesday morning as he was tracking immigration enforcement across Minneapolis ‚Äì a person was shot by ICE at 34th Street and Portland Avenue.

He jumped into his car to head to the scene. Torres DeSantiago manages the Immigrant Defense Network, a group that monitors ICE activity and responds to community needs after someone is taken. He has responded to dozens of scenes in the past few months, and even more in the last few days since the federal government surged its presence in the midwestern city.

Continue reading...

item.title: With Venezuela, Trump has achieved his dream of making his own 80s action movie
item.description:
Given his rise during the ego joyride of the 1980s, it‚Äôs no shock that Trump‚Äôs foreign policy is to emulate that decade‚Äôs belligerent cinema

The box office barnstormer of 2026 arrived early this year. A sleazy banana-republic dictator flooding the American streets with blow. The over-the-border Delta Force extraction squad sent to pluck this schmo out of his impregnable fortress. The bronzed tough-talker who‚Äôs firing an RPG up the tailpipe of the international rules-based order ‚Äì but who gets the job done. Call it: Caracas Thunder.

Sounds like a bit of a throwback, you might be thinking. But, judging by his press conference after the US military‚Äôs abduction of Venezuelan president Nicol√°s Maduro, Donald Trump seemed to have finally achieved his dream of directing his own 80s action movie.

Continue reading...

item.title: Surveillance cameras livestreamed for the internet to see
item.description:
For the past couple months, YouTube technologist Benn Jordan has been investigating Flock Safety surveillance cameras. With the help of 404 Media, they found that many of these cameras were not only tracking, zooming and following every passerby, but the footage was freely accessible on the internet.


Jordan joined Marketplace Tech host Meghan McCarty Carino to talk about how he found the footage and the dangers the surveillance system poses to privacy and other civil liberties. Remember, Big Brother is always watching.
item.source:markdown:
For the past couple months, YouTube technologist Benn Jordan has been investigating Flock Safety surveillance cameras. With the help of 404 Media, they found that many of these cameras were not only tracking, zooming and following every passerby, but the footage was freely accessible on the internet.
Jordan joined Marketplace Tech host Meghan McCarty Carino to talk about how he found the footage and the dangers the surveillance system poses to privacy and other civil liberties. Remember, Big Brother is always watching.

item.title: Trump's tariff fight at the Supreme Court could make for a messy refund battle for businesses

item.title: Kicking zones and a ban on losing teams: NFL playoff tweaks we‚Äôd like to see
item.description:
The postseason consistently serves up enthralling football. But there are ways to make it even more compelling

No legitimate Super Bowl champion should have a losing record in the regular season. The Panthers, crowned NFC South champions at 8-9, are not an outlier. Since 2010, five teams with losing records have made the postseason. The 2022 Bucs were the first team to make the dance with a losing record since the league instituted a 17-game schedule. This season, the NFC South has done it again.

Continue reading...

item.title: The Timberwolves should not play until ICE violence in Minneapolis is held to account | Lee Escobedo
item.description:
A federal enforcement operation ended with a woman dead and the facts contested. The NBA cannot treat state violence in a residential neighborhood as background noise

The SUV sat motionless against a tree on a south Minneapolis street, its engine quiet, angled as if it had simply run out of gas. Except the windshield bore a small shattered star, delicate and sharp, like a snowflake pressed into glass. Cold Minnesota air leaked through the fracture, settling over the still body inside. The car became a sealed room, a thin shell holding death in place, surrounded by the stuffed animals of the woman‚Äôs children.

In the street, witnesses screamed. Not in words, but in sounds that come before language, as reality breaks faster than thought.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
A federal enforcement operation ended with a woman dead and the facts contested. The NBA cannot treat state violence in a residential neighborhood as background noise

Except the windshield bore a small shattered star, delicate and sharp, like a snowflake pressed into glass. Cold Minnesota air leaked through the fracture, settling over the still body inside. The car became a sealed room, a thin shell holding death in place, surrounded [by the stuffed animals](https://x.com/adamemedia/status/2009038936396509522?s=46) of the woman‚Äôs children.
In the street, witnesses screamed. Not in words, but in sounds that come before language, as reality breaks faster than thought.

item.title: Amber Glenn sets US short program record to edge Alysa Liu at nationals
item.description:
• Glenn reclaims short program record at nationals

  • Liu close behind as Olympic spots near decision

  • Efimova, Mitrofanov lead pairs amid eligibility wait

Two-time defending champion Amber Glenn set the record for a women‚Äôs short program at the US Figure Skating Championships on Wednesday night, giving her a narrow lead over world champion Alysa Liu heading into the free skate.

Liu had broken the record mere minutes earlier with a score of 81.11 points, earning a standing ovation from a crowd packed into the home of the St Louis Blues. But then Glenn took the ice and was flawless from an opening triple axel to a finishing combination spin, earning 83.05 points, a hug from coach Damon Allen and a standing ovation of her own.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trae Young traded to Washington Wizards as Atlanta Hawks move on from franchise star
item.description:
• Hawks trade Young, ending eight-year partnership

  • Wizards land four-time All-Star as rebuild centerpiece

  • McCollum, Kispert head to Atlanta in return

Trae Young‚Äôs tenure in Atlanta is over, with the Hawks agreeing to trade the high-scoring and frequently criticized guard to the Washington Wizards for a package including veteran CJ McCollum, a person with knowledge of the move said Wednesday night.

Corey Kispert is also headed from Washington to Atlanta, said the person, who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the trade had not received the required league approval. The person said the league‚Äôs trade call will not take place before Thursday. Typically, teams cannot discuss pending trades until they are approved by the league.

item.title: US seizes two tankers as Trump widens oil grab and says Venezuela will buy American goods with proceeds from oil sale ‚Äì live
item.description:
US takes over two tankers, one Russian-flagged in the North Atlantic and the other Venezuela-linked in the Caribbean; Trump says Caracas will be ‚Äòpurchasing only American Made Products‚Äô

  • Explainer: why so much interest in a rusty tanker in the Atlantic?

Meanwhile, in the UK, Nigel Farage has offered his take on Trump‚Äôs plans to control Greenland, saying it would be ‚Äúoutrageous‚Äù for the US to seize it from Denmark.

Farage says he agrees with Starmer that the fate of Greenland must be decided by Greenland and Denmark, not the US ‚Äì but sided with Trump on ‚Äúsome genuine security concerns‚Äù that require further presence there.

‚ÄúWhat I will say is this. There are some genuine security concerns around Greenland and that becomes ever more relevant with a retraction of the ice caps as we head towards the North Pole. There is a strong feeling in British intelligence circles, and many in Nato, that there needs to be a significant Nato base located directly on the north of Greenland.

At the moment, it would appear that is something Greenland is not particularly keen to do.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US takes over two tankers, one Russian-flagged in the North Atlantic and the other Venezuela-linked in the Caribbean; Trump says Caracas will be ‚Äòpurchasing only American Made Products‚Äô
- [Explainer: why so much interest in a rusty tanker in the Atlantic?](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/07/marinera-seized-tanker-atlantic-us-uk-russia)
Meanwhile, in the UK, **Nigel Farage has offered his take on Trump‚Äôs plans to control Greenland, saying it would be ‚Äúoutrageous‚Äù for the US to seize it from Denmark.**
**Farage** says he agrees with Starmer that the fate of Greenland must be decided by Greenland and Denmark, not the US ‚Äì but sided with Trump on ‚Äúsome genuine security concerns‚Äù that require further presence there.
_‚ÄúWhat I will say is this. **There are some genuine security concerns around Greenland** and that becomes ever more relevant with a retraction of the ice caps as we head towards the North Pole. There is a strong feeling in British intelligence circles, and many in Nato, that **there needs to be a significant Nato base located directly on the north of Greenland.**_
_At the moment, **it would appear that is something Greenland is not particularly keen to do.**_
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/07/europe-greenland-denmark-us-france-trade-weather-latest-news-updates)

item.title: Labor market anxieties grow
item.description:
The job market has been steadily losing steam and workers have noticed. Though the unemployment rate remains fairly low, some groups are experiencing heightened job-finding trouble, and overall employment sentiment is falling. In this episode, are job market worriers paranoid or prophetic? Plus: Nvidia CEO announces new AI chips won‚Äôt require as-expensive cooling systems, car sales were up in 2025, and economists study why new tariffs haven't dinged the economy much ‚Äî yet.

item.title: Shock and outrage at scene of Minneapolis ICE shooting: ‚ÄòThis is just sad‚Äô
item.description:
People gathered at the scene of the killing to protest after city‚Äôs mayor demands ICE ‚Äòget the fuck out‚Äô

When a federal agent shot and killed a woman during a large-scale immigration enforcement operation in Minneapolis on Wednesday, the Guardian was nearby, shadowing observers who have trained for months to monitor and respond to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) activity in the state.

ICE vehicles, unmarked, lined the street, and yellow police tape cordoned off the area in the immediate aftermath of the shooting. Dozens of protesters and community members were seen on the snowy street, shouting at ICE agents and at the local police. More agents arrived amid the chaos.

Continue reading...

item.title: A ‚Äòday of love‚Äô with more than 100 casualties
item.description:
The White House‚Äôs official retelling of the January 6 insurrection strains credulity

  • This was originally published in This Week in Trumpland; sign up to receive it in your inbox every Wednesday

According to Donald Trump, it was a day of love. For those who watched the violent insurrection on January 6, and for the more than 140 law enforcement officers injured that day, it didn‚Äôt seem like there was much love on show.

Live video footage showed scores of Trump supporters smashing windows, beating police officers and scrambling over each other as they broke into the Capitol building, in an attempt to overturn the result of the 2020 election. ‚ÄúThe most shameful day in American history,‚Äù Guardian writer Robert Reich called it.

Continue reading...

item.title: Marco Rubio says he will meet Danish officials to discuss Greenland next week
item.description:
Remarks by US secretary of state come after Greenland and Denmark request urgent meeting over Trump threats

  • Europe live ‚Äì latest updates

The US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, says he plans to meet Danish officials next week to discuss Greenland as a crisis escalates within Nato over Donald Trump‚Äôs threats to take over the Arctic territory.

An urgent meeting had been requested by the foreign ministers of Greenland and Denmark, which has said that any invasion or seizure of the territory by its Nato ally would mark the end of the western military alliance and ‚Äúpost-second world war security‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: US seizes Russian-flagged oil tanker in Atlantic after two-week pursuit
item.description:
US European Command says it boarded the Marinera over alleged sanctions violations, a move that risks confrontation with Moscow

  • Europe live ‚Äì latest updates

The US has seized a Russian-flagged oil tanker in the Atlantic Ocean in a high-stakes operation that could risk confrontation with the Kremlin after Moscow reportedly dispatched a submarine to safeguard the vessel.

US European Command said on Wednesday that it had boarded the Marinera over alleged sanctions violations, bringing to an end a dramatic two-week pursuit that began in the Caribbean and concluded in the Atlantic.

item.title: Trump says he will ban big investors from buying single-family homes
item.description:
Median sale price was at $410,800 last year, according to the Census Bureau, even as Trump campaigned on affordability

Donald Trump said his administration was moving to ban large institutional investors from buying single-family homes in a bid to reduce home prices.

In a post on Truth Social, his social media platform, the US president said he will be asking Congress to codify the measure and will be discussing additional housing and affordability proposals in a speech at the Davos World Economic Forum.

item.title: Elon Musk wishes NVIDIA luck on self-driving, strangely silent on Hyundai‚Äôs humanoid robot
item.description:
CES 2026 in Las Vegas has been dominated by two things: the next generation of AI compute and a sudden explosion of credible humanoid robots.

While Tesla isn‚Äôt officially exhibiting on the floor, Elon Musk has been actively monitoring the event from X. His reactions, and lack thereof, to the major announcements give us a fascinating look into how Tesla views the rapidly crowding field of autonomy.

Musk was quick to comment on NVIDIA‚Äôs major push into embedded AI for autonomous systems, but he has been noticeably quiet regarding the masterclass put on by Hyundai and Boston Dynamics.

more‚Ä¶

While Tesla isn‚Äôt officially exhibiting on the floor, Elon Musk has been actively monitoring the event from X. His reactions, and lack thereof, to the major announcements give us a fascinating look into how Tesla views the rapidly crowding field of autonomy.

item.title: Trump administration releases updated dietary guidelines: ‚ÄòEat real food‚Äô
item.description:

The Trump administration has released updated dietary guidelines for Americans on Wednesday that emphasize eating whole and minimally processed foods, scaling back refined carbohydrates, and ‚Äúdeclaring war‚Äù on added sugars.

The recommendations encourage ‚Äúprioritizing high-quality protein, healthy fats, fruits, vegetables and whole grains‚Äù while steering clear of highly processed foods. Robert F Kennedy Jr, the health and human services (HHS) secretary, and Brooke Rollins, the agriculture secretary, are presenting the new guidance at a White House briefing.

item.title: US reportedly warns Maduro ally Diosdado Cabello he could be next
item.description:
Interior minister told he must back acting president, while Marco Rubio lays out three-point plan for Venezuela

The Trump administration has reportedly put Venezuela‚Äôs hardline interior minister, Diosdado Cabello, on notice that he could be next to fall if he does not support the acting president, Delcy Rodr√≠guez, who has been in power since Nicol√°s Maduro was seized on Saturday.

Reuters reported that US officials were ‚Äúespecially concerned‚Äù that Cabello, long seen by many as the regime‚Äôs real No 2, could sabotage Washington‚Äôs plan to keep key figures from Maduro‚Äôs inner circle in place in the name of stability while pursuing a transition and unrestricted access to Venezuela‚Äôs oil.

item.title: Democrats decry Venezuela attack as Republicans defend Trump after Senate briefing
item.description:
Top Trump officials briefed 100 US senators on weekend raid while defending military operation and US president

Top officials from the Trump administration arrived on Capitol Hill this morning to defend one of the most audacious military operations in recent US history: the forcible capture of a sitting head of state from his own capital.

Secretary of state Marco Rubio, defense secretary Pete Hegseth, attorney general Pam Bondi, CIA director John Ratcliffe and Gen Dan Caine, chair of the joint chiefs of staff, briefed all 100 US senators on Operation Absolute Resolve, the lightning raid that plucked the Venezuelan president, Nicol√°s Maduro, from his Caracas residence and deposited him in a New York City jail cell.

Continue reading...
