item.title: US abandons child exploitation and drug cases to prioritize ICE, Democrats allege
item.description:
Exclusive: Letter decries ‚Äòstunning abdication of basic responsibilities‚Äô and demands to know how many officers diverted

The Trump administration has abandoned efforts to combat child exploitation, human trafficking and cartels as it diverts thousands of law enforcement personnel to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Democratic senators said in a letter to the White House.

Ruben Gallego of Arizona, along with 28 other Democratic senators and one independent, wrote to the president, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Justice (DoJ) on Monday demanding that federal officials provide a ‚Äúfull accounting‚Äù of officers who have been redirected to immigration enforcement and a list of all investigations affected by the reassignments.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

The [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) has abandoned efforts to combat child exploitation, [human trafficking](https://www.theguardian.com/law/human-trafficking) and cartels as it diverts thousands of law enforcement personnel to [Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ice-us-immigration-and-customs-enforcement), Democratic senators said in a letter to the White House.
Ruben Gallego of Arizona, along with 28 other Democratic senators and one independent, wrote to the president, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Justice (DoJ) on Monday demanding that federal officials provide a ‚Äúfull accounting‚Äù of officers who have been redirected to immigration enforcement and a list of all investigations affected by the reassignments.

Every player at the World Cup this summer will have his own physically accurate ‚ÄúAI avatar‚Äù that will be used in taking video assistant referee (VAR) decisions.

The innovation, which will involve every player being digitally scanned and leaves the possibility of size mattering in offside calls, was part of a package of ¬≠technological ¬≠measures announced by Fifa‚Äôs president, Gianni Infantino, as he made a keynote appearance at the Consumer Electronic Show in Las Vegas.

item.title: Carter George hopes to inspire Thunder Bay, Ont.'s next crop of NHL talent
item.description: Thunder Bay has long been known as a hockey hotbed, sending dozens of local players to the National Hockey League, and even a pair of players to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Yet, when it comes to the annual World Junior Ice Hockey Championships, Thunder Bay‚Äôs representation is comparatively low. This year‚Äôs tournament marked the second World Juniors selection for Thunder Bay‚Äôs Carter George, whose selection in last year‚Äôs event marked the first time a player from the city was selected since Mackenzie Blackwood in 2016.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Trump lawyer ordered to defend using US attorney title despite ruling it‚Äôs unlawful
item.description:
Lindsey Halligan was installed in the position by the president to prosecute Letitia James and James Comey

A judge has ordered the Donald Trump-appointed lawyer who led failed prosecutions of two of his political opponents to explain why she is still representing herself as US attorney for the eastern district of Virginia, after another judge ruled she was in the position unlawfully.

In an order filed in the district‚Äôs Richmond division on Tuesday, Lindsey Halligan was given seven days to explain why she had engaged in ‚Äúprofessional misconduct‚Äù by continuing to sign indictments.

item.title: Letenda is building new 30-ft electric midibus built for Canadian winters
item.description:
A new player in the electric transit space, Quebec-based Letenda, is trying to solve a problem that has plagued the transition to electric buses in North America: the ‚Äúmissing middle.‚Äù While we have seen plenty of full-size 40-foot electric buses and smaller shuttles, the 30-foot ‚Äúmidibus‚Äù market has been largely underserved.

Letenda thinks they have the answer with the ‚ÄúElectrip,‚Äù a ground-up design that focuses heavily on winter efficiency and a modular build.

more‚Ä¶

item.title: Three LA wildfire victims on surviving the horror ‚Äì and what happened next
item.description:
After their lives were upended last year, they‚Äôre finally regaining their footing ‚Äì but memories of the fires still haunt them

Few among the nearly 10 million people who live in Los Angeles county were left untouched by last year‚Äôs disastrous firestorm. Driven by strong winds through parched vegetation, multiple fires exploded in quick succession last January, and devoured roughly 16,000 structures on all sides of LA.

Thirty-one lives were lost and thousands more were for ever changed. For many, a new chapter of the disaster began to unfold when the flames were extinguished, while the slow road to recovery started to take shape in the year that followed.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

Driven by strong winds through parched vegetation, multiple fires exploded in quick succession last January, and devoured roughly 16,000 structures on all sides of LA.
Thirty-one lives were lost and thousands more were for ever changed. For many, a new chapter of the disaster began to unfold when the flames were extinguished, while the slow road to recovery started to take shape in the year that followed.

item.title: ‚ÄòDirty‚Äô and ‚Äòinfested with drugs‚Äô: the New York jail holding Maduro and Mangione
item.description:
High-profile names including Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs have resided in Metropolitan detention center, accused of unsafe, inhumane conditions

After US military forces seized Nicol√°s Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, in Caracas during a controversial pre-dawn raid, they were ultimately spirited to one of this country‚Äôs most infamous jails: Metropolitan detention center in Brooklyn, New York.

The deposed Venezuelan president and Flores will almost certainly reside in Metropolitan detention center (MDC) until their federal trial on drugs and weapons charge ‚Äì inducting them into a notorious group that counts Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs, Ghislaine Maxwell, Sam Bankman-Fried, and Mexican drug kingpin ‚ÄúEl Chapo‚Äù as either current or previous members.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
High-profile names including Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs have resided in Metropolitan detention center, accused of unsafe, inhumane conditions
After US military forces [seized](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/03/why-trump-us-attacked-caracas-captured-venezuela-president-nicolas-maduro) [Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/world/nicolas-maduro) and his wife, Cilia Flores, in Caracas during a controversial pre-dawn raid, they were ultimately spirited to one of this country‚Äôs most infamous jails: Metropolitan detention center in Brooklyn, [New York](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/new-york).
The deposed Venezuelan president and Flores will almost certainly reside in Metropolitan detention center (MDC) until their federal trial on drugs and weapons charge ‚Äì inducting them into a notorious group that counts [Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2024/nov/02/drug-weapon-sweep-brooklyn-jail-sean-diddy-combs), [Ghislaine Maxwell](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/jun/16/ghislaine-maxwell-new-york-jail-sewage), [Sam Bankman-Fried](https://www.theguardian.com/business/sam-bankman-fried), and Mexican drug kingpin ‚Äú [El Chapo](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/30/el-chapo-guzman-harsh-prison-conditions-new-york)‚Äù as either current or previous members.

item.title: US suspends funds for needy families in five Democratic-led states
item.description:
Administration has alleged fraud in decision to halt grants from California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York

Donald Trump‚Äôs administration said Tuesday that it is withholding funding for programs that support needy families with children in five Democratic-led states over concerns about fraud.

The US Department of Health and Human Services, which oversees the program, will require the states to provide extra documentation to access the funds.

The child care and development fund subsidizes day care for low-income households, enabling parents to work or go to school.

Temporary assistance for needy families provides cash assistance and job training so parents in poverty can afford diapers and clothes and earn paychecks.

The social services block grant, a much smaller fund, supports several different social service programs.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Administration has alleged fraud in decision to halt grants from California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York
Donald [Trump‚Äôs administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) said Tuesday that it is withholding funding for programs that support needy families with children in five Democratic-led states over concerns about fraud.
The US Department of Health and Human Services, which oversees the program, will require the states to provide extra documentation to access the funds.
The child care and development fund subsidizes day care for low-income households, enabling parents to work or go to school.
Temporary assistance for needy families provides cash assistance and job training so parents in poverty can afford diapers and clothes and earn paychecks.
The social services block grant, a much smaller fund, supports several different social service programs.

item.title: More gen Z men live with parents in this city than anywhere in the US. How do they date?
item.description:
In Vallejo, California, ‚Äòtrad sons‚Äô report feeling trapped by family obligations, slim job prospects and the fear of violence ‚Äì leaving little room for romance

Are boys becoming men later? In recent decades, the markers of adulthood have shifted for young American men: they are almost twice as likely to be single, less likely to go to college and more likely to be unemployed. Most significantly for their parents, they are also less likely to have fled the nest, with the term ‚Äútrad son‚Äù springing into social media lexicon in recent months. In the 1970s, only 8% of Americans aged 25 to 34 were living with their parents, but by 2023, that figure had jumped to 18%, with men more likely to live at home than women, according to a Pew survey.

But not everywhere in the US has the same rates of adults living in their familial home. The living arrangement is least common in the midwest and most common in the north-east. Topping the list was Vallejo, where 33% of young adults live with their parents. How were they making it work?

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
In Vallejo, California, ‚Äòtrad sons‚Äô report feeling trapped by family obligations, slim job prospects and the fear of violence ‚Äì leaving little room for romance
Are boys becoming men later? In recent decades, the markers of adulthood have shifted for young American men: they are almost twice as likely to be [single](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/02/08/for-valentines-day-5-facts-about-single-americans/), less likely to [go to college](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/12/18/fewer-young-men-are-in-college-especially-at-4-year-schools/) and more likely to be [unemployed](https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-men-are-more-unemployed-than-women-healthcare-tech-2025-8). Most significantly for their parents, they are also less likely to have fled the nest, with the term ‚Äú [trad son](https://people.com/what-is-a-trad-son-11836688)‚Äù springing into social media lexicon in recent months. In the 1970s, only 8% of Americans aged 25 to 34 were living with their parents, but by 2023, that figure had jumped to 18%, with men more likely to live at home than women, according to a [Pew survey](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/04/17/the-shares-of-young-adults-living-with-parents-vary-widely-across-the-us/).
But not everywhere in the US has the same rates of adults living in their familial home. The living arrangement is least common in the midwest and most common in the north-east. Topping the list was Vallejo, where 33% of young adults live with their parents. How were they making it work?
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/07/dating-while-living-with-parents-vallejo-california)

item.title: Former Bengals and Texas receiver Jordan Shipley severely burned in ranch accident
item.description:
• 40-year-old was flown to Austin after accident

  • Shipley played three seasons in NFL

Former Texas star and NFL receiver Jordan Shipley is being treated in hospital after suffering severe burns in an accident on his ranch near his home town of Burnet, Texas.

According to a statement from his family, Shipley was operating a machine when it caught fire. Although the 40-year-old was able to free himself from the machine ‚Äúit was not before sustaining severe burns on his body in the process,‚Äù read the statement. ‚ÄúHe was able to get to one of his workers on the ranch who drove him to a local hospital. He was then care-flighted to Austin, where he remains in critical but stable condition.‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: Recovery remains slow for Eaton Fire survivors
item.description: A survey released in the fall finds that most people displaced by the Southern California wildfires a year ago are still living in temporary housing. Since so few homes have been rebuilt, how are people paying for shelter? Today, we'll hear how survivors have organized to demand accountability and the resources needed. Plus, a semiconductor chip shortage echoes the great supply chain crisis of 2020, but this time it's driven by AI.

item.title: Greenland has become the island that could break NATO
item.description: European leaders have sounded the alarm over Donald Trump‚Äôs ambitions to take over Greenland, but the U.S. president may instead be thinking of his legacy. item.title: Thousands stranded amid flight cancellations in Amsterdam
item.description: From the BBC World Service: One of Europe's busiest airports has canceled more than 700 flights today as a disruption caused by snow and ice enters a sixth day. The problem was made worse because of a shortage of anti-freeze for de-icing planes at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam. Dutch airline KLM is the main one affected. Then, China's Foreign Ministry calls President Donald Trump's demands for Venezuelan oil "typical bullying" from the U.S.

item.title: White House says using US military ‚Äòalways an option‚Äô for acquiring Greenland | First Thing
item.description:
Trump demands Venezuela open up to US oil companies or risk more military action. Plus, justice department has released less than 1% of Epstein files

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

Donald Trump and his advisers are looking at ‚Äúa range of options‚Äù in an effort to acquire Greenland, noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is ‚Äúalways an option‚Äù.

How are the US‚Äôs European allies responding? In a show of solidarity on Tuesday, the leaders of France, Germany, the UK and other countries issued a joint statement with the prime minister of Denmark, Mette Frederiksen, urging the US to respect its sovereignty. They said Arctic security was a top priority for Nato, a defense alliance that includes the US and Greenland. ‚ÄúGreenland belongs to its people,‚Äù the statement said.

What would a deal of this kind signify? Top Venezuelan officials have called Maduro‚Äôs capture a kidnapping and accused the US of trying to steal the country‚Äôs vast oil reserves. However, Tuesday‚Äôs agreement is a strong sign that the government is responding to Trump‚Äôs demand that it open up to US oil companies or risk more military intervention.

Continue reading...

Donald Trump and his advisers are looking at ‚Äúa range of options‚Äù in [an effort to acquire Greenland](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/06/trump-greenland-control-us-military), noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is ‚Äúalways an option‚Äù.
**How are the US‚Äôs European allies responding?** In a show of solidarity on Tuesday, the leaders of France, Germany, the UK and other countries issued a joint statement with the prime minister of Denmark, Mette Frederiksen, urging the US to respect its sovereignty. They said Arctic security was a top priority for Nato, a defense alliance that includes the US and Greenland. ‚ÄúGreenland belongs to its people,‚Äù the statement said.
**What would a deal of this kind signify?** Top Venezuelan officials have called Maduro‚Äôs capture a kidnapping and accused the US of trying to steal the country‚Äôs vast oil reserves. However, Tuesday‚Äôs agreement is a strong sign that the government is responding to Trump‚Äôs demand that it [open up](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/06/trump-us-taxpayers-oil-firms-venezuela-investment) to US oil companies or risk more military intervention.

item.title: ‚ÄòAstounding‚Äô vaccine change puts US behind peer countries, experts warn
item.description:
Scientists predict increased disease outbreaks after Trump officials no longer recommend third of childhood vaccines

The bombshell announcement that the Trump administration no longer fully recommends a third of childhood vaccines means the US moved from leading globally on vaccination to lagging behind other high-income nations in preventing disease, experts say.

The move is the latest and most significant escalation against vaccines from Robert F Kennedy Jr, a longtime vaccine skeptic and current secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Scientists predict increased disease outbreaks after Trump officials no longer recommend third of childhood vaccines
The bombshell announcement that the Trump administration no longer fully recommends [a third of childhood vaccines](https://www.theguardian.com/society/2026/jan/05/trump-rfk-jr-child-vaccine-recommendations) means the US moved from leading globally on vaccination to lagging behind other high-income nations in preventing disease, experts say.
The move is the latest and most significant escalation against vaccines from Robert F Kennedy Jr, a longtime vaccine skeptic and current secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

item.title: The 2026 World Cup may transform US soccer. The 2030 World Cup could be even better
item.description:
This summer‚Äôs tournament is seen as a culmination, but in truth it‚Äôs the next World Cup where the USMNT may have the most success

When the US was confirmed as a future World Cup co-host on the eve of the 2018 tournament in Russia, the USMNT were still stuck under the rubble of their shocking failure to qualify. Mauricio Pochettino was just establishing himself among European club soccer‚Äôs managerial elite, taking Tottenham to the Champions League final a year later.

Few could have imagined that he‚Äôd be leading the USMNT into the 2026 World Cup, and perhaps fewer believe he‚Äôll stick around for the next cycle. Nevertheless, after a 2-1 win over Australia in Commerce City, Colorado to end the October window, Pochettino noted he‚Äôs building a team with 2030 in mind, too.

Continue reading...

item.title: Farming in the digital age
item.description:
Over a century ago, farmers exchanged their horses and plows for the automated tractor. Generations of farmers have come, gone and watched technology transform their industry.


Automation and biotechnology have continued to propel farming forward, but with the emergency of AI technology, farmers have gained another tool up their sleeve.


Andrew Nelson is a fifth-generation farmer in Farmington, Washington, and he is now using his computer science degree to help tend to his crops.
item.source:markdown:
Over a century ago, farmers exchanged their horses and plows for the automated tractor. Generations of farmers have come, gone and watched technology transform their industry.
Automation and biotechnology have continued to propel farming forward, but with the emergency of AI technology, farmers have gained [another tool up their sleeve.](https://www.marketplace.org/episode/2025/05/20/california-farmers-reshape-agriculture-with-cutting-edge-tech)
Andrew Nelson is a fifth-generation farmer in Farmington, Washington, and he is now using his computer science degree to help tend to his crops.

item.title: Turbulence is getting worse. Would it be better if planes looked more like birds?
item.description: Pilots can‚Äôt see it coming, and it‚Äôs hard to avoid. But severe clear-air turbulence can shake a plane ‚Äòlike King Kong.‚Äô It‚Äôs on the rise, and forecast to get worse due to climate change. ‚ÄúThis Oil will be sold at its Market Price, and that money will be controlled by me, as President of the United States of America, to ensure it is used to benefit the people of Venezuela and the United States!‚Äù Trump said in a post online.

item.title: White House says using US military is ‚Äòalways an option‚Äô for acquiring Greenland
item.description:
European leaders push back forcefully against US president‚Äôs desire to seek takeover of Arctic territory

Donald Trump and his advisers are looking into ‚Äúa range of options‚Äù in an effort to acquire Greenland, noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is ‚Äúalways an option‚Äù.

‚ÄúPresident Trump has made it well known that acquiring Greenland is a national security priority of the United States, and it‚Äôs vital to deter our adversaries in the Arctic region. The president and his team are discussing a range of options to pursue this important foreign policy goal, and of course, utilizing the US military is always an option at the commander-in-chief‚Äôs disposal,‚Äù White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement.

Continue reading...

Donald Trump and his advisers are looking into ‚Äúa range of options‚Äù in an effort to acquire Greenland, noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is ‚Äúalways an option‚Äù.
‚ÄúPresident Trump has made it well known that acquiring Greenland is a national security priority of the United States, and it‚Äôs vital to deter our adversaries in the Arctic region. item.title: Corporations expected to take on record debt in 2026
item.description:
This year, amid ongoing economic uncertainty, corporations are expected to refinance old debt, invest in artificial intelligence, and prep for mergers and acquisitions. All of which require extra cash. And how do corporations stretch their budgets? By taking on more debt, of course. Later in this episode: An Altadena small business owner struggles to rebuild after the LA fires, Texas pitmasters weigh rising brisket prices, and Costco converts wine snobs.

item.title: John Harbaugh fired by Baltimore Ravens after 18 seasons in charge
item.description:
• Harbaugh was NFL‚Äôs second longest-tenured head coach

  • Ravens went from Super Bowl favorites to 8-9 finish

The Baltimore Ravens have fired head coach John Harbaugh after 18 seasons in charge, the team announced on Tuesday.

Harbaugh is the most successful coach in the history of the franchise and was the second longest-tenured head coach in the NFL before his dismissal. Ironically, his final game with the Ravens came against the only name ahead of him in terms of tenure length ‚Äì Mike Tomlin, who has been head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers for 19 seasons.

Continue reading...

item.title: Republicans silent and Democrats incensed on fifth anniversary of US Capitol attack
item.description:
Democrats hold hearing to examine impact of January 6, while protesters commemorate attack on Capitol grounds

Congressional Republicans were largely silent on the fifth anniversary of the January 6 insurrection on Tuesday, even as Democrats sought to use the occasion to condemn Donald Trump and a small group of protesters convened on the grounds of the US Capitol in solidarity with those who carried out the attack.

Democrats, who are in the minority in Congress after fruitlessly hoping that the well-documented violence would cause voters to reject Trump for good, seized on the anniversary to decry the president as a threat to democracy, and accuse Republicans of acting as his accomplices.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Democrats hold hearing to examine impact of January 6, while protesters commemorate attack on Capitol grounds
Congressional [Republicans](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans) were largely silent on the fifth anniversary of the [January 6 insurrection](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-capitol-breach) on Tuesday, even as [Democrats](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/democrats) sought to use the occasion to condemn [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) and a small group of protesters convened on the grounds of the US Capitol in solidarity with those who carried out the attack.
Democrats, who are in the minority in Congress after fruitlessly hoping that the well-documented violence would cause voters to reject Trump for good, seized on the anniversary to decry the president as a threat to democracy, and accuse Republicans of acting as his accomplices.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/06/january-6-us-capitol-attack-fifth-anniversary)

item.title: Top union accuses Texas of targeting teachers over Charlie Kirk posts
item.description:
American Federation of Teachers sues over what it says are unconstitutional investigations into social media comments

A major Texas teachers‚Äô union filed a federal lawsuit against the state on Tuesday challenging what it describes as unconstitutional investigations into hundreds of educators who posted comments on social media following the September killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk.

The Texas American Federation of Teachers, which represents approximately 66,000 public school employees, is asking a federal court to block the Texas Education Agency and its commissioner, Mike Morath, from continuing investigations that the union argues violate teachers‚Äô free speech protections.

Continue reading...

item.title: Winter Olympic ice hockey venues may not be finished in time for Games
item.description:

The head of the International Ice Hockey Federation said parts of the main hockey rink for the Milan Cortina Olympics might not be fully finished on time, but the playing surface, practice facilities and dressing rooms will be ready when the puck drops for the men‚Äôs event on 11 February.

‚ÄúWe can be confident on that,‚Äù IIHF President Luc Tardif told reporters Monday at the world junior championship. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to go to Milano for nothing.‚Äù

item.title: 28 years later, see the southern Quebec ice storm as it was reported in 1998
item.description: In one of the most important meteorological events in the province‚Äôs history, successive bouts of freezing rain left thick layers of ice over everything in southern Quebec during a week-long span in January 1998, knocking out power for millions of people.

item.title: Tom Izzo ‚Äòticked off‚Äô after former player ejected for criticizing officials
item.description:
• Paul Davis played for Izzo at Michigan St in the early 00s

  • Davis was ejected for verbal abuse of officials on Monday

Former Michigan State and NBA player Paul Davis was ejected from his alma mater‚Äôs Breslin Center after vocally criticizing officials from the stands during the 12th-ranked Spartans‚Äô 80-51 victory over Southern California on Monday night.

Michigan State led 67-46 with just over six minutes left when officials motioned toward the stands to point out Davis, who was eventually ordered to leave.

item.title: Pesticide industry ‚Äòimmunity shield‚Äô stripped from US appropriations bill
item.description:
Democrats and ‚Äòmake America healthy again‚Äô movement pushed back on the rider in a funding bill led by Bayer

In a setback for the pesticide industry, Democrats have succeeded in removing a rider from a congressional appropriations bill that would have helped protect pesticide makers from being sued and could have hindered state efforts to warn about pesticide risks.

Chellie Pingree, a Democratic representative from Maine and ranking member of the House appropriations interior, environment, and related agencies subcommittee, said Monday that the controversial measure pushed by the agrochemical giant Bayer and industry allies has been stripped from the 2026 funding bill.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Democrats and ‚Äòmake America healthy again‚Äô movement pushed back on the rider in a funding bill led by Bayer
In a setback for the [pesticide](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/pesticides) industry, [Democrats](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/democrats) have succeeded in removing a rider from a congressional [appropriations bill](https://appropriations.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/republicans-appropriations.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/fy26-interior%2C-environment%2C-and-related-agencies-bill-text.pdf) that would have helped protect pesticide makers from being sued and could have hindered state efforts to warn about pesticide risks.
Chellie Pingree, a Democratic representative from Maine and ranking member of the House appropriations interior, environment, and related agencies subcommittee, said Monday that the controversial measure pushed by the agrochemical giant Bayer and industry allies has been stripped from the 2026 funding bill.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2026/jan/06/pesticide-industry-protection-bill-removed)

item.title: In KemiWorld, might makes right. Just don‚Äôt mention Greenland | John Crace
item.description:
In an interview with Nick Robinson, the Tory leader made it clear she was thrilled to see the back of international law. May the best country win!

These weren‚Äôt exactly the words Kemi Badenoch had been hoping to hear. Halfway through her interview on the Today programme on Tuesday morning, the BBC presenter Nick Robinson observed that, in regard to the US coup in Venezuela, the Conservative leader‚Äôs position wasn‚Äôt that far off from Keir Starmer‚Äôs. You could sense the air go out of the room. In KemiWorld there is no greater dishonour than a likeness to the prime minister. Time for the fightback to begin. To create some distance.

OK, Kemi said. Yes, she too drew the line at Greenland. That would be a step too far. There was no need for Donald Trump to claim the country for America. That was an action that could threaten Nato. And besides, as far as she knew, Greenland wasn‚Äôt a rogue narco state. She, too believed in a world of moral relativism. One where it was fine to invade countries whose regimes we disliked. There was one rule for the west and another for the rest.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
In an interview with Nick Robinson, the Tory leader made it clear she was thrilled to see the back of international law. May the best country win!
These weren‚Äôt exactly the words Kemi Badenoch had been hoping to hear. Halfway through her interview on the Today programme on Tuesday morning, the BBC presenter Nick Robinson observed that, [in regard to the US coup in Venezuela](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/05/maduro-pleads-not-guilty), the Conservative leader‚Äôs position wasn‚Äôt that far off from Keir Starmer‚Äôs. You could sense the air go out of the room. In KemiWorld there is no greater dishonour than a likeness to the prime minister. Time for the fightback to begin. To create some distance.
OK, Kemi said. [Yes, she too drew the line at Greenland](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/06/stephen-miller-donald-trump-threats-take-over-greenland). That would be a step too far. There was no need for Donald Trump to claim the country for America. That was an action that could threaten Nato. And besides, as far as she knew, Greenland wasn‚Äôt a rogue narco state. She, too believed in a world of moral relativism. One where it was fine to invade countries whose regimes we disliked. There was one rule for the west and another for the rest.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/jan/06/kemiworld-might-makes-right-dont-mention-greenland)

item.title: NRA sues the charitable version of itself, alleging a factional ‚Äòbeef‚Äô
item.description:
New leadership claims former allies are trying to repurpose $160m in NRA Foundation donations for personal gain

The National Rifle Association (NRA) is suing its own charitable arm, the NRA Foundation, claiming that its leaders are trying to seize control of the gun rights organization and illegally ‚Äúrepurposing‚Äù $160m in donations to support their ‚Äúthirst for power‚Äù.

The allegations come in a lawsuit filed on Monday in federal court in Washington DC laying bare the turmoil that has plagued the NRA since its disgraced longtime chief executive, Wayne LaPierre, was ousted in 2024 alongside other senior figures after a financial corruption scandal.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
New leadership claims former allies are trying to repurpose $160m in NRA Foundation donations for personal gain
The National Rifle Association ( [NRA](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/nra)) is suing its own charitable arm, the NRA Foundation, claiming that its leaders are trying to seize control of the gun rights organization and illegally ‚Äúrepurposing‚Äù $160m in donations to support their ‚Äúthirst for power‚Äù.
The allegations come in a [lawsuit](https://www.washingtonpost.com/documents/55cd324b-b3f3-46c2-bc76-02fc73ad4a1c.pdf?itid=lk_inline_manual_4) filed on Monday in federal court in Washington DC laying bare the turmoil that has plagued the NRA since its disgraced longtime chief executive, Wayne LaPierre, was [ousted in 2024](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2024/jan/05/wayne-lapierre-nra-resigns-corruption-scandal) alongside other senior figures after a financial corruption scandal.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/06/nra-sues-charity)

item.title: Doug LaMalfa, California Republican congressman, dies aged 65
item.description:
LaMalfa‚Äôs death cuts the House Republican majority to 218-213, tightening GOP control for passing bills

Doug LaMalfa, a California Republican who represented the state‚Äôs rural northern region in the House of Representatives and was known for his work on water and forestry policy, has died at age 65, according to statements from Republican officials.

LaMalfa, a fourth-generation rice farmer who previously served in the California state legislature, was in his seventh term representing California‚Äôs first congressional district. He sat on the House agriculture, natural resources, and transportation and infrastructure committees.

Continue reading...

item.title: The road to rebuilding, one year after the LA wildfires
item.description:
It‚Äôs been a year since the Eaton and Palisades fires swept through Southern California, taking 31 lives and destroying over 16,000 structures ‚Äî including the homes of ‚ÄúMarketplace Morning Report‚Äù host David Brancaccio and his neighbors in Altadena. On the show today, David joins Kimberly to talk about the road to rebuilding the community and the complicated, costly task of rebuilding with fire resistant materials.


Here‚Äôs everything we talked about today:


  • "How my Altadena neighbors are rebuilding, one year since the Eaton Fire" from Marketplace¬†
  • "L.A. wildfires broke record for costliest in the history of the planet" from the San Francisco Chronicle¬†
  • "These numbers tell the story of the Los Angeles wildfires, one year later" from AP News
  • "Marketplace‚Äôs David Brancaccio on community, loss and rebuilding in Altadena" from Marketplace
  • "To rebuild homes cheaper, faster and safer, some want new rules" from Marketplace


We love hearing from you. Leave us a voicemail at 508-U-B-SMART or email¬†makemesmart@marketplace.org.
item.source:markdown:
It‚Äôs been a year since the Eaton and Palisades fires swept through Southern California, taking 31 lives and destroying [over 16,000 structures](https://apnews.com/article/los-angeles-wildfires-by-numbers-palisades-altadena-9c077a61ab1482638d12885db76dce49) ‚Äî including the homes of ‚ÄúMarketplace Morning Report‚Äù host David Brancaccio and his neighbors in Altadena. On the show today, David joins Kimberly to talk about the road to rebuilding the community and the complicated, costly task of rebuilding with fire resistant materials.
Here‚Äôs everything we talked about today:
- ["How my Altadena neighbors are rebuilding, one year since the Eaton Fire"](https://www.marketplace.org/story/2026/01/06/how-one-altadena-block-is-rebuilding-a-year-since-the-eaton-fire) from Marketplace - ["L.A. wildfires broke record for costliest in the history of the planet"](https://www.sfchronicle.com/california-wildfires/article/los-angeles-palisades-eaton-insurance-20775841.php) from the San Francisco Chronicle - ["These numbers tell the story of the Los Angeles wildfires, one year later"](https://apnews.com/article/los-angeles-wildfires-by-numbers-palisades-altadena-9c077a61ab1482638d12885db76dce49) from AP News - ["Marketplace‚Äôs David Brancaccio on community, loss and rebuilding in Altadena"](https://www.marketplace.org/story/2025/01/31/marketplaces-david-brancaccio-on-community-loss-and-rebuilding-in-altadena) from Marketplace - ["To rebuild homes cheaper, faster and safer, some want new rules"](https://www.marketplace.org/story/2025/02/27/rebuild-homes-cheaper-faster-safer-la-builders-architects) from Marketplace

item.title: George Conway, a former anti-Trump Republican, to run for Congress as a Democrat
item.description:

George Conway, the former Republican turned Donald Trump critic and ex-husband of the US president‚Äôs 2016 campaign manager and senior aide Kellyanne Conway, is running for Congress.

Conway, a conservative lawyer who helped start the Lincoln Project, a prominent anti-Trump group of Republicans, launched his bid as a Democrat seeking to represent New York‚Äôs 12th congressional district, in what will be a crowded field of contenders.

item.title: Finding a contractor one year after California's wildfires
item.description: Dustin Kunkel is a father of two, works in the solar panel business, and is a neighbor of "Marketplace Morning Report" host David Brancaccio. Kunkel lost his Altadena home in the Eaton Fire and, since then, spoke to 30 contractors before finding someone to rebuild the house. We hear what the process ‚Äî and pricing ‚Äî¬†has been like. Also, the realities of this economy continue to diverge for lower- and higher-income households.

item.title: US justice department has released less than 1% of Epstein files, filing reveals
item.description:
Federal law required majority of documents to be released by 19 December, but only 125,575 pages have been published

The Department of Justice has released less than 1% of the so-called Epstein files, a court filing has revealed, as Democrats step up criticism of the Trump administration‚Äôs ‚Äúlawlessness‚Äù for keeping records under seal.

The department conceded that only 12,285 documents, totalling 125,575 pages, relating to the disgraced financier and sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein have been published to date, despite a federal law requiring the vast majority to be released by 19 December.

Continue reading...

item.title: Two Republicans oppose Pete Hegseth‚Äôs censure of fellow Senator Mark Kelly
item.description:
Pushback from Susan Collins and Thom Tillis is striking amid tepid response from most other Republican senators

Two senior Republican senators on Monday openly opposed Pentagon secretary Pete Hegseth‚Äôs attempt to punish their fellow Senator Mark Kelly by demoting him and cutting his pension after he released a video telling active-duty military to follow the law.

Susan Collins of Maine, who chairs the Senate appropriations committee with jurisdiction over the Pentagon‚Äôs budget, said she believed it was wrong to target Kelly‚Äôs military benefits because of a political video.

Continue reading...

item.title: First Thing: US foes and allies denounce Trump‚Äôs ‚Äòcrime of aggression‚Äô in Venezuela
item.description:
Brazil, China, Colombia, Cuba, Eritrea, Mexico, Russia, South Africa and Spain condemn attack at UN meeting. Plus, why the world‚Äôs food system needs urgent change

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

The US was roundly denounced for a ‚Äúcrime of aggression‚Äù at an emergency meeting of the UN security council on Monday after the Trump administration‚Äôs deadly strikes on Venezuela and the capture of its leader, Nicol√°s Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores.

What‚Äôs the latest on the US ‚Äúrunning‚Äù Venezuela? The Republican speaker of the House, Mike Johnson, insisted the US was not at war with the country ‚Äì but the Democratic Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, warned that the US was on the brink of being dragged into a fresh conflict.

How many officers have been diverted? More than 28,000 federal law enforcement personnel have been diverted from their regular duties to work for ICE‚Äôs enforcement and removal operations, according to an ICE document from August 2025.

Continue reading...

Brazil, China, Colombia, Cuba, Eritrea, Mexico, Russia, South Africa and Spain condemn attack at UN meeting. Plus, why the world‚Äôs food system needs urgent change

Good morning.
The US was [roundly denounced](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/05/un-security-council-trump-attack-venezuela) for a ‚Äúcrime of aggression‚Äù at an emergency meeting of the UN security council on Monday after the Trump administration‚Äôs deadly strikes on Venezuela and the capture of its leader, Nicol√°s Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores.
**What‚Äôs the latest on the US ‚Äúrunning‚Äù Venezuela?** The Republican speaker of the House, Mike Johnson, [insisted](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/05/venezuela-mike-johnson-speaker-congress-briefing) the US was not at war with the country ‚Äì but the Democratic Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, warned that the US was on the brink of being dragged into a fresh conflict.
**How many officers have been diverted?** More than 28,000 federal law enforcement personnel have been diverted from their regular duties to work for ICE‚Äôs enforcement and removal operations, according to an ICE document from August 2025.

item.title: Avalanche in California‚Äôs Sierra Nevada kills snowmobiler
item.description:
Rescuers were called to the Truckee area after a 911 report of an avalanche, but the man was found dead under snow

An avalanche in California‚Äôs Sierra Nevada on Monday buried a snowmobiler in snow and killed him, authorities said.

Rescuers responded after a 911 call around 2.20pm reported a possible avalanche near Johnson Peak and Castle Peak in Truckee.

Continue reading...

item.title: US will be exempt from global tax deal targeting profits of large multinationals
item.description:
Agreement finalised by the OECD waters down a landmark 2021 deal that set a minimum global corporate tax of 15%

Nearly 150 countries have agreed on a landmark plan to stop large global companies shifting profits to low-tax jurisdictions, but the US will be exempt from the deal, angering tax transparency groups.

The plan, finalised by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, excludes large US-based multinational corporations from the 15% global minimum tax after negotiations between the Trump administration and other members of the G7.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump taking ‚Äòdrill, baby, drill‚Äô plan to Venezuela ‚Äòterrible‚Äô for climate, experts warn
item.description:
‚ÄòEverybody loses‚Äô if production supercharged in country with largest known oil reserves, critics say

Donald Trump, by dramatically seizing Nicol√°s Maduro and claiming dominion over Venezuela‚Äôs vast oil reserves, has taken his ‚Äúdrill, baby, drill‚Äù mantra global. Achieving the president‚Äôs dream of supercharging the country‚Äôs oil production would be financially challenging ‚Äì and if fulfilled, would be ‚Äúterrible for the climate‚Äù, experts say.

Trump has aggressively sought to boost oil and gas production within the US. Now, after the capture and arrest of Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, he is seeking to orchestrate a ramp-up of drilling in Venezuela, which has the largest known reserves of oil in the world ‚Äì equivalent to about 300bn barrels, according to research firm the Energy Institute.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
‚ÄòEverybody loses‚Äô if production supercharged in country with largest known oil reserves, critics say
[Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump), by dramatically seizing [Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/world/nicolas-maduro) and claiming dominion over [Venezuela](https://www.theguardian.com/world/venezuela)‚Äôs vast oil reserves, has taken his ‚Äú [drill, baby, drill](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/12/trump-fossil-fuels-oil-and-gas)‚Äù mantra global. Achieving the president‚Äôs dream of supercharging the country‚Äôs oil production would be financially challenging ‚Äì and if fulfilled, would be ‚Äúterrible for the climate‚Äù, experts say.
Trump has aggressively sought to [boost oil and gas production](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2025/jan/22/trump-big-oil-energy-priorities-explained) within the US. Now, after the capture and arrest of Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, he is seeking to orchestrate a ramp-up of drilling in Venezuela, which has the largest known reserves of oil in the world ‚Äì equivalent to about 300bn barrels, [according to](https://knowledge.energyinst.org/search/record?id=58930) research firm the Energy Institute.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/06/trump-venezuela-oil-climate-crisis)

item.title: "It felt happy. Then, 24 hours, it was gone.‚Äù
item.description: Today, we have the story of one burned block: that of "Marketplace Morning Report" host David Brancaccio. Last year's wildfires in California were the costliest in history, with more than 16,000 structures destroyed and over 30 deaths. Fifteen of the houses destroyed in the Eaton Fire sat on a single street in Altadena. A year on, we check in with Brancaccio's neighbors to hear about life, loss, and efforts to rebuild.

item.title: Michigan loophole makes it difficult to track utilities‚Äô donations to politicians
item.description:
Revelation comes as a first-in-the-nation citizen‚Äôs ballot initiative to ban donations by utilities picks up steam

An investigation into Michigan election records has found a major loophole in reporting laws that makes it difficult to track when and how campaign contributions move between lawmakers and the state‚Äôs controversial utilities, DTE Energy and Consumers Energy.

State law does not require the date that a contributor makes a donation to match the date that a campaign committee reports receiving it. That has created a scenario in which utilities throughout 2025 have cut checks for lawmakers around the time of controversial votes, but the lawmakers sometimes still have not reported receiving the contribution or report it much later.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Revelation comes as a first-in-the-nation citizen‚Äôs ballot initiative to ban donations by utilities picks up steam
An investigation into Michigan election records has found a major loophole in reporting laws that makes it difficult to track when and how campaign contributions move between lawmakers and the state‚Äôs [controversial](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jul/07/michigan-covid-lockdown-dte-energy) utilities, DTE Energy and Consumers Energy.
State law does not require the date that a contributor makes a donation to match the date that a campaign committee reports receiving it. That has created a scenario in which utilities throughout 2025 have cut checks for lawmakers around the time of controversial votes, but the lawmakers sometimes still have not reported receiving the contribution or report it much later.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/06/michigan-utilities-political-donations)

item.title: Deep in the vaults: the Bank of England‚Äôs ¬£1.4bn Venezuelan gold conundrum
item.description:
Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs seizure by US reopens question of who controls country‚Äôs reserves held in the UK

  • Trump suggests US taxpayers could reimburse oil firms

  • Business live ‚Äì latest updates

  • Venezuela live ‚Äì latest updates

Deep under London‚Äôs streets, thousands of miles from Caracas, Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs seizure by the US has reopened a multibillion-dollar question: who controls Venezuela‚Äôs gold reserves at the Bank of England?

After the ousting of Maduro, global attention has largely focused on the South American country‚Äôs vast oil wealth ‚Äì believed to be the largest reserves of any nation in the world. However, Venezuela also has significant gold holdings ‚Äì including bullion worth at least $1.95bn (¬£1.4bn) frozen in Britain.

Continue reading...

After the ousting of Maduro, global attention has largely focused on the South American country‚Äôs [vast oil wealth](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/04/venezuela-oil-industry-bust-what-role-could-the-us-play) ‚Äì believed to be the largest reserves of any nation in the world. item.title: Hockey fans throw thousands of teddy bears on to the ice for charity ‚Äì video
item.description:
Hockey fans threw thousands of stuffed animals on to the ice for the Hershey Bears annual teddy toss. The stuffed animals collected will now be distributed to over 60 local charities as part of the club‚Äôs Hershey Bears Cares program, where they will go to children in need.

The Bears collected 81,796 stuffed animals, increasing the total number of teddy bears and stuffed animals collected to 648,246 since Hershey hosted its first Teddy Bear Toss event in 2001.

Continue reading...

item.title: Bosch releases new update to make stolen e-bikes (almost) unusable
item.description:
E-bike theft is one of those problems that never really goes away. Those of us who have been victims of it will never really forget that feeling. Of course, good locks can help, and GPS trackers might assist in getting a stolen bike back. But once a bike is stolen, the real incentive for thieves is simple: resale. And that‚Äôs exactly the problem Bosch is aiming to tackle with a new software update unveiled at CES 2026.¬†

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2026/01/bosch-lock-header.jpg?quality=82&strip=all&w=1600)
E-bike theft is one of those problems that never really goes away. Those of us [who have been victims](https://electrek.co/2022/09/20/i-just-had-another-expensive-electric-bike-stolen-heres-what-would-have-stopped-it/) of it will never really forget that feeling. Of course, good locks can help, and GPS trackers might assist in getting a stolen bike back. But once a bike is stolen, the real incentive for thieves is simple: resale. And that‚Äôs exactly the problem Bosch is aiming to tackle with a new software update unveiled at CES 2026.

item.title: US ‚Äònot at war‚Äô in Venezuela, Johnson says after briefing with top officials
item.description:
Speaker says Trump not looking to take control militarily as Democrats say briefing raises more questions than answers

The United States is ‚Äúnot at war‚Äù in Venezuela, the Republican speaker of the House Mike Johnson said on Monday, despite the weekend raid Donald Trump ordered to capture president Nicol√°s Maduro and announcement that the US would now ‚Äúrun‚Äù the country.

The surprise incursion came after months of mounting US pressure on Venezuela, which has included a blockade of some oil shipments and airstrikes on vessels off its shores that have killed at least 110 people.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Speaker says Trump not looking to take control militarily as Democrats say briefing raises more questions than answers
The United States is ‚Äúnot at war‚Äù in Venezuela, the Republican speaker of the House Mike Johnson said on Monday, despite the weekend raid Donald Trump ordered to [capture president Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/03/trump-venezuela-oil-industry) and announcement that the US would now ‚Äúrun‚Äù the country.
The surprise incursion came after months of mounting US pressure on Venezuela, which has included [a blockade](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/16/trump-orders-blockade-oil-tankers-venezuela) of some oil shipments and [airstrikes on vessels](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/01/us-coast-guard-search-survivors-boat-strike-pacific-ocean) off its shores that have killed at least 110 people.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/05/venezuela-mike-johnson-speaker-congress-briefing)

item.title: Markets shrug off U.S. capture of Maduro
item.description:
Disruptive geopolitical events often push investors to jump into bonds or sell off stocks temporarily. But when the U.S. military captured Venezuelan leader Nicol√°s Maduro and President Trump declared control over the oil-rich nation, neither of those happened. In this episode, markets are largely unmoved by Trump‚Äôs military intervention. Plus: Experts say jobs data is most important for predicting where the economy is headed, and Landon Derentz at the¬†Atlantic Council Global Energy Center gives context to Venezuela‚Äôs oil infrastructure.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.


Marketplace is more than a radio show. Check out our original reporting and financial literacy content at¬†marketplace.org¬†‚Äî and consider¬†making an investment¬†in our future.

item.title: Arizona supreme court evacuated after package tests positive for explosives
item.description:

Arizona‚Äôs supreme court building was evacuated Monday morning after multiple vials that tested positive for a homemade explosive substance were sent to the building, according to the state‚Äôs department of public safety (DPS).

At about 8am on Monday, DPS responded to reports of a ‚Äúsuspicious package‚Äù. Later that morning multiple agencies, including the US Bureau of alcohol firearms and tobacco responded.

item.title: Michael Schumacher, author of Francis Ford Coppola and Eric Clapton biographies, dies aged 75
item.description:
Daughter of the Wisconsin author confirmed her father died on 29 December and did not provide cause of death

Michael Schumacher, a Wisconsin author who produced a diverse array of works ranging from biographies of film-maker Francis Ford Coppola and musician Eric Clapton to accounts of Great Lakes shipwrecks, has died. He was 75.

Schumacher‚Äôs daughter, Emily Joy Schumacher, confirmed Monday that her father died on 29 December. She did not provide the cause of death.

item.title: Protesters celebrate and denounce US capture of Maduro outside New York court
item.description:
Some demonstrators celebrated the Venezuelan president‚Äôs detention while others spoke out against US imperialism

Dozens of demonstrators of various stripes gathered outside the federal courthouse in freezing temperatures in New York on Monday to express their views on the US criminal charges against Venezuela‚Äôs forcibly removed president, Nicol√°s Maduro.

As Maduro pleaded not guilty to charges related to international drug trafficking and weapons charges inside the heavily secured court, Alejandro Flores joined other Venezuelans outside in chants that celebrated the detention of the Latin American dictator since the early hours of Saturday.

item.title: Deposed Maduro pleads not guilty after capture in shock US attack on Venezuela
item.description:
President protests innocence in US court as countries at UN meeting condemn Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äòcrime of aggression‚Äô

  • Venezuela crisis ‚Äì latest updates

The deposed Venezuelan president Nicol√°s Maduro pleaded not guilty to drugs, weapons and narco-terrorism charges on Monday, two days after his capture by US special forces in an operation ordered by Donald Trump that sent shockwaves around the world.

The brevity and formality of the arraignment hearing in federal court in Manhattan ‚Äì barely 30 minutes during which Maduro was asked to confirm his name and that he understood the four charges against him ‚Äì belied the far-reaching consequences of the US action.

Continue reading...

item.title: Corporation For Public Broadcasting formally dissolves after federal funding cuts
item.description:
Board of directors vote to dissolve organization after nearly 60 years in operation after funding cuts under Trump

The nonprofit charged by Congress with allocating funds to NPR, PBS and other US public radio and television stations announced is dissolving after massive federal funding cuts under Donald Trump.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) announced on Monday that its board of directors had voted to dissolve the organization after nearly 60 years in operation.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Board of directors vote to dissolve organization after nearly 60 years in operation after funding cuts under Trump
The nonprofit charged by Congress with allocating funds to NPR, [PBS](https://www.theguardian.com/media/pbs) and other [US public radio](https://www.theguardian.com/media/public-radio) and television stations announced is dissolving after massive federal funding cuts under Donald Trump.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) [announced](https://cpb.org/pressroom/corporation-public-broadcasting-board-votes-dissolve-organization-act-responsible) on Monday that its board of directors had voted to dissolve the organization after nearly 60 years in operation.

item.description:
Jabs to prevent influenza, rotavirus, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and other vaccines are no longer fully recommended

The Trump administration will slash routine vaccine recommendations during childhood from 17 to 11 jabs ‚Äì the biggest change to vaccines yet under the purview of longtime vaccine critic Robert F Kennedy Jr.

The changes, which US health officials announced on Monday afternoon and are effective immediately, will erode trust and reduce access to vaccines while allowing infectious diseases to spread, experts said.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòA warning not an insult‚Äô: US doubles down on criticism of Europe
item.description:
Forecast of Europe‚Äôs ‚Äòcivilisational erasure‚Äô was part of call for pro-growth reform, says Trump official

Donald Trump‚Äôs administration has doubled down on its recent criticism of Europe, saying last month‚Äôs US national security strategy was an attempt to ‚Äújolt‚Äù an ally back to economic life.

The document was widely condemned in Europe as representing a seismic shift in the 70-year transatlantic alliance with its dark references to a purported threat of ‚Äúcivilisational erasure‚Äù with migration and censorship creating ‚Äústrife‚Äù, ‚Äúcratering birthrates‚Äù and ‚Äúloss of national identities‚Äù.

item.title: US foes and allies denounce Trump‚Äôs ‚Äòcrime of aggression‚Äô in Venezuela at UN meeting
item.description:
US ambassador defends attack as ‚Äòlaw enforcement‚Äô action against an ‚Äòillegitimate‚Äô leader, not an act of war

  • The ‚ÄòPutinization‚Äô of US foreign policy has arrived in Venezuela

The US has faced widespread condemnation for a ‚Äúcrime of aggression‚Äù in Venezuela at an emergency meeting of the United Nations security council.

Brazil, China, Colombia, Cuba, Eritrea, Mexico, Russia, South Africa and Spain were among countries that on Monday denounced Donald Trump‚Äôs decision to launch deadly strikes on Venezuela and snatch its leader, Nicol√°s Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, to stand trial in the US.

item.title: US woman charged with fetal homicide after allegedly inducing own abortion
item.description:
Kentucky woman reportedly ordered medication to end her pregnancy and buried remains in her yard

A Kentucky woman is facing multiple criminal charges after she allegedly induced her own abortion using medication.

Kentucky state police arrested the woman, Melinda S Spencer, 35, on charges of fetal homicide in the first degree, abuse of a corpse and tampering with physical evidence, according to a local Kentucky news outlet. Spencer reportedly ordered medication online to end her pregnancy, then buried the remains of her pregnancy in her backyard.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Kentucky woman reportedly ordered medication to end her pregnancy and buried remains in her yard
A [Kentucky](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/kentucky) woman is facing multiple criminal charges after she allegedly induced her own abortion using medication.
Kentucky state police arrested the woman, Melinda S Spencer, 35, on charges of fetal homicide in the first degree, abuse of a corpse and tampering with physical evidence, [according to](https://www.fox10tv.com/2026/01/02/woman-charged-with-fetal-homicide-after-abortion-burying-infant-home-police-say/) a local Kentucky news outlet. Spencer reportedly ordered medication online to end her pregnancy, then buried the remains of her pregnancy in her backyard.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/02/kentucky-woman-arrest-abortion)

item.title: Despite Trump‚Äôs hopes, big oil will be wary of rushing back to Venezuela | Nils Pratley
item.description:
The US might aim to unlock the country‚Äôs reserves, but cost and political uncertainty make it look an uncertain option

  • US energy stocks rise as Trump vows to unlock Venezuela‚Äôs oil

  • Venezuela crisis ‚Äì latest updates

The theory sounds straightforward. Venezuela has vast oil reserves and used to produce more than three times as much volume as it does now. Therefore it should be a simple matter to upgrade the crumbling kit with an injection of dollars and watch the extra barrels and profits flow.

That, roughly speaking, is the only clear part of Donald Trump‚Äôs plan for what happens next in Venezuela. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have our very large US oil companies, the biggest anywhere in the world, go in, spend billions of dollars, fix the badly broken infrastructure ‚Äì the oil infrastructure ‚Äì and start making money for the country,‚Äù he said at the weekend.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
The US might aim to unlock the country‚Äôs reserves, but cost and political uncertainty make it look an uncertain option
- [US energy stocks rise as Trump vows to unlock Venezuela‚Äôs oil](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/05/oil-price-dips-venezuela)
- [Venezuela crisis ‚Äì latest updates](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/06/venezuela-live-updates-maduro-trump-us-attack-opposition-machado-return)
The theory sounds straightforward. Venezuela [has vast oil reserves](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/04/venezuela-oil-industry-bust-what-role-could-the-us-play) and used to produce more than three times as much volume as it does now. Therefore it should be a simple matter to upgrade the crumbling kit with an injection of dollars and watch the extra barrels and profits flow.
That, roughly speaking, is the only clear part of Donald Trump‚Äôs plan for what happens next in Venezuela. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have our very large US oil companies, the biggest anywhere in the world, go in, spend billions of dollars, fix the badly broken infrastructure ‚Äì the oil infrastructure ‚Äì and start making money for the country,‚Äù he said at the weekend.

item.title: Stanford students face trial over felony charges stemming from pro-Palestinian protest
item.description:
Trial is the most severe criminal case brought against US students who staged protests against Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza

Five Stanford University students are facing trial beginning on Monday over felony charges stemming from a pro-Palestinian protest on campus ‚Äì the most severe criminal case brought against some of the thousands of students who staged nationwide protests and encampments against Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza.

The northern California students are part of a group of 12 who were charged with felony conspiracy to trespass and felony vandalism in connection to an hour-long, June 2024 occupation during which the group barricaded themselves inside the university president‚Äôs office to demand Stanford consider a student resolution to divest from Israel, among other requests.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trial is the most severe criminal case brought against US students who staged protests against Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza
Five Stanford University students are facing trial beginning on Monday over felony charges stemming from a pro-Palestinian protest on campus ‚Äì the most severe criminal case brought against some of the thousands of students who staged nationwide protests and encampments against Israel‚Äôs war in Gaza.
The northern California students are part of a group of 12 who were charged with felony conspiracy to trespass and felony vandalism in connection to an hour-long, June 2024 occupation during which the group barricaded themselves inside the university president‚Äôs office to demand Stanford consider a student resolution to divest from Israel, among other requests.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/05/stanford-students-felony-case-pro-palestinian-protest)

Sporting Kansas City named Rapha√´l Wicky as the fifth permanent head coach in franchise history on Monday.

Wicky, 48, coached the Chicago Fire from 2020-21 before managing BSC Young Boys in his native Switzerland from 2022-24. He signed a contract through the 2027-28 MLS season with an option for the 2028-29 campaign.

item.title: Raiders fire Pete Carroll after one season; Tom Brady to advise on new hire
item.description:
• Las Vegas went 3-14 in Carroll‚Äôs first year as head coach

  • Team dropped 10 straight, securing No 1 draft pick

The Las Vegas Raiders fired Pete Carroll on Monday after just one year, meaning they will enter their third consecutive season with a new coach in charge.

Carroll expressed high hopes upon taking over, saying he was used to double-digit victories and he expected the same in Las Vegas. But the Raiders went 3-14, going on a 10-game losing streak before finishing with a 14-12 victory over Kansas City on Sunday.

Continue reading...

item.title: Novo Nordisk launches Wegovy weight-loss pill in US, triggering price war
item.description:
First and only GLP-1 pill on the market costs significantly less than injectable versions

The first pill version of the blockbuster GLP-1 weight loss drugs has been launched in the US by Novo Nordisk at a lower cost than jab varieties, accelerating a price war in the sector.

The Danish pharmaceutical company said on Monday that its once-a-day Wegovy pill, which received approval from the US regulator just before Christmas, was now available in the country.

Continue reading...

item.title: Dense, sticky and heavy: why Venezuelan crude oil appeals to US refineries
item.description:
South American nation‚Äôs tar-like oil is what many Gulf coast facilities were built for but ramping up production to 3m barrels a day will be a long game

Clustered along the US Gulf coast are some of the largest and most complex heavy-oil refineries in the world. These sprawling industrial hubs, owned by major US oil companies, stand ready to emerge as some of the major victors of Donald Trump‚Äôs swoop on Venezuela.

In some ways, these refineries are a relic of another time; built to process the heavy, unctuous crude imported from Latin America before the boom in lighter US shale oil emerged earlier this century.

Continue reading...

item.title: Pete Hegseth issues formal censure to Democratic senator Mark Kelly
item.description:
US defense secretary also started proceedings that could strip Kelly from retired military rank and cut pension

Defense secretary Pete Hegseth said on Monday that he had issued a formal censure to Democratic senator Mark Kelly and initiated proceedings that could strip the Arizona lawmaker of his retired military rank and cut his pension, escalating a dispute that began when Kelly urged service members to resist unlawful orders.

Just days after a covert mission to capture Venezuelan dictator Nicol√°s Maduro and strike the capital city, Hegseth announced that Kelly faces retirement grade determination proceedings, a rare administrative action that could see the former astronaut and navy captain demoted in his retired rank. Hegseth accused Kelly of making ‚Äúseditious statements‚Äù that undermined military discipline.

Continue reading...

item.title: How one Chinese e-bike motor maker is building quieter electric bikes
item.description:
If you‚Äôve spent enough time riding electric bikes, you quickly realize that power is only part of the draw. Another big part is sound ‚Äì or more accurately, the lack of it. A smooth, quiet motor can make an e-bike feel refined and premium, while a buzzy, rattly drivetrain can cheapen the experience no matter how strong the specs look on paper.

That‚Äôs something Bafang, one of the world‚Äôs largest e-bike motor manufacturers, says it has been focusing on for years. And after I took a trip inside their motor testing grounds, I got to see how they do it.

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2026/01/bafang-motor-head-sound.jpg?quality=82&strip=all&w=1600)
If you‚Äôve spent enough time riding electric bikes, you quickly realize that power is only part of the draw. Another big part is sound ‚Äì or more accurately, the lack of it. A smooth, quiet motor can make an e-bike feel refined and premium, while a buzzy, rattly drivetrain can cheapen the experience no matter how strong the specs look on paper.
That‚Äôs something Bafang, one of the world‚Äôs largest e-bike motor manufacturers, says it has been focusing on for years. And after [I took a trip inside their motor testing grounds](https://electrek.co/2025/02/17/i-went-back-to-bafangs-factory-in-china-five-years-later-the-difference-is-mindblowing/), I got to see how they do it.

item.title: Ruben Amorim is gone, but Manchester United‚Äôs forever crisis rolls on | Jonathan Wilson
item.description:
The head coach (or should that be manager?) fired cryptic shots at his Old Trafford bosses, then was fired himself

  • Amorim sacked after power struggle over transfers

Discontent at Manchester United these days is only ever deferred. Ruben Amorim‚Äôs departure from the club on Monday was long anticipated and came, in the end, with a weary sigh. He had made a half-hearted protest about the recruitment structure after Sunday‚Äôs draw at Leeds, but it felt even at the time like barely more than a gesture. And so another manager, the seventh since Sir Alex Ferguson left in 2013, falls victim to the United meat-grinder.

Everybody at United, fundamentally, is unhappy. And not unhappy in the sense that Alex Ferguson used to be unhappy, when the club was essentially fuelled by his volcanic rages, but enervated, frustrated by the realisation that this is not how things used to be, that this was once the biggest football club in the country and now they keep failing to get the win they need to lift them to fifth.

Continue reading...

Everybody at United, fundamentally, is unhappy. item.title: Tim Walz says he will not run for third term as Minnesota governor
item.description:
Announcement comes after ongoing fraud of social services cases became focus of ire for Republicans and Trump

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

Tim Walz, the Democratic governor of Minnesota who ran for vice-president in 2024, announced on Monday that he is abandoning his quest for a third term in office.

The move comes after ongoing fraud of social services cases caught the attention of US Republicans, including Donald Trump, who then used the cases as a pretext to go after Somali residents.

Walz said in a statement that he wasn‚Äôt able to ‚Äúgive a political campaign my all‚Äù.

item.title: US energy stocks rise as Trump vows to unlock Venezuela‚Äôs oil
item.description:
Oil price rises despite fears US president‚Äôs pledge could deepen global supply glut

  • Big oil will be wary of rushing back to Venezuela

  • Venezuela crisis - latest updates

US energy stocks rose on Monday, after Donald Trump promised to unlock Venezuela‚Äôs vast crude oil reserves following the US capture of the country‚Äôs president, Nicol√°s Maduro.

Shares in Chevron, which already operates in Venezuela under a special licence provided by the Trump administration, were up 5% on Wall Street. Exxon Mobil was up 2.3%, while Halliburton, which provides products and services to the oil and gas sector, jumped 9.7%.

item.title: How markets are responding to Venezuela
item.description: Oil markets and financial markets seem to be shrugging off the major geopolitical story out of the weekend: the U.S. arrest of Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro. "Investors are looking at the situation and not seeing a dramatic change in the state of affairs that could alter global markets in a major way," said Julia Coronado, founder of MacroPolicy Perspectives. "What makes most sense¬†... is to wait and see what unfolds," said Ben Kumar, head of equity strategy at investment management business 7IM. On today's show, we unpack it all.

item.title: Ottawa's Rideau Canal Skateway fully opens

item.title: Monarch butterflies could disappear. Butterfly Town USA is scrambling to save them
item.description:
Pacific Grove is known as ‚ÄòButterfly Town USA‚Äô for its role as an overwintering spot. As the insect‚Äôs population plummets, residents are coming to its rescue

In the tiny seaside village of Pacific Grove, California, there‚Äôs no escaping the monarch butterfly.

Here, butterfly murals abound: one splashes across the side of a hotel, another adorns a school. As for local businesses, there‚Äôs the Monarch Pub, the Butterfly Grove Inn, even Monarch Knitting (a local yarn shop). And every fall, the small city hosts a butterfly parade, where local elementary school children dress up in butterfly costumes. The city‚Äôs municipal code even declares it an unlawful act to ‚Äúmolest or interfere‚Äù with monarchs in any way, with a possible fine of $1,000.

Continue reading...

item.title: Nicol√°s Maduro to appear in New York court on drugs and weapons charges
item.description:
Venezuelan president captured by US in shocking raid is seen being led in handcuffs on his way to court

The deposed Venezuelan president, Nicol√°s Maduro, is expected to appear in Manhattan federal court on Monday afternoon on drugs and weapons charges after his extraordinary capture by US special forces this weekend.

Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, were seized in a shocking pre-dawn raid at a compound on Saturday during an assault on Caracas. At least 40 people, including civilians and Venezuelan military members, reportedly died in the attack.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Venezuelan president captured by US in shocking raid is seen being led in handcuffs on his way to court
Thedeposed Venezuelan president, [Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/world/nicolas-maduro?page=2), is expected to appear in Manhattan federal court on Monday afternoon on drugs and weapons charges after his extraordinary [capture](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/03/explosions-reported-venezuela-caracas) by US special forces this weekend.
Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, were seized in a shocking pre-dawn raid at a compound on Saturday during an [assault on Caracas](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/03/venezuela-attack-what-we-know-so-far-as-trump-claims-maduro-captured). At least 40 people, including civilians and Venezuelan military members, [reportedly](https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/03/world/americas/venezuela-airstrike-civilian-deaths.html) died in the attack.

item.title: Maduro‚Äôs capture had the world‚Äôs ear ‚Äì but Trump returned to petty gripes
item.description:
Though he also discussed plans to ‚Äòrun‚Äô Venezuela, the US president could not resist upending his moment of glory

‚ÄúNever in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few but what I‚Äôd really like to talk about is my disastrous predecessor and some pathetic city mayors,‚Äù is what Winston Churchill didn‚Äôt say during Britain‚Äôs war against Adolf Hitler.

On Saturday, Donald Trump fancied himself at his most Churchillian as he hailed the derring-do of US military heroes who toppled Venezuelan dictator Nicol√°s Maduro in an audacious overnight operation.

item.title: All eyes on secretary of state races ‚Äì with 2028 White House at stake
item.description:
Voters will choose secretaries of state in contests that could play key role in outcome of 2028 presidential election

When Americans go to cast ballots in the midterm elections in 2026, much of the attention is likely to be on races for the US House, Senate and governorships ‚Äì contests that will serve as a referendum on Donald Trump‚Äôs first two years in office and determine the trajectories of the final ones.

But further down the ballot, voters will choose secretaries of state in key races that could have a major effect on how elections are run in many US states, including several battleground states that are key to the 2028 presidential race. Twenty-six states are set to choose secretaries of state next year, including the presidential battlegrounds of Nevada, Arizona and Michigan.

Continue reading...

But further down the ballot, voters will choose secretaries of state in key races that could have a major effect on how elections are run in many US states, including several battleground states that are key to the 2028 presidential race.
