item.title: Lamar Jackson is a once in a lifetime talent. And the Ravens are still going backwards
item.description:
John Harbaugh has spent nearly two decades leading Baltimore. But his failure to get the most out of his quarterback is a fireable failing

There are losses, and then there are those defeats that show us exactly who a team are. The Steelers‚Äô 26-24 win over the Ravens on Sunday night was the latter. It wasn‚Äôt just a loss; it was a referendum. The game was vintage, grubby, beautiful AFC North football. A rivalry game with a playoff place on the line. Big plays. Dumb decisions. Cris Collinsworth making unintelligible noises on commentary. In the final three minutes, four plays swung the win probability by more than 40 percentage points.

The Steelers, missing DK Metcalf and Darnell Washington, scored on four of their five second-half drives, three of them touchdowns, with Aaron Rodgers finding Calvin Austin for a 26-yard score with 55 seconds left. Baltimore, by contrast, couldn‚Äôt get out of their own way until Lamar Jackson strapped on his cape, completing seven of his final nine passes, throwing two touchdowns and converting a ridiculously clutch fourth-down strike to Isaiah Likely with 21 seconds left and the season on the line.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
John Harbaugh has spent nearly two decades leading Baltimore. But his failure to get the most out of his quarterback is a fireable failing
There are losses, and then there are those defeats that show us exactly who a team are. [The Steelers‚Äô 26-24 win over the Ravens](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LbgNNw0SJ3o) on Sunday night was the latter. It wasn‚Äôt just a loss; it was a referendum. The game was vintage, grubby, beautiful AFC North football. A rivalry game with a playoff place on the line. Big plays. Dumb decisions. Cris Collinsworth making unintelligible noises on commentary. In the final three minutes, four plays swung the win probability by more than 40 percentage points.
The Steelers, missing DK Metcalf and Darnell Washington, scored on four of their five second-half drives, three of them touchdowns, with Aaron Rodgers finding Calvin Austin for a 26-yard score with 55 seconds left. Baltimore, by contrast, couldn‚Äôt get out of their own way until Lamar Jackson strapped on his cape, completing seven of his final nine passes, throwing two touchdowns and converting [a ridiculously clutch fourth-down strike](https://x.com/All_22_NFL_Cuts/status/2008026031148683394) to Isaiah Likely with 21 seconds left and the season on the line.

item.description:

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

Nicol√°s Maduro, the deposed Venezuelan president, is expected to appear in Manhattan federal court on Monday afternoon on drugs and weapons charges after US special forces seized him in a shocking raid at the weekend.

What is the reaction in Caracas? While some quietly rejoiced at Maduro‚Äôs demise, the traumatic night-time assault on the city prompted stockpiling, uncertainty and fear.

What‚Äôs the global impact of Trump‚Äôs slashing of climate science? It‚Äôs substantial. Scientists and forecasters around the world depend on US satellites and studies to track extreme weather in Europe, plan disaster responses in the Caribbean and monitor deforestation in the Amazon.

item.title: Trump push to politicize US military ‚Äòreminiscent of Stalin‚Äô, top general warns
item.description:
Maj Gen Paul Eaton says US president‚Äôs effort to bend military to his will could have dire long-term consequences

Donald Trump and his defense secretary Pete Hegseth are mounting an aggressive push to politicise the top ranks of the US military ‚Äì a push that smacks of Stalinism and could take years to repair, the former infantry chief who trained troops to invade Iraq has warned.

Maj Gen Paul Eaton has sounded the alarm, saying in an interview with the Guardian that the effort to bend the higher echelons of the military to the US president‚Äôs will was unparalleled in recent history and could have long-term dire consequences. He warned that both the reputation and efficiency of the world‚Äôs most powerful fighting force was in the balance.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Maj Gen Paul Eaton says US president‚Äôs effort to bend military to his will could have dire long-term consequences
Donald Trump and his defense secretary [Pete Hegseth](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/pete-hegseth) are mounting an aggressive push to politicise the top ranks of the US military ‚Äì a push that smacks of Stalinism and could take years to repair, the former infantry chief who trained troops to [invade Iraq](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/mar/17/iraq-war-invasion-2003-aftermath-middle-east-islamic-state) has warned.
Maj Gen Paul Eaton has sounded the alarm, saying in an interview with the Guardian that the effort to bend the higher echelons of the military to the US president‚Äôs will was unparalleled in recent history and could have long-term dire consequences. item.title: How U.S. political campaigns have used generative AI
item.description: The 2024 presidential race was the first big election to happen in the new generative AI era. There have, of course, been major concerns that the technology could be used to deceive voters or interfere with the exercise of democracy. But so far, that kind of activity has been limited, according to Tim Harper, a senior policy analyst and coauthor of a recent report from the Center for Democracy and Technology.
item.source:markdown: The 2024 presidential race was the first big election to happen in the new generative AI era. item.title: Protests in US cities over Trump‚Äôs military intervention in Venezuela
item.description:
Hundreds gathered coast to coast, even as many in the diaspora celebrated ousting of Maduro

  • Top Republicans backpedal from Trump claim that US will run Venezuela

Protests bubbled up in several US cities over the weekend as people demonstrated against the Trump administration‚Äôs unilateral military intervention in Venezuela ‚Äì even as many in the diaspora publicly celebrated the forced removal of president Nicol√°s Maduro.

Gatherings took place as crowds expressed opposition to a potential war with Venezuela and to declare illegal the US operation to snatch Maduro early on Saturday and bring him to the US to face drug-trafficking charges in court.

Continue reading...

Gatherings took place as crowds expressed opposition to a potential war with Venezuela and to declare illegal the US operation to [snatch Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/04/tactical-surprise-and-air-dominance-how-the-us-snatched-maduro-in-two-and-a-half-hours) early on Saturday and bring him to the US to face drug-trafficking charges in court.

item.title: Falcons fire Raheem Morris and GM Terry Fontenot hours after finishing 8-9 season
item.description:
• Morris fired after second straight 8-9 season

  • Fontenot exits after four-year tenure as GM

  • Falcons begin concurrent searches for both roles

The Atlanta Falcons fired coach Raheem Morris and general manager Terry Fontenot on Sunday night, announcing the moves hours after the team completed their second straight 8-9 finish under Morris and an eighth consecutive losing season.

Morris said after Sunday‚Äôs 19-17 win over the New Orleans Saints that he expected to return for a third season. Instead, his 16-18 record was not enough to save his job after a year that began with optimism the Falcons would reach the playoffs for the first time since 2017.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
- Morris fired after second straight 8-9 season
- Fontenot exits after four-year tenure as GM
- Falcons begin concurrent searches for both roles
The Atlanta Falcons fired coach Raheem Morris and general manager Terry Fontenot on Sunday night, announcing the moves hours after the team completed their second straight 8-9 finish under Morris and an eighth consecutive losing season.
Morris said after Sunday‚Äôs 19-17 win over the New Orleans Saints that he expected to return for a third season. Instead, his 16-18 record was not enough to save his job after a year that began with optimism the Falcons would reach the playoffs for the first time since 2017.

item.title: Novak Djokovic cuts ties with players‚Äô group he co-founded amid transparency concerns
item.description:
• Djokovic says values no longer align with PTPA

  • Players‚Äô group sued tours and grand slams in March

  • Serb was not named as plaintiff in lawsuit

Novak Djokovic is cutting ties with the Professional Tennis Players Association, a group he co-founded that sued the sport‚Äôs governing bodies last year, writing on social media on Sunday that ‚Äúmy values and approach are no longer aligned with the current direction of the organization‚Äù.

The 24-time grand slam champion announced at the 2020 US Open that he and the now-retired Canadian player Vasek Pospisil were launching the PTPA. They said they were aiming to offer representation for players who are independent contractors in a largely individual sport.

Continue reading...

item.title: High tides and heavy rain flood parts of California‚Äôs Bay Area
item.description:
King tides cause highest floodwaters in decades for area, while people are rescued from trapped cars and roads close

High tides and heavy rains have flooded parts of the Bay Area, prompting road closures and rescues of people trapped in cars.

Five northern counties remained under a flood watch, with up to 3in (7.6cm) of rain possible through Monday night in areas that have been drenched off and on since around Christmas, said the National Weather Service office in Eureka. At least a foot (0.3 meters) of snow was likely in the mountains.

Continue reading...

item.title: Venezuelans under TPS can apply for refugee status, Kristi Noem says
item.description:
Homeland security secretary says Venezuelan leader needs to protect America against drug trafficking and terrorists

Kristi Noem, the US homeland security secretary, said on Sunday that the US wants a leader in Venezuela who will be ‚Äúa partner that understands that we‚Äôre going to protect America‚Äù to stop drug trafficking and ‚Äúterrorists from coming into our country‚Äù.

Noem indicated in an interview on Fox News Sunday that the immigration status of Venezuelan nationals living in the US under temporary protected status (TPS) was part of an administration-wide decision-making process that her department would follow.

item.title: NFL roundup: Falcons‚Äô win over Saints throws NFC South title to Panthers
item.description:
• Panthers win NFC South after Falcons beat Saints 19‚Äì17

  • Jags rout Titans to clinch AFC South, extend hot streak

  • Garrett gets sack No 23 to set NFL single-season record

  • Giants beat Cowboys as Vikings finish season on a high

Dee Alford‚Äôs red-zone interception stopped a potential go-ahead drive by New Orleans, and the Atlanta Falcons beat the Saints 19-17 on Sunday to give the NFC South title to the Carolina Panthers.

By closing the season with four consecutive wins, the Falcons (8-9) finished in a three-way tie with Carolina and Tampa Bay for first place in the NFC South. The Panthers won the tiebreaker with the best record within the division.

Continue reading...

- Giants beat Cowboys as Vikings finish season on a high

item.title: Indomitable Jessie Diggins captures Tour de Ski to sharpen Olympic hopes
item.description:
• Diggins wins six-stage Tour de Ski for third time

  • American finishes more than two minutes clear

  • Norway‚Äôs Kl√¶bo hauls in record fifth men‚Äôs title

Jessie Diggins capped one of the most demanding stretches in cross-country skiing on Sunday by winning the Tour de Ski for the third time, a result that further solidifies her status as an Olympic medal favorite heading into what she has already announced will be her final season.

Diggins, the 34-year-old American from Afton, Minnesota, clinched the overall title after the sixth and final stage of the Tour de Ski, an eight-day, multi-race series staged across Italy and modeled after cycling‚Äôs Tour de France. The competition tests skiers across sprint and distance races, classic and freestyle techniques, and concludes with the sport‚Äôs most notorious challenge: a steep, lung-burning climb up Alpe Cermis.

Continue reading...

Democratic leaders responded with fury on Sunday to Donald Trump‚Äôs military intervention in Venezuela, slamming it as an illegal act carried out in the absence of required congressional approval that would lead to disaster for the American people.

Top Democrats took to the Sunday TV political talk shows to express their dismay at the lack of any prior notification of lawmakers about the audacious military raid 24 hours earlier.

item.title: Top Republicans backpedal from Trump claim that US will run Venezuela
item.description:
Secretary of State Marco Rubio defends capture of Nicol√°s Maduro and says US has ‚Äòleverage‚Äô over country

Marco Rubio, the US secretary of state, and prominent Republicans swiftly backpedaled from Donald Trump‚Äôs assertion that the US will run Venezuela in transition after US forces snatched the president, Nicol√°s Maduro, and brought him to the US to face federal criminal charges.

Rubio appeared on numerous US politics shows on Sunday morning to defend the US operation in the early hours of Saturday to capture Maduro and his wife despite critics calling the operation illegal on multiple levels and the White House failing to demonstrate how it would run the South American nation.

item.title: ‚ÄòThe perfect storm‚Äô: Trump has left the US less prepared for natural disasters, experts say
item.description:
Emergency managers say the US president has presided over a dangerous erosion in US capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disasters

Donald Trump has presided over a dangerous erosion in US capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disasters, according to emergency management experts.

The first year of his second term was marked by crackdowns on climate science that produced world-class weather forecasts and the gutting of frontline federal agencies - policies that have left the country, already struggling to keep pace with severe storms, even more at risk.

Continue reading...

[Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) has presided over a dangerous erosion in US capacity to prepare for and respond to natural disasters, according to emergency management experts.
The first year of his second term was marked by crackdowns on [climate](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-crisis) science that produced world-class weather forecasts and the gutting of frontline federal agencies - policies that have left the country, already struggling to keep pace with severe storms, even more at risk.

item.title: ‚ÄòA big bad bull whipped me down‚Äô: cowboy poetry, old art form of the US west, lassos a new generation
item.description:
From Los Angeles to Nevada, younger people are preserving a longstanding tradition one lyric at a time

Deep in the heart of Los Angeles‚Äôs Koreatown, just a few doors down from H Mart and a K-pop music superstore, an American flag hangs over the entrance of a saloon called Eastwood.

The western-themed bar would normally be cranking Luke Bryan while customers play skee-ball, line dance and get bucked off their mechanical bull named Gucci. But tonight, the music is low and the loudest sounds come from the clacking of vintage mechanical typewriters. About 30 people in the bar are drafting poems about horses, sunsets and Stetson hats ‚Äì which are plentiful atop the heads in the crowd.

Heck, they thought they killed me back in 15

flew me out in a chopper, covered me with a sheet.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

Deep in the heart of Los Angeles‚Äôs Koreatown, just a few doors down from H Mart and a K-pop music superstore, an American flag hangs over the entrance of a saloon called Eastwood.
The western-themed bar would normally be cranking Luke Bryan while customers play skee-ball, line dance and get bucked off their mechanical bull named Gucci. But tonight, the music is low and the loudest sounds come from the clacking of vintage mechanical typewriters. About 30 people in the bar are drafting poems about horses, sunsets and Stetson hats ‚Äì which are plentiful atop the heads in the crowd.
_Heck, they thought they killed me back in_ _15_
_flew me out in a chopper, covered me with a sheet._

item.title: European leaders appear torn in face of new world order after Venezuela attack
item.description:
Leaders try to focus on what comes next, as backing for ejection of Maduro mingles uncomfortably with voicing of support for international law

  • Venezuela crisis: latest updates

European leaders emerged divided and torn as they tried to welcome the ejection of Venezuela‚Äôs authoritarian president, but still uphold the principles of international law that did not appear to allow Donald Trump to seize Nicol√°s Maduro, let alone declare that the US will run Venezuela and control its oil industry.

Europe tried to focus on the principle of a democratic transition, pointing out that the continent had not recognised Maduro as the legitimate leader of Venezuela since what were widely regarded as fraudulent elections in June 2024.

Continue reading...

item.description:
Jackery has just pulled the wraps off its newest portable power station, the Explorer 1500 Ultra, and it‚Äôs aiming squarely at people who actually use these things outside ‚Äì not just those who keep them pristine in a garage for the occasional blackout. Unveiled this week at CES 2026, the new unit is designed to be tougher, lighter, and more weather-resistant than most power stations in its class, with specs showing how Jackery is leaning hard into real-world use cases.¬†

Beyond just portable power, the company is also showcasing innovative new products that target much bigger ambitions ‚Äì literally. With a new solar gazebo and a self-following robot, the Jackery is dramatically expanding the scope of its solar and portable power initiatives.

more‚Ä¶

item.title: Why the dollar fell over 9% in 2025, and what to expect in 2026
item.description: The dollar fell over 9% in 2025, its worst annual performance since 2017. The declines reflect a volatile year for the U.S. economy, with investors likely facing another unpredictable 12 months.

item.title: From the AI bubble to Fed fears: the global economic outlook for 2026
item.description:
Analysts and investors voice caution about tech valuations and Trump‚Äôs influence on the US central bank

Investors expect global stock markets to keep rising in 2026, despite fears that the AI bubble could burst, and anxiety about chaos engulfing the US central bank.

Wall Street strategists broadly expect the S&P 500 share index of US-listed companies to continue to rise over the next 12 months, but said it could be a volatile year if geopolitical tensions increase and inflation fails to fall.

item.title: What role could the US play in Venezuela‚Äôs ‚Äòbust‚Äô oil industry?
item.description:
Experts say lifting production to former levels could take decades and huge investment will be needed

The Venezuelan oil industry has been ‚Äúa total bust‚Äù for a long time, according to Donald Trump. After attacking Caracas and taking the country‚Äôs leader captive, Trump promised to take control of Venezuela‚Äôs oil industry with the help of America‚Äôs biggest oil companies.

Venezuela‚Äôs beleaguered oil industry could ‚Äúmake a lot of money‚Äù with the might of the US behind it, Trump told the press, claiming that the new regime would invest billions to revive its fortunes.

item.title: US attack on Venezuela raises fears of future Greenland takeover
item.description:
Danish ambassador posts ‚Äòfriendly reminder‚Äô about defence ties after provocative Maga post over territory

  • Venezuela crisis ‚Äì latest updates

The US bombardment of Venezuela and the capture of its president, Nicol√°s Maduro, have renewed fears of an American takeover of Greenland, as members of Donald Trump‚Äôs Maga movement gleefully set their sights on the Danish territory after the attack in South America.

Just hours after the US military operation in Venezuela, the rightwing podcaster Katie Miller ‚Äì the wife of Stephen Miller, Donald Trump‚Äôs powerful deputy chief of staff for policy ‚Äì posted on X a map of Greenland draped in the stars and stripes with the caption: ‚ÄúSOON.‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: 60-year-old letters between trapper John Tetso and unlikely pen pal donated to N.W.T. library
item.description: The librarian of the John Tetso Memorial Library in Fort Simpson, N.W.T., was surprised by the donation of 60-year-old correspondences between trapper John Tetso and a pen pal from the prominent Molson family. Tetso wrote one of the first autobiographies documenting life in the bush, and this donation elaborates upon his life and legacy.

item.title: Auston Matthews passes Mats Sundin as Toronto Maple Leafs‚Äô all-time leading goalscorer
item.description:
• Matthews passes Sundin for Leafs career goals mark

  • Captain scores twice but Islanders win in overtime

  • Toronto star hits 421 goals in just 664 games

Toronto Maple Leafs captain Auston Matthews scored twice in the second period against the New York Islanders on Saturday night to pass Mats Sundin and set the franchise record for career goals with 421.

‚ÄúIt means a lot, it‚Äôs a very historical franchise,‚Äù Matthews said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of pride. ‚Ä¶ I am very humbled. I couldn‚Äôt do it without the great group of guys around me.‚Äù

item.title: Venezuela attack: what we know so far as US captures President Maduro
item.description:
Donald Trump says US will ‚Äòrun‚Äô Venezuela as Nicol√°s Maduro and wife Cilia Flores are flown to New York

The US president, Donald Trump, has said the US will ‚Äòrun‚Äô Venezuela after its president, Nicol√°s Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, were captured and taken to New York, hours after a ‚Äúlarge-scale‚Äù pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region. Here is what we know so far:

Donald Trump said ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to run the country [Venezuela] until such time as we can do a safe, proper and judicious transition‚Äù during a press conference about the attack on Venezuela. He has not given details.

A plane carrying Maduro and Flores landed in New York on Saturday evening and they were expected to be transported to appear in Manhattan federal court, possibly as soon as Monday.

The US is going to be ‚Äúvery strongly involved‚Äù in Venezuela‚Äôs oil industry after the military operation, Trump said. He said: ‚ÄúWe have the greatest oil companies in the world, the biggest, the greatest, and we‚Äôre going to be very much involved in it.‚Äù

Trump posted a photograph of Maduro on his Truth Social platform. It appeared to show the captured Venezuelan president in handcuffs, wrap-around sun goggles and headphones.

The UN security council is due to hold an emergency meeting on Monday.

Trump said his administration had not spoken to Venezuela‚Äôs exiled opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado. He said he did not think she would be able to return to lead Venezuela, saying: ‚ÄúShe does not have the support in Venezuela. She is a very nice woman but she does not have the support.‚Äù

The constitutional chamber of Venezuela‚Äôs supreme court has ordered vice president Delcy Rodr√≠guez to assume the role of acting president in Maduro‚Äôs absence.

Trump was asked about Cuba during the press conference on Venezuela. He said ‚ÄúCuba, as you know, is not doing very well right now. That system has not been a very good one for Cuba. The people there have suffered for many, many years and I think Cuba is going to be something we‚Äôll end up talking about, because Cuba is a failing nation right now.‚Äù

The US Department of Justice released a new indictment against Nicol√°s Maduro, including his wife, Celia Flores, his son and others.

The US vice-president, JD Vance, hailed what he called a ‚Äútruly impressive operation‚Äù. Resharing Trump‚Äôs post about the action, Vance wrote: ‚ÄúThe president offered multiple off-ramps, but was very clear throughout this process: the drug trafficking must stop, and the stolen oil must be returned to the United States.‚Äù

In a statement on X, the US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, said Maduro was ‚Äúunder indictment for pushing drugs in the United States‚Äù. The Republican senator Mike Lee said on Saturday that Rubio had told him he ‚Äúanticipates no further action in Venezuela now that Maduro is in US custody‚Äù.

The UN secretary general, Ant√≥nio Guterres, is deeply alarmed by US military action in Venezuela, his spokesperson has said, and considered the US intervention ‚Äúa dangerous precedent‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Donald Trump says US will ‚Äòrun‚Äô Venezuela as Nicol√°s Maduro and wife Cilia Flores are flown to New York
The US president, Donald Trump, has said the US will ‚Äòrun‚Äô Venezuela after its president, Nicol√°s Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, were captured and taken to New York, hours after a ‚Äúlarge-scale‚Äù pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region. Here is what we know so far:
Donald Trump said **‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to run the country**\[Venezuela\] until such time as we can do a safe, proper and judicious transition‚Äù during a press conference about the attack on Venezuela. He has not given details.
**A plane carrying Maduro and Flores landed in New York on Saturday evening** and they were expected to be transported to appear in Manhattan federal court, possibly as soon as Monday.
**The** **US is going to be ‚Äúvery strongly involved‚Äù in Venezuela‚Äôs oil industry after the military operation** **, Trump** **said.** He said: ‚ÄúWe have the greatest oil companies in the world, the biggest, the greatest, and we‚Äôre going to be very much involved in it.‚Äù
**Trump posted a photograph of Maduro on his Truth Social platform.** It appeared to show the captured Venezuelan president in handcuffs, wrap-around sun goggles and headphones.
**The** **UN security council** is [due to hold](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/03/caracas-explosions-venezuela-maduro-latest-news-updates-live?page=with%3Ablock-69597e098f083c44d70df0a0#block-69597e098f083c44d70df0a0) an emergency meeting on Monday.
Trump said his administration **had not spoken to Venezuela‚Äôs exiled opposition leader** **Mar√≠a Corina Machado**. He said he did not think she would be able to return to lead Venezuela, saying: ‚ÄúShe does not have the support in Venezuela. She is a very nice woman but she does not have the support.‚Äù
The constitutional chamber of Venezuela‚Äôs supreme court has ordered **vice president Delcy Rodr√≠guez** to assume the role of acting president in Maduro‚Äôs absence.
**Trump was asked about Cuba** during the press conference on Venezuela. He said ‚ÄúCuba, as you know, is not doing very well right now. That system has not been a very good one for Cuba. The people there have suffered for many, many years and I think Cuba is going to be something we‚Äôll end up talking about, because Cuba is a failing nation right now.‚Äù
The **US Department of Justice released a new indictment** against Nicol√°s Maduro, including his wife, Celia Flores, his son and others.
**The US vice-president, JD Vance, hailed what he called a ‚Äútruly impressive operation‚Äù** **.** Resharing Trump‚Äôs post about the action, Vance [wrote](https://x.com/JDVance/status/2007447083909841398): ‚ÄúThe president offered multiple off-ramps, but was very clear throughout this process: the drug trafficking must stop, and the stolen oil must be returned to the United States.‚Äù
**In a statement on X, the US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, said Maduro** **was ‚Äúunder indictment for pushing drugs in the United States‚Äù.** The Republican senator Mike Lee said on Saturday that Rubio had told him he ‚Äúanticipates no further action in Venezuela now that Maduro is in US custody‚Äù.
The **UN secretary general, Ant√≥nio Guterres, is deeply alarmed by US military action in Venezuela**, his spokesperson has said, and considered the US intervention ‚Äúa dangerous precedent‚Äù.

item.title: ‚ÄòNaked imperialism‚Äô: how Trump intervention in Venezuela is a return to form for the US
item.description:
Most of the Americas have suffered from interference from their powerful northern neighbour ‚Äì and are usually the worse off for it

  • Maduro detained in New York ‚Äì live updates

The US bombardment of Venezuela and the capture of its president, Nicol√°s Maduro, follow a long history of interventions in South and Central America and the Caribbean over the past two centuries. But they also mark an unprecedented moment as the first direct US military attack on a South American country.

At a press conference after Maduro‚Äôs capture, Donald Trump said that ‚ÄúAmerican dominance in the western hemisphere will never be questioned again‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Jordan Stolz falls at US speed skating trials but still qualifies for Olympics
item.description:
• Stolz trips early but finishes third in 1,000m

  • World record-holder still locks in Olympic spot

  • Jackson tops Brittany Bowe in women‚Äôs 1,000m

Star speed skater Jordan Stolz shockingly stumbled to the ice right after the start of the men‚Äôs 1,000 meters at the US Olympic trials for long track speed skating on Saturday but still finished with the third-fastest time and will head to the Milan Cortina Winter Games.

Stolz caught the toe of one of his skates on the slick surface, lost his footing and tripped after fewer than five strides at the Pettit National Ice Center, about 40 miles south of his hometown of Kewaskum. It was the sort of thing that simply doesn‚Äôt happen to the best in the world at what he does ‚Äì someone expected to earn multiple medals and to be one of the faces of the 6-22 February Olympics.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump news at a glance: outcry and questions after US attack on Venezuela
item.description:
With Nicol√°s Maduro in US custody, Donald Trump says ‚Äòwe will run‚Äô Venezuela until ‚Äòa safe, proper and judicious transition‚Äô can be made ‚Äì key US politics stories from 3 January 2026

The US attacked Venezuela and captured its long-serving president Nicol√°s Maduro on Saturday, with Donald Trump promising to put the country under American control for now, even as Venezuelan officials vowed defiance.

As part of a dramatic overnight operation that knocked out electricity in parts of Caracas, US special forces captured Maduro in or near one of his safe houses, the US president said.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
With Nicol√°s Maduro in US custody, Donald Trump says ‚Äòwe will run‚Äô Venezuela until ‚Äòa safe, proper and judicious transition‚Äô can be made ‚Äì key US politics stories from 3 January 2026
The US attacked Venezuela and captured its long-serving president [Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.theguardian.com/world/nicolas-maduro) on Saturday, with Donald Trump promising to put the country under American control for now, even as Venezuelan officials vowed defiance.
As part of a [dramatic overnight operation](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/03/venezuela-attack-what-we-know-so-far-as-trump-claims-maduro-captured) that knocked out electricity in parts of Caracas, US special forces captured Maduro in or near one of his safe houses, the US president said.

item.title: Seahawks clinch NFC‚Äôs No 1 seed as Buccaneers cling to playoff hopes
item.description:
• Seahawks shut down 49ers to secure NFC top seed

  • Seattle ride defense and run game in 13-3 win

  • Buccaneers survive Panthers, await NFC South fate

Zach Charbonnet scored on a 27-yard run in the first quarter and Seattle shut down the high-powered San Francisco offense in a 13-3 victory over the 49ers on Saturday night that secured the No 1 seed for the Seahawks in the NFC playoffs.

Seattle (14-3) won their first division title since 2020 and are now two home wins away from returning to Levi‚Äôs Stadium for the Super Bowl next month after besting San Francisco (12-5) in just the fourth season-ending game ever where the winner was guaranteed the No 1 seed in the playoffs.

A plane carrying captured Venezuelan leader Nicol√°s Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, has arrived in New York hours after an overnight US military attack that Donald Trump hailed as ‚Äúan assault like people have not seen since world war two‚Äù as he vowed the US would run the leaderless country.

Trump, speaking at a press conference at his Mar-a-Lago residence in Palm Beach, Florida, on Saturday, provided few details after ousting Maduro in an audacious military attack but said the US would be in control of Venezuela until there is an orderly transition of power.

item.title: US sees spike in flu cases in December, after most severe season since 2018
item.description:
Not clear whether more people will get the flu this season, but more than 3,100 people have died in last year in US

The United States has seen the number of influenza cases climb significantly in December, coming after the most severe flu season since 2018, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.

It‚Äôs not yet clear whether there will be an increase in the total number of people who get the flu this season ‚Äì or whether more people just got it at once in December ‚Äì but more than 3,100 people died from the virus in the US in the year ending August 2025, according to the latest data from the CDC.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòIt sends a horrible signal‚Äô: US politicians react to capture of Nicol√°s Maduro
item.description:
Republicans cheer capture of Venezuelan leader, but Democrats say it ‚Äòrisks pulling our nation into another war‚Äô

  • US attacks Venezuela ‚Äì live updates

Reaction to the capture of Nicol√°s Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, by US forces on Saturday has been starkly polarized along political lines, with administration officials and Republicans celebrating the enforcement of a 2020 US narco-trafficking indictment against Maduro and Democrats decrying what they see as a violation of Venezuela‚Äôs right to self-determination.

The US attorney general, Pam Bondi, said on X that Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, had been indicted in the southern district of New York on charges including narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation conspiracy, possession of machine guns and destructive devices, and conspiracy to possess machine guns and destructive devices against the United States.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Republicans cheer capture of Venezuelan leader, but Democrats say it ‚Äòrisks pulling our nation into another war‚Äô
- [US attacks Venezuela ‚Äì live updates](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/03/caracas-explosions-venezuela-maduro-latest-news-updates-live)

[The US attorney general, Pam Bondi, said on X](https://x.com/AGPamBondi/status/2007428087143686611) that Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, had been indicted in the southern district of New York on charges including narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation conspiracy, possession of machine guns and destructive devices, and conspiracy to possess machine guns and destructive devices against the United States.

item.title: Airstrikes, helicopters and a snatch squad with a blowtorch: how the US raid on Caracas unfolded
item.description:
Some suspected the attacks on Venezuela were coming, but the shock was still real and no one knows what will happen next

  • US strikes on Venezuela ‚Äì live updates

  • Why has US attacked Venezuela and captured president?

As they were jolted from their beds just before 2am on Saturday, many Caracas residents sought an innocent explanation for the racket that had interrupted their sleep: an exploding air conditioning unit, a tropical thunderstorm, an earthquake. Or perhaps a festive display of pyrotechnics over Venezuela‚Äôs mountain-flanked capital.

‚ÄúI thought it might be fireworks,‚Äù Carlos Hurtado, a resident of the 23 de Enero housing estate on the city‚Äôs west side, recalled of the moment he was woken by a mysterious sequence of rumblings and explosions.

Last year in the final in Ottawa, Ontario, the Americans had beaten the Finns 4-3 in overtime. ‚ÄúGot to give credit to the US,‚Äù the Finnish captain, Aron Kiviharju, said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a hell of a team, full of great individuals and a well coached team.   • Fight drew 33m global viewers on Netflix

  • Loss followed brief cruiserweight ranking run

Jake Paul has fallen out of the World Boxing Association‚Äôs cruiserweight rankings after his sixth-round knockout loss to Anthony Joshua last month.

The YouTuber was stopped by the former two-time heavyweight champion in a scheduled eight-round bout in Miami, where Joshua scored four knockdowns before the referee halted the contest in the sixth round. Paul suffered a broken jaw in two places and required surgery after the fight.

item.title: Four sisters from LA‚Äôs Watts nurture families from the same blocks: ‚ÄòThey stand in the gap‚Äô
item.description:
The Sisters of Watts have served families for a decade, providing food, fitness, money and after-school programs

The weekend before Thanksgiving, the gymnasium in Ted Watkins park in the south Los Angeles neighborhood of Watts was crowded with more than 100 families. For three hours, they ate and talked while their kids ran around and a DJ blasted west coast hip-hop staples during games of limbo and musical chairs.

Toward the back of the room, people clamored around a step-and-repeat to get a picture with the event‚Äôs organizers: four siblings known as the Sisters of Watts, who for the past decade have arranged food giveaways, backpack drives and after-school activities for kids growing up on the same blocks they did. At this event, there were bags of fresh produce available for families that wanted them.

Continue reading...

item.title: Epstein disclosures raise key question: why wasn‚Äôt he stopped earlier?
item.description:
New documents reveal numerous missed opportunities as experts and victims condemn US authorities‚Äô failures

Over the course of two decades, Jeffrey Epstein repeatedly appeared on law enforcement‚Äôs radar for sexual misconduct involving teen girls and young women. And over this same period of time, Epstein avoided serious and meaningful punishment for his crimes.

The US justice department‚Äôs recent disclosure of long-secret investigative files related to Epstein has once again raised the question of why he wasn‚Äôt interdicted sooner, despite numerous reports of misconduct. The issue has been the subject of many conspiracy theories, often focusing on the idea that Epstein ‚Äì who lived at the center of a network of powerful people ‚Äì enjoyed some form of protection.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

item.title: States tighten SNAP rules in 2026
item.description:
By the end of the year, at least 18 states will restrict the use of SNAP benefits to purchase ‚Äúnon-nutritious‚Äù food and drinks. But the definition of non-nutritious is up to each state. In this episode, the knock-on effects of benefit restrictions, for shoppers and retailers. Plus: Gigantic driverless trucks are poised to transform Minnesota iron mining and a deportation deal between the U.S. and Ghana could deter future emigration from the region.

item.title: Saks Global CEO steps down as luxury retailer reportedly preparing for bankruptcy
item.description:
Executive chair Richard Baker to replace Marc Metrick after company misses $100m interest payment on debt

Saks Global said on Friday that its CEO, Marc Metrick, has stepped down and named executive chair, Richard Baker, as his successor, amid reports that the luxury retailer is preparing for bankruptcy.

The change at the top comes days after the Wall Street Journal reported that the Neiman Marcus parent company is preparing for bankruptcy after missing an interest payment exceeding $100m on debt from its Neiman merger.

Continue reading...

item.title: US‚Äôs first registry of domestic abusers takes effect in Tennessee
item.description:
‚ÄòSavanna‚Äôs law‚Äô named after woman killed by ex-boyfriend, who had extensive record of domestic violence allegations

A state law creating the first registry of people convicted of domestic abuse in the US took effect Thursday in Tennessee.

Named after Savanna Puckett, a woman who was shot to death by her ex-boyfriend in January 2022, ‚ÄúSavanna‚Äôs law‚Äù requires the Tennessee bureau of investigation to maintain a database of people who have been convicted of or pleaded guilty to at least two domestic violence offenses.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
‚ÄòSavanna‚Äôs law‚Äô named after woman killed by ex-boyfriend, who had extensive record of domestic violence allegations
A state law creating the first registry of people convicted of domestic abuse in the US took effect Thursday in Tennessee.
Named after Savanna Puckett, a woman who was shot to death by her ex-boyfriend in January 2022, ‚ÄúSavanna‚Äôs law‚Äù requires the Tennessee bureau of investigation to maintain a [database](https://dvr.tbi.tn.gov/search) of people who have been convicted of or pleaded guilty to at least two domestic violence offenses.

item.title: From "This Is Uncomfortable": Wait, I think I‚Äôm being underpaid
item.description:
Hey smarties! Happy New Year. We‚Äôre taking a short break for the holidays. In the meantime, we‚Äôre sharing an episode from our friends over at ‚ÄúThis Is Uncomfortable.‚Äù Reema Khrais and the team are getting ready to relaunch the show on Jan. 15. Stay tuned for new episodes!


Nikki Massie never had a reason to question her salary. After more than a decade with the same company, she‚Äôd earned awards, promotions and the trust of co-workers who felt like family. But then one day, she discovered she might have missed out on tens of thousands of dollars over the years. Nikki began to wonder: What do you do when you suspect you‚Äôve been underpaid? And at what point do you consider walking away?¬†


If you liked this episode, share it with a friend. And to get even more Uncomfortable,¬†subscribe to our newsletter!
item.source:markdown:
_Hey smarties! Happy New Year. We‚Äôre taking a short break for the holidays. In the meantime, we‚Äôre sharing an episode from our friends over at ‚ÄúThis Is Uncomfortable.‚Äù Reema Khrais and the team are getting ready to relaunch the show on Jan. 15. Stay tuned for new episodes!_

item.description:

item.title: DC pipe bomb suspect must remain in jail before trial, judge rules
item.description:
Brian Cole, accused of planting bombs before Capitol attack, presents ‚Äòintolerable risk of danger‚Äô, court finds

A federal magistrate judge has ruled that the man accused of planting pipe bombs outside the Democratic and Republican headquarters the night before the January 6 Capitol attack must remain in custody while awaiting trial.

In a memorandum opinion, the court determined that Brian Cole Jr, 30, of Woodbridge, Virginia, ‚Äúposes an intolerable risk of danger to the community if released‚Äù, granting the government‚Äôs motion for pretrial detention.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Brian Cole, accused of planting bombs before Capitol attack, presents ‚Äòintolerable risk of danger‚Äô, court finds
A federal magistrate judge has ruled that the man accused of planting pipe bombs outside the Democratic and Republican headquarters the night before the [January 6 Capitol attack](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-capitol-breach) must remain in custody while awaiting trial.
In a [memorandum opinion](https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.dcd.287327/gov.uscourts.dcd.287327.28.0.pdf), the court determined that Brian Cole Jr, 30, of Woodbridge, Virginia, ‚Äúposes an intolerable risk of danger to the community if released‚Äù, granting the government‚Äôs motion for pretrial detention.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/02/dc-pipe-bomb-suspect-custody)

item.title: US homeland security condemned for using Japanese artist‚Äôs work without consent
item.description:
Hiroshi Nagai, in a post on X, has objected to his artwork being used by the agency to promote its deportation agenda

The US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is facing backlash once again, this time from a Japanese artist who has condemned the agency for using, without permission, his work to promote deportations.

In a post on X on New Year‚Äôs Eve, the department posted a photo featuring a pristine and empty beach with palm trees and a vintage car. Written across the photo was ‚ÄúAmerica after 100 million deportations,‚Äù along with a separate caption that said: ‚ÄúThe peace of a nation no longer besieged by the third world.‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: FBI says it thwarted planned New Year‚Äôs Eve terrorist attack in North Carolina
item.description:
FBI says teen was planning Islamic State-inspired hammer and knife attack on Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ people

The FBI has said it thwarted an alleged plot to carry out a New Year‚Äôs Eve terrorist attack on a grocery store and restaurant in North Carolina in support of the Islamic State (IS).

Christian Sturdivant, 18, of Mint Hill ‚Äì a town outside Charlotte ‚Äì was arrested on 31 December as he was being released from a special medical facility. He was charged with attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization, the US attorney for the western district of North Carolina, Russ Ferguson, said at a press conference on Friday morning.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
FBI says teen was planning Islamic State-inspired hammer and knife attack on Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ people

Christian Sturdivant, 18, of Mint Hill ‚Äì a town outside Charlotte ‚Äì was arrested on 31 December as he was being released from a special medical facility. He was charged with attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization, the US attorney for the western district of North Carolina, Russ Ferguson, said at a press conference on Friday morning.

item.title: Growing number of California sheriffs no longer respond to mental health calls
item.description:
A shift away from police-led responses spreads, but gaps in crisis teams leave some communities exposed

In the past year, a handful of sheriff‚Äôs departments in California have started refusing to respond to 911 calls that involve a mental health crisis, but where no crime has been reported.

In February, the Sacramento sheriff, Jim Cooper, announced that his deputies would only respond to mental health crises if a crime had been committed or was in process, or if someone other than the person in crisis was in imminent danger. Down in San Diego county, the police chief for the city of El Cajon, Jeremiah Larson, made a similar policy decision in May.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
A shift away from police-led responses spreads, but gaps in crisis teams leave some communities exposed
In the past year, a handful of sheriff‚Äôs departments in [California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california) have [started refusing to respond](https://calmatters.org/health/mental-health/2025/04/mental-health-crisis-california-police-response/) to 911 calls that involve a mental health crisis, but where no crime has been reported.
In February, the Sacramento sheriff, Jim Cooper, announced that his deputies would only respond to mental health crises if a crime had been committed or was in process, or if someone other than the person in crisis was in imminent danger. Down in San Diego county, the police chief for the city of El Cajon, Jeremiah Larson, made a similar policy decision in May.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/02/california-police-cut-mental-health-calls)

item.title: China‚Äôs BYD overtakes Tesla as world‚Äôs biggest electric car seller
item.description:
Sales at Elon Musk‚Äôs company slump after Donald Trump‚Äôs withdrawal of EV subsidies

China‚Äôs BYD overtook Tesla as the world‚Äôs largest electric carmaker in 2025, after the US company run by Elon Musk reported a slump in deliveries at the end of the year.

BYD sold 2.26m battery electric cars during the year, easily outstripping the 1.63m deliveries reported on Friday by Tesla for the same period.

item.title: Warren Buffett steps down, ending an era at Berkshire
item.description: Greg Abel has officially taken the reins at Berkshire Hathaway, stepping into the role long held by the titan of value investing, Warren Buffett. We look at what Abel‚Äôs leadership could mean for an empire that touches everything from energy to insurance. Plus, stocks had a strong year, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posting double-digit gains, but the job market tells a very different story. And do professional movie critics still matter in an age of Reddit threads and Letterboxd reviews?

item.title: Colorado authorities suspect mountain lion attack after woman found dead near trail
item.description:
Other hikers had reported seeing the animal near the body and scared it away ‚Äòby throwing rocks‚Äô at it

Authorities are investigating a suspected fatal mountain lion attack after a woman was found dead on a hiking trail in Colorado on Thursday.

In a news release on Thursday, Colorado Parks and Wildlife (CPW) said that hikers reported seeing a mountain lion near a person lying on the ground on the Crosier Mountain trail in unincorporated Larimer county at around 12.15pm local time on Thursday.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs our turn‚Äô: gun-safety advocates are riding a ‚Äòseismic‚Äô wave to US legislatures
item.description:
A once-toxic topic is helping survivors and relatives of victims get elected to enact the laws they helped draft

A new generation of young political leaders is gaining power in the US by using their personal experience with gun violence to push for reforms they say the US is ready for.

Their ascent is part of a nearly decade-long shift, from gun violence prevention being a third-rail issue in politics that was rarely spoken about on campaign trails, to one that candidates, most of them Democrats, are now running ‚Äì and winning ‚Äì on.

Continue reading...

item.title: Mamdani pledges ‚Äònew era‚Äô for New York and vows to govern ‚Äòaudaciously‚Äô
item.description:
New mayor gives speech at inauguration and rescinds all orders signed by Eric Adams after corruption indictment

Zohran Mamdani vowed to ‚Äúreinvent‚Äù New York City in a speech on his first day as mayor, promising ‚Äúa new era‚Äù for America‚Äôs largest city and an ambitious start to his term of office.

The 34-year-old political star and democratic socialist, who a year ago was a virtually unknown state assemblyman, is the city‚Äôs first Muslim mayor, the first of south Asian descent and the first to be born in Africa. He is also the first to be sworn in using the Qur‚Äôan.

item.title: 2025 was a big year for climate in the US courts - these were the wins and losses
item.description:
Americans are increasingly turning to courts to hold big oil accountable. Here are major trends that emerged last year

As the Trump administration boosts fossil fuels, Americans are increasingly turning to courts to hold big oil accountable for alleged climate deception. That wave of litigation swelled in 2025, with groundbreaking cases filed and wins notched.

But the year also brought setbacks, as Trump attacked the cases and big oil worked to have them thrown out. The industry also worked to secure a shield from current and future climate lawsuits.

Continue reading...

item.title: Amid wide healthcare cuts, a bright spot for rural hospitals
item.description: Healthcare costs are climbing for many Americans as enhanced Affordable Care Act tax credits roll back, raising premiums for middle-income households unless Congress intervenes. In this vacuum, we look at a major new federal investment aimed at expanding healthcare access in rural communities. Plus, U.S. travel is sending mixed signals this year ‚Äî domestic travel is booming, but fewer international visitors are visiting the States, and that shift is being felt by America‚Äôs museums.

item.title: Donald Trump wants the US back on the moon before his term ends. Can it happen?
item.description:
After losing a year to havoc and job-slashing at Nasa, the pressure is on billionaire administrator Jared Isaacman

With astronauts set to fly around the moon for the first time in more than half a century when Artemis 2 makes its long-awaited ascent some time this spring, 2026 was already destined to become a standout year in space.

It is also likely to be one of the most pivotal, with new leadership at Nasa in billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman, and the tycoon-led private space industry assuming more than a mere supporting role to help win for the US its race with China back to the lunar surface.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
After losing a year to havoc and job-slashing at Nasa, the pressure is on billionaire administrator Jared Isaacman
With astronauts set to fly around the moon for the first time in [more than half a century](https://www.theguardian.com/science/2022/nov/20/from-apollo-to-artemis-50-years-on-is-it-time-to-go-back-to-the-moon) when Artemis 2 makes its long-awaited ascent some time this spring, 2026 was already destined to become a standout year in space.
It is also likely to be one of the most pivotal, with [new leadership at Nasa](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/17/nasa-jared-isaacman-confirmation) in billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman, and the tycoon-led private space industry assuming more than a mere supporting role to help win for the US its [race with China](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2025/dec/28/the-guardian-view-on-the-new-space-race-humanity-risks-exporting-its-old-politics-to-the-moon) back to the lunar surface.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/02/trump-moon-nasa-space)

item.title: Italian pasta makers win reprieve from Trump tariffs
item.description:
US cuts proposed levies to between 2% and 14% despite accusing Italian producers of selling at unfairly low prices

The US government has slashed proposed tariffs on Italian pasta that would have almost doubled the cost of many brands for shoppers.

Donald Trump had threatened to impose tariffs as high as 92% on Italian pasta companies, after accusing 13 producers including Barilla, La Molisana and Pastificio Lucio Garofalo of selling their products at unfairly low prices.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US cuts proposed levies to between 2% and 14% despite accusing Italian producers of selling at unfairly low prices
The US government has slashed proposed tariffs on Italian pasta that would have almost [doubled the cost of many brands](https://www.theguardian.com/food/2025/nov/13/pasta-italian-imports-trump-tariffs) for shoppers.
Donald Trump had threatened to [impose tariffs as high as 92% on Italian pasta companies](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/09/a-fatal-blow-italian-producers-fear-effects-of-trumps-war-against-pasta), after accusing 13 producers including Barilla, La Molisana and Pastificio Lucio Garofalo of selling their products at unfairly low prices.

item.title: Swiss investigators race to identify victims after 40 killed in resort bar fire | First Thing
item.description:
Blaze that swept through crowded New Year‚Äôs Eve bar in Crans-Montana also injured 115 people. Plus, the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda

Good morning.

Swiss investigators are racing to identify the victims of a fire that tore through a crowded bar, killing about 40 people and injuring 115 who were celebrating at a New Year‚Äôs Eve party in the Alpine ski resort of Crans-Montana.

How did the fire start? The fire broke out at 1.30am on Thursday in the town‚Äôs Le Constellation bar, but it‚Äôs not yet clear what set off the blaze. Some witnesses said it started after sparklers or flares were put into champagne bottles.

How long will it take to identify the dead? Swiss police have warned it could take days or even weeks, leaving an agonising wait for family and friends.

What else did he say? Mamdani did not shy away from his socialist politics. ‚ÄúI was elected as a democratic socialist and I will govern as a democratic socialist. I will not abandon my principles for fear of being called radical,‚Äù he said to loud cheers from the gathered crowd. He ended by saying: ‚ÄúThe work has only just begun.‚Äù

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Blaze that swept through crowded New Year‚Äôs Eve bar in Crans-Montana also injured 115 people. Plus, the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda
Good morning.
Swiss investigators are [racing to identify the victims of a fire](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/01/switzerland-to-hold-five-days-of-mourning-after-dozens-killed-in-resort-fire) that tore through a crowded bar, killing about 40 people and injuring 115 who were celebrating at a New Year‚Äôs Eve party in the Alpine ski resort of Crans-Montana.
**How did the fire start?** The fire broke out at 1.30am on Thursday in the town‚Äôs Le Constellation bar, but it‚Äôs not yet clear what set off the blaze. Some witnesses said it started after sparklers or flares were put into champagne bottles.
**How long will it take to identify the dead?** Swiss police have warned it could take days or even weeks, leaving an agonising wait for family and friends.
**What else did he say?** Mamdani did not shy away from his socialist politics. ‚ÄúI was elected as a democratic socialist and I will govern as a democratic socialist. I will not abandon my principles for fear of being called radical,‚Äù he said to loud cheers from the gathered crowd. He ended by saying: ‚ÄúThe work has only just begun.‚Äù
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/02/first-thing-swiss-investigators-race-to-identify-victims-resort-bar-fire)

item.title: Indiana hand Alabama worst ever bowl loss to join Oregon and Ole Miss in college football‚Äôs last four
item.description:
• Indiana crush Alabama 38-3 in historic Rose Bowl win

  • Oregon‚Äôs defense shuts out Texas Tech in Orange Bowl

  • Last-minute field goal lifts Mississippi past Georgia

Fernando Mendoza threw for 192 yards and three touchdowns to lead top-seeded Indiana to a 38-3 blowout of ninth-seeded Alabama in a College Football Playoff quarter-final at the Rose Bowl on Thursday in Pasadena, California.

The Hoosiers advance to the semi-finals and will take on fifth-seeded Oregon on 9 January in the Peach Bowl.

item.title: USMNT‚Äôs World Cup, Arsenal‚Äôs title challenge and Real‚Äôs power struggle: soccer questions for 2026
item.description:
The world of soccer throws up no shortage of questions every year. In today‚Äôs Pitch Points column, we address three of the big ones for 2026

You may have heard there‚Äôs a World Cup this year. After all the debate about ticket prices and peace prizes and cooling breaks, an actual soccer tournament will kick off. That‚Äôs when the US, both as a national team and a host nation, will truly be judged; when the 2026 World Cup will be deemed a soaring success or a grotesque failure. There will be no in between. No nuance. That vanished from public discourse a long time ago.

item.title: ‚ÄòNo one can know‚Äô: Heated Rivalry‚Äôs gay love story exposes ice hockey‚Äôs culture of silence
item.description:
The surprise hit series has reopened a familiar debate: why, in the National Hockey League, visibility is still treated as a problem rather than a possibility

At around the midpoint of the first episode of Heated Rivalry, just after Shane Hollander and Ilya Rozanov ‚Äì one Canadian, the other Russian, both hockey‚Äôs top prospects ‚Äì have had their first tryst, Hollander sits at the side of his hotel bed and says: ‚ÄúSo. You‚Äôre not going to tell anyone about this, are you?‚Äù Rozanov, lying naked beside him, replies sarcastically: ‚ÄúMe? Yes, Hollander, I‚Äôm going to tell everyone.‚Äù Hollander reinforces the point: ‚ÄúBecause no one can know,‚Äù he says. Rozanov utters something under his breath in Russian, then: ‚ÄúHollander. Look, I‚Äôm not going to tell anyone, OK?‚Äù Hollander replies: ‚ÄúOK.‚Äù

No one can know. If hockey were to have an unofficial slogan, this might be it. Heated Rivalry, the surprise 2025 hit series from Crave and HBO, is layered drama, prompting timely questions about the barriers to acceptance that persist within sport even as they are lowered elsewhere across society. But it may be that hockey‚Äôs existential battle with its culture of silence is the show‚Äôs deepest target.

Continue reading...

item.title: The Guardian Footballer of the Year Jess Carter: ‚ÄòI remember not wanting to go out‚Äô
item.description:
England defender publicly confronted racist abuse at the Euros and ended 2025 a title winner with club and country

The Guardian Footballer of the Year is an award given to a player who has done something remarkable, whether by overcoming adversity, helping others or setting a sporting example by acting with exceptional honesty.

Jess Carter has spent her life grappling with when to hold back and when to speak up; wrestling with being naturally herself, embodying the characteristics her parents instilled in her of being open, honest, vocal and confident, and subduing herself because, while society values those traits, in a black woman they can be viewed negatively.

Continue reading...

item.title: South Park writer buys ‚ÄòTrump Kennedy Center‚Äô domain name
item.description:
Toby Morton now owns trumpkennedycenter.org, which advertises new year performance by the ‚ÄòEpstein dancers‚Äô

Donald Trump may be remaking the John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts into a pool of his self-reflection, but a writer for South Park, the TV series that better reflects the obsessions and tendencies of the administration than any political pundit, has purchased the rights to trumpkennedycenter.org.

Toby Morton, a TV writer and producer who has worked on the long-running and joyfully offensive sitcom, said he purchased the domain in August after predicting the president would change the name from the Kennedy Center to the Trump Kennedy Center after he installed himself as chair and stocked the board with loyalists.

Continue reading...

item.title: The year in charitable giving
item.description:
The winter holiday season is a key time for nonprofit fundraising ‚Äî an estimated 30% of annual giving happens in December. But in 2025, highly publicized federal cuts resulted in an individual giving boost throughout the year. In this episode, some nonprofits worry demand will soon outgrow those private donations. Plus: Latino immigrants say deportation fears are reminiscent of the Covid-19 lockdown, communities fight to buy back private utilities, and ‚ÄúThis Is Uncomfortable‚Äù host Reema Khrais gives tips for sticking to financial New Year‚Äôs resolutions.

item.title: From "This Is Uncomfortable": "You'll never be ready to buy a home"
item.description:
Hey smarties! Happy New Year. We‚Äôre taking a short break for the holidays. In the meantime, we‚Äôre sharing an episode from our friends over at ‚ÄúThis Is Uncomfortable.‚Äù Reema Khrais and the team are getting ready to relaunch the show on Jan. 15. Stay tuned for new episodes!


When newlyweds Chantal and Travis Lisback started searching for their dream home in Seattle, they weren‚Äôt entirely on the same page. Chantal was eager to settle down as soon as possible, while Travis was more comfortable waiting a few years. As the search dragged on, what began as a shared dream started to feel more like a standoff.¬†


This week, a story about how a big life decision can bring to light the money and communication issues you didn‚Äôt know were there. Plus, later in the episode, Chantal and Travis sit down with financial therapist¬†Aja Evans¬†to unpack what‚Äôs happening beneath the surface, and how to approach money fights with more care and intention.¬†


If you liked this episode, share it with a friend!

item.description:

item.title: Trump says he takes more aspirin than recommended but his ‚Äòhealth is perfect‚Äô
item.description:
President tells Wall Street Journal in interview that his doctors encouraged him to take lower dose but he declined

Donald Trump takes ‚Äúmore aspirin‚Äù than his doctors recommend but says his ‚Äúhealth is perfect‚Äù, according to an interview given to the Wall Street Journal after the outlet recently questioned the 79-year-old president‚Äôs health.

Trump told the Journal that the large dose of aspirin he take daily causes him to bruise easily and that doctors have encouraged him to take a lower dose ‚Äì but he declined the advice because he has been taking it for 25 years.

item.title: Abortion may no longer be a top priority for Democratic voters ahead of 2026 midterms, polls show
item.description:
Abortion was seen as one of Democrats‚Äô strongest issues in the 2024 election ‚Äì new polls indicate that may be shifting

Up to seven states will vote on abortion rights this year. But recent polling indicates that Democrats may not be able to count on the issue in their efforts to drive votes in the 2026 midterms, after making abortion rights the centerpiece of their pitch to voters in the elections that followed the fall of Roe v Wade.

In 2024, 55% of Democrats said abortion was important to their vote, according to polling from the Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI). But in October of this year, just 36% of Democrats said the same. By contrast, abortion remained about as important to Republicans in both 2024 and 2025, PRRI found. PRRI‚Äôs findings mirror a September poll from the 19th and SurveyMonkey, which found that the voters who cared most about abortion are people who want to see it banned.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Abortion was seen as one of Democrats‚Äô strongest issues in the 2024 election ‚Äì new polls indicate that may be shifting
Up to seven states will vote on abortion rights this year. But recent polling indicates that Democrats may not be able to count onthe issue in their efforts todrive votes in the 2026 midterms, after makingabortion rightsthe centerpiece of their pitch to voters in the elections that followedthe fall of Roe v Wade.
In 2024, 55% of Democrats said abortion was important to their vote, according to polling from the Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI). But in October of this year, just 36% of Democrats said the same. By contrast, abortion remained about as important to Republicans in both 2024 and 2025, PRRI found. [PRRI‚Äôs findings mirror a September poll](https://19thnews.org/2025/09/poll-abortion-voters-motivations-priorities/) from the 19th and SurveyMonkey, which found that the voters who cared most about abortion are people who want to see it banned.

item.title: ‚ÄòTheir first instinct was to loot‚Äô: how Trump‚Äôs acolytes are plundering the Kennedy Center
item.description:
Sheldon Whitehouse, an ex officio member of the Kennedy Center board, remains undeterred and determined to press on with his investigation

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the tactic they use,‚Äù said Sheldon Whitehouse, a Rhode Island senator, pondering whether Donald Trump might attach his name to the John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. ‚ÄúYou float stuff and you float stuff and you float stuff until people get inured to what a stupid or outrageous thing it is that has been floated and then you pull the trigger.‚Äù

Whitehouse was sitting in his Senate office and speaking to the Guardian at 11am on Thursday 18 December. Two hours later, his words proved prophetic. Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, announced on X that the Kennedy Center board had ‚Äúvoted unanimously‚Äù to rename it the Trump-Kennedy Center.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the tactic they use,‚Äù said Sheldon Whitehouse, a Rhode Island senator, pondering whether Donald Trump might attach his name to the [John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](https://www.kennedy-center.org/). ‚ÄúYou float stuff and you float stuff and you float stuff until people get inured to what a stupid or outrageous thing it is that has been floated and then you pull the trigger.‚Äù
Whitehouse was sitting in his Senate office and speaking to the Guardian at 11am on Thursday 18 December. Two hours later, his words proved prophetic. Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, [announced on X](https://x.com/PressSec/status/2001717032191168839?s=20) that the Kennedy Center board had ‚Äúvoted unanimously‚Äù to rename it the Trump-Kennedy Center.

item.title: US federal employees file complaint against ban on gender-affirming care
item.description:
Complaint argues Trump administration denying coverage of gender-affirming care is sex-based discrimination

The Trump administration is facing a legal complaint from a group of government employees affected by a new policy going into effect Thursday that eliminates coverage for gender-affirming care in federal health insurance programs.

The complaint, filed Thursday on the employees‚Äô behalf by the Human Rights Campaign, is in response to an August announcement from the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) that it would no longer cover ‚Äúchemical and surgical modification of an individual‚Äôs sex traits through medical interventions‚Äù in health insurance programs for federal employees and US Postal Service workers.

Continue reading...

item.title: Gas prices are lower, but will that stick around in 2026?
item.description: Gas prices hit their lowest level for a December since 2020, according to AAA, thanks largely to a global oil glut that pushed crude prices down about 20% last year. We look at whether cheaper fuel is likely to stick around in 2025. Plus, a new business in New York City doubles as a museum celebrating the history and cultural impact of the photo booth. And we examine how the expiration of federal tax credits is reshaping the electric vehicle market after a rocky year.

item.title: US ‚Äòadapt, shrink or die‚Äô terms for $2bn aid pot will mean UN bowing down to Washington, say experts
item.description:
Afghanistan and Yemen excluded from list of 17 priority countries chosen by Trump administration to receive aid laden with demands

The $2bn (¬£1.5bn) of aid the US pledged this week may have been hailed as ‚Äúbold and ambitious‚Äù by the UN but could be the ‚Äúnail in the coffin‚Äù in changing to a shrunken, less flexible aid system dominated by Washington‚Äôs political priorities, aid experts fear.

After a year of deep cuts in aid budgets by the US and European countries, the announcement of new money for the humanitarian system is a source of some relief, but experts are deeply concerned about demands that the US has imposed on how the money should be managed and where it can go.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Afghanistan and Yemen excluded from list of 17 priority countries chosen by Trump administration to receive aid laden with demands
The $2bn (¬£1.5bn) of aid the [US pledged this week](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/29/us-pledge-un-model-humanitarian-assistance) may have been hailed as [‚Äúbold and ambitious‚Äù](https://reliefweb.int/report/world/ocha-managed-humanitarian-funds-receive-landmark-us2-billion-contribution-united-states) by the UN but could be the ‚Äúnail in the coffin‚Äù in changing to a shrunken, less flexible aid system dominated by Washington‚Äôs political priorities, aid experts fear.
After a year of [deep cuts in aid budgets](https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2025/dec/21/sweden-and-germany-slash-aid-budgets-to-focus-on-ukraine-and-defence-spending) by the US and European countries, the announcement of new money for the humanitarian system is a source of some relief, but experts are deeply concerned about demands that the US has imposed on how the money should be managed and where it can go.

item.title: From rent to utility bills: the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda
item.description:
As the Trump administration derides climate policy as a ‚Äòscam‚Äô, emissions-cutting measures are gaining popularity

A group of progressive politicians and advocates are reframing emissions-cutting measures as a form of economic populism as the Trump administration derides climate policy as a ‚Äúscam‚Äù and fails to deliver on promises to tame energy costs and inflation.

Climate politics were once cast as a test of moral resolve, calling on Americans to accept higher costs to avert environmental catastrophe, but that ignores how rising temperatures themselves drive up costs for working people, said Stevie O‚ÄôHanlon, co-founder of the youth-led Sunrise Movement.

item.title: ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt think we should have billionaires‚Äô: mayor Zohran Mamdani in his own words
item.description:
Democratic socialist mayor led historic push to lead New York, speaking on immigration, Trump and subway burritos

Zohran Mamdani, the democratic socialist who is now mayor of New York City, ran a campaign known for its soaring political rhetoric, its viral memes and its candidate‚Äôs witty quips.

Here are some of the quotes that came to define his historic push to lead one of the world‚Äôs most important cities:

New York will remain a city of immigrants: a city built by immigrants, powered by immigrants, and, as of tonight, led by an immigrant. So hear me, President Trump, when I say this: to get to any of us, you will have to get through all of us.

What I don‚Äôt have in experience, I make up for in integrity. And what you don‚Äôt have in integrity, you could never make up for with experience.

No more will New York be a city where you can traffic in Islamophobia and win an election.

It‚Äôs pronounced ‚Äòcyclist‚Äô.

I am young, despite my best efforts to grow older. I am Muslim. I am a democratic socialist. And most damning of all, I refuse to apologize for any of this.

I don‚Äôt think that we should have billionaires because, frankly, it is so much money in a moment of such inequality, and ultimately, what we need more of is equality across our city and across our state and across our country.

I hear you. I see you. And if you‚Äôre a burrito on the Q train, I eat you.

If anyone can show a nation betrayed by Donald Trump how to defeat him, it is the city that gave rise to him. So, if there is any way to terrify a despot, it is by dismantling the very conditions that allowed him to accumulate power. This is not only how we stop Trump, it‚Äôs how we stop the next one. So, Donald Trump, since I know you‚Äôre watching, I have four words for you: turn the volume up!

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Democratic socialist mayor led historic push to lead New York, speaking on immigration, Trump and subway burritos
[Zohran Mamdani](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/zohran-mamdani), the democratic socialist who is now mayor of [New York City](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/new-york), ran a campaign known for its soaring political rhetoric, its [viral memes](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/20/zohran-mamdani-social-media-viral-videos) and its candidate‚Äôs witty quips.
Here are some of the quotes that came to define his [historic](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/06/zohran-mamdani-campaign-new-york-democrats) [push](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jun/23/zohran-mamdani-new-york-city-mayor-race-viral) to lead one of the world‚Äôs most important cities:
New York will remain a city of immigrants: a city built by immigrants, powered by immigrants, and, as of tonight, led by an immigrant. So hear me, President Trump, when I say this: to get to any of us, you will have to get through all of us.
What I don‚Äôt have in experience, I make up for in integrity. And what you don‚Äôt have in integrity, you could never make up for with experience.
No more will New York be a city where you can traffic in Islamophobia and win an election.
It‚Äôs pronounced ‚Äòcyclist‚Äô.
I am young, despite my best efforts to grow older. I am Muslim. I am a democratic socialist. And most damning of all, I refuse to apologize for any of this.
I don‚Äôt think that we should have billionaires because, frankly, it is so much money in a moment of such inequality, and ultimately, what we need more of is equality across our city and across our state and across our country.
I hear you. I see you. And if you‚Äôre a burrito on the Q train, I eat you.
If anyone can show a nation betrayed by Donald Trump how to defeat him, it is the city that gave rise to him. So, if there is any way to terrify a despot, it is by dismantling the very conditions that allowed him to accumulate power. This is not only how we stop Trump, it‚Äôs how we stop the next one. So, Donald Trump, since I know you‚Äôre watching, I have four words for you: turn the volume up!
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/01/mamdani-own-words-quotes)

item.title: From Sehitler to Armstrong: 10 female footballers set for breakthrough in 2026
item.description:
Today‚Äôs newsletter looks at 10 superlative talents who are ready to take the next step in the coming 12 months

Alara Sehitler, Bayern Munich and Germany (19): Sehitler‚Äôs transition into Bayern Munich‚Äôs first team has come as little surprise and the creative midfielder has established herself as a strong impact player for Jos√© Barcala‚Äôs side. She has three Frauen Bundesliga goals this season and sparked Bayern‚Äôs comeback against Arsenal in the Champions League. After making her senior debut for Germany in November 2024, she will be looking to establish herself as a regular for their upcoming 2027 World Cup qualifiers.

Giulia Galli, Roma and Italy (17): Galli is widely regarded as one of the best young Italian talents to emerge for a long time and became Roma‚Äôs youngest player to make her Serie A debut in May 2024, aged 16 and one month. Establishing herself in the senior squad this season, she scored her first club goal in September and has featured in the Champions League. After starring in Italy‚Äôs sensational run to the semi-finals of last summer‚Äôs Under-17 Euros, the talented forward played a significant role at the subsequent Under-17 World Cup, picking up the bronze boot. She will surely feature at this autumn‚Äôs Under-20 World Cup.

Continue reading...

item.title: Zohran Mamdani is now mayor of New York City. Here‚Äôs what he campaigned on
item.description:
From freezing rents to free buses and municipal grocery stores ‚Äì a recap of the policies that won Mamdani the office

Zohran Mamdani was sworn into office as New York‚Äôs 111th mayor at the stroke of midnight, the first Muslim mayor as well as the first to take office as a Democrat bearing the credentials of a democratic socialist.

The 34-year-old was sworn in by Letitia James, the state attorney general, in a disused subway station beneath city hall that acts as turnaround for the local 5 train, to be followed by a first-of-its-kind public block party along Broadway‚Äôs ‚ÄúCanyon of Heroes‚Äù.
