item.title: How to talk dating like gen Z: 51 (hyperspecific) terms for love, sex and bad behavior
item.description:
As young people take on a messy dating landscape, they‚Äôve created their own lexicon to match. Here‚Äôs like what phrases ‚Äòbird theory‚Äô and ‚Äòmonkey branching‚Äô mean

This year marked a decade since the term ‚Äúghosting‚Äù hit the mainstream. At the time, the idea that someone could abruptly cease communication with a lover without explanation seemed like the peak of indignity. How naive we were. In the 10 years since, finding a partner has only become more confounding ‚Äì an oftentimes fruitless exercise in humiliation that is increasingly pigeonholed by social media jargon.

Gen Z, a cohort who came of age during a loneliness epidemic, a masculinity crisis, and a coordinated attack on the rights of women and the LGBTQ+ community, faces a far messier landscape than their millennial predecessors could ever imagine. And so their dating glossary has grown longer and more deranged, with phrases like ‚ÄúShrekking‚Äù and ‚Äúmonkey branching‚Äù testing the limits of your sanity.

Red flags ‚Äì Behavioral quirks indicating a potential partner is bad news. Examples include calling their exes crazy, subpar tipping habits, a love of Woody Allen films, a burgeoning DJ career ‚Ä¶

Green flags ‚Äì These quirks validate your decision to pursue a mate. Examples include checking in to make sure you got home safe after a date, low screen time, owning a bed frame ‚Ä¶

Beige flags ‚Äì These usually describe niche, mostly benign quirks. Examples include being an enthusiastic birdwatcher, still carrying around a pen in their purse, paying rent in cash ‚Ä¶

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
As young people take on a messy dating landscape, they‚Äôve created their own lexicon to match. Here‚Äôs like what phrases ‚Äòbird theory‚Äô and ‚Äòmonkey branching‚Äô mean
This year marked a decade since the term ‚Äúghosting‚Äù hit the mainstream. At the time, the idea that someone could abruptly cease communication with a lover without explanation seemed like the peak of indignity. How naive we were. In the 10 years since, finding a partner has only become more confounding ‚Äì an oftentimes fruitless exercise in humiliation that is increasingly pigeonholed by social media jargon.
[Gen Z](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/series/the-sex-lives-of-gen-z), a cohort who came of age during a loneliness epidemic, a masculinity crisis, and a coordinated attack on the rights of women and the LGBTQ+ community, faces a [far messier landscape](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/datablog/2025/nov/28/gen-z-sex-dating-relationships) than their millennial predecessors could ever imagine. And so their dating glossary has grown longer and more deranged, with phrases like ‚ÄúShrekking‚Äù and ‚Äúmonkey branching‚Äù testing the limits of your sanity.
**Red flags** ‚Äì Behavioral quirks indicating a potential partner is bad news. Examples include calling their exes crazy, subpar tipping habits, a love of Woody Allen films, a burgeoning DJ career ‚Ä¶
**Green flags** ‚Äì These quirks validate your decision to pursue a mate. Examples include checking in to make sure you got home safe after a date, low screen time, owning a bed frame ‚Ä¶
**Beige flags** ‚Äì These usually describe niche, mostly benign quirks. Examples include being an enthusiastic birdwatcher, still carrying around a pen in their purse, paying rent in cash ‚Ä¶

item.title: A tech company that ‚Äòhappens to build homes‚Äô
item.description:
When it comes to homebuilding, Ronda Conger, vice president of CBH Homes, wants to be like the Savannah Bananas.


‚ÄúWe are out there trying to do things so differently,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the reasons we embraced AI so quickly.‚Äù


But there are growing fears that artificial intelligence will begin to replace human employees. For Conger‚Äôs team, the bots are doing the grunt work, so the real humans can shine.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani sworn in as mayor of New York City
item.description:
New mayor, 34, was sworn in by state attorney general Letitia James in old beaux-arts city hall subway station

Zohran Mamdani was sworn in as mayor of New York City soon after midnight in a private ceremony in an abandoned beaux-arts subway station ‚Äì a prelude to daylong celebrations set to include a second, public swearing-in and a block party outside city hall.

Mamdani, 34, was sworn into office by the New York attorney general, Letitia James, surrounded by wife, Rama Duwaji, members of his immediate family, including Mira Nair, his mother and a film-maker, and his father, Mahmood Mamdani, a professor of African studies at Columbia University.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump is wrong: ‚Äòwoke‚Äô policies aren‚Äôt the real threat to Europe | Nouriel Roubini
item.description:
The continent‚Äôs problems are not caused by immigration or cultural politics but by economic and technological decline

Donald Trump‚Äôs new national security strategy offers a misguided assessment of Europe, long regarded as the US‚Äôs most reliable ally. Unrestrained immigration and other policies derided by administration officials as ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, it warns, could lead to ‚Äúcivilisational erasure‚Äù within a few decades.

That argument rests on a fundamental misreading of Europe‚Äôs current predicament. While the EU does face an existential threat, it has little to do with immigration or cultural politics. In fact, the share of foreign-born residents in the US is slightly higher than in Europe.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
The continent‚Äôs problems are not caused by immigration or cultural politics but by economic and technological decline
Donald Trump‚Äôs new [national security strategy](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/2025-National-Security-Strategy.pdf) offers a misguided assessment of Europe, long regarded as the US‚Äôs most reliable ally. Unrestrained immigration and other policies derided by administration officials as ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, it warns, could lead to ‚Äúcivilisational erasure‚Äù within a few decades.
That argument rests on a fundamental misreading of Europe‚Äôs current predicament. While the EU does face an existential threat, it has little to do with immigration or cultural politics. In fact, the share of foreign-born residents in the [US](https://usafacts.org/answers/how-many-immigrants-are-in-the-us/country/united-states/) is slightly higher than [in Europe](https://www.rfberlin.com/immigrant-population-eu/).
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/01/trump-woke-policies-europe-economic-technological-decline)

item.title: Father and son dress as Santa, visit Gaza tent city with gifts, music to celebrate New Year
item.description: Sunset bathed the north of Gaza City in golden light Tuesday evening as Izzat Al-Qawasmeh and his 11-year-old son Mohamed climbed through rubble to the top of a building that once housed hundreds of people.¬†The duo had decided to visit the tent city with gifts, dressed in Santa Claus costumes.

item.title: Lauren Boebert claims Trump‚Äôs veto of safe drinking water bill is retaliation
item.description:
Colorado lawmaker, who pushed for Epstein files release, points to bill‚Äôs unanimous passage through US House and Senate

Republican representative Lauren Boebert has fired back at Donald Trump for vetoing a bill that would have funded a drinking water project in her Colorado district, implying the president was playing at political retaliation.

The bill was aimed at funding a decades-long project to bring safe drinking water to 39 communities in Colorado‚Äôs eastern plains, where the groundwater is high in salt and wells sometimes unleash radioactivity into the water supply.

item.title: What's next for the job market in 2026
item.description:
Total jobless claims fell last week, which is the second-lowest reading in the last two years. Experts, though, say it‚Äôs likely a seasonal blip ‚Äî especially since the labor market has been slowing all year. In this episode, what might be ahead in 2026. Plus: Los Angeles expands rent control, influencers change the consumer economy with ‚Äúshopaganda,‚Äù and tribute bands get a moment in the spotlight.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.

item.title: US Olympic men‚Äôs ice hockey squad takes shape ahead of Friday‚Äôs reveal
item.description:
• Clayton Keller captained US to world title last May

  • NHL players back at Olympics after 12-year absence

  • Team USA targets first Olympic gold since 1980

A trio of NHL players ‚Äì Utah Mammoth captain Clayton Keller, Buffalo Sabres forward Tage Thompson and Florida Panthers defenseman Seth Jones ‚Äì will make their Olympic debuts with Team USA at February‚Äôs Winter Games, ESPN reported on Wednesday.

Olympic rosters had to be submitted by Wednesday. USA Hockey plans to announce its roster Friday morning on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúToday.‚Äù This is the first time in 12 years that NHL players will compete in the Olympics.

item.title: Trump administration reportedly freezes all childcare payments to all states
item.description:
Trump official says funds will be released ‚Äòonly when states prove they are being spent legitimately‚Äô

The Department of Health and Human Services is freezing all childcare payments to all states, an official for Donald Trump‚Äôs administration told ABC News in a report published Wednesday. States‚Äô funds will be released ‚Äúonly when states prove they are being spent legitimately‚Äù.

The report came a day after Jim O‚ÄôNeill, the HHS deputy secretary, and Alex Adams, an HHS assistant secretary who oversees the Administration for Children and Families (ACF), appeared in a Tuesday evening video message. O‚ÄôNeill declared that the department had ‚Äúactivated our defend-the-spend system for all ACF childcare payments across America‚Äù and would now require ‚Äújustification, receipt or photo evidence before we make a payment‚Äù.

Continue reading...

Trump official says funds will be released ‚Äòonly when states prove they are being spent legitimately‚Äô

States‚Äô funds will be released ‚Äúonly when states prove they are being spent legitimately‚Äù.

item.title: Energy Dept. orders Colorado to waste millions to reopen a dead coal plant
item.description:
The Department of Energy ordered Colorado coal plant to stay open for three months, one day before it was set to close. The coal plant will require tens of millions in repairs to get up and running again, and its retirement was expected to save Colorado ratepayers $79 million per year.

item.title: Jack Smith told House committee he had ‚Äòproof beyond reasonable doubt‚Äô in cases against Trump
item.description:
Ex-special counsel testified in front of judiciary committee about aborted federal prosecution of Donald Trump

Jack Smith, the former justice department special counsel who led the aborted federal prosecution of Donald Trump, told a congressional committee that he never spoke to Joe Biden about his cases, according to the transcript of a deposition released on Wednesday.

In his behind-closed-doors testimony to the House judiciary committee earlier this month, Smith defended the charges he brought against Trump for allegedly possessing classified documents and attempting to overturn the 2020 election, while warning of the consequences of allowing election meddling to go unpunished.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Ex-special counsel testified in front of judiciary committee about aborted federal prosecution of Donald Trump
Jack Smith, the former justice department special counsel who led the aborted federal prosecution of [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump), told a congressional committee that he never spoke to [Joe Biden](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/joebiden) about his cases, according to [the transcript of a deposition](https://judiciary.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/republicans-judiciary.house.gov/files/2025-12/Smith-Depo-Transcript_Redacted-w-Errata.pdf) released on Wednesday.
In his behind-closed-doors testimony to the House judiciary committee earlier this month, Smith [defended the charges](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/17/jack-smith-house-testimony-trump) he brought against Trump for allegedly possessing classified documents and attempting to overturn the [2020 election](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-elections-2020), while warning of the consequences of allowing election meddling to go unpunished.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/31/jack-smith-house-testimony)

item.title: Trump backs away from deploying national guard in Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland
item.description:
Decision comes after DoJ stopped contesting California court‚Äôs ruling to return control of guard to state‚Äôs governor

Donald Trump has staged a sudden climbdown from his attempts to impose federal troops in law enforcement roles on Democratic-run cities, announcing on Wednesday that he was ending attempted deployments from Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland.

The unexpected shift came after justice department lawyers said they were no longer contesting a California court‚Äôs ruling that returned the national guard troops to the authority of Gavin Newsom, the state‚Äôs governor. It also followed a rare rebuke from the US supreme court, which blocked the White House‚Äôs efforts to deploy national guards in Illinois.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Decision comes after DoJ stopped contesting California court‚Äôs ruling to return control of guard to state‚Äôs governor
[Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) has staged a sudden climbdown from his attempts to impose federal troops in law enforcement roles on Democratic-run cities, announcing on Wednesday that he was ending attempted deployments from Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland.
The unexpected shift came after justice department lawyers said they were no longer contesting a [California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california) court‚Äôs ruling that returned the national guard troops to the authority of Gavin Newsom, the state‚Äôs governor. It also followed a rare rebuke from the US supreme court, which blocked the White House‚Äôs efforts to deploy national guards in [Illinois](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/illinois).

item.title: ICE plans $100m yearlong ‚Äòwartime recruitment‚Äô media blitz to attract new agents
item.description:
Campaign will target rightwing ideologues to fill ranks to meet Trump deportation goals in 2026

US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has reportedly planned a $100m, one-year media blitz for what it‚Äôs calling ‚Äúwartime recruitment‚Äù, targeting conservative radio show listeners, gun rights aficionados, military affairs followers and men‚Äôs interests enthusiasts ‚Äì among others in the Maga-verse ‚Äì for jobs in the Trump administration‚Äôs next phase of its mass deportation campaign.

‚ÄúWant to deport illegals with your absolute boys?‚Äù one of the agency‚Äôs ads says, directing interested readers to apply.

item.title: End of an era as New York City transit retires three-decade-old MetroCard
item.description:
Resisted at first, the replacement for the subway token became an indelible symbol of the city

First, New Yorkers saw the elimination of subway token, which lasted for half a century. Now, its successor ‚Äì the swipeable MetroCard, which lasted barely more than three decades ‚Äì has seen its demise.

At midnight on 1 January, the flexible credit card-sized pass used by millions of New Yorkers to get through subway turnstiles is being terminated from sale just as a new mayor, Zohran Mamdani, takes office.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not a coincidence‚Äô: journalists of color on being laid off amid Trump‚Äôs anti-DEI push
item.description:
Black and brown former employees from CBS, NBC and Teen Vogue talk about the effects of being let go

Trey Sherman was traveling to work on the New York subway when he received an email from David Reiter, a CBS News executive, about an imminent meeting on 29 October. Sherman, an associate producer of CBS Evening News Plus at the time, suspected that he would be laid off. CBS News‚Äôs parent company, Paramount, had closed a merger with the Hollywood studio Skydance in August, and planned to slash more than 2,000 jobs as part of corporate restructuring.

Sherman, who is Black, and Reiter, who is white, had an amicable conversation, according to Sherman. Reiter told Sherman that he was being laid off because his show was being eliminated, Sherman said, and that Reiter was unable to assign the team to other positions. Sherman accepted the news and the two men wished each other good luck.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Black and brown former employees from CBS, NBC and Teen Vogue talk about the effects of being let go
Trey Sherman was traveling to work on the New York subway when he received an email from [David Reiter](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/11/07/bari-weiss-cbs-news-remake/), a CBS News executive, about an imminent meeting on 29 October. Sherman, an associate producer of CBS Evening News Plus at the time, suspected that he would be laid off. CBS News‚Äôs parent company, Paramount, had closed a merger with the Hollywood studio Skydance in August, and planned to slash [more than 2,000 jobs](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/29/business/media/paramount-layoffs-skydance.html) as part of corporate restructuring.
Sherman, who is Black, and Reiter, who is white, had an amicable conversation, according to Sherman. Reiter told Sherman that he was being laid off because his show was being eliminated, Sherman said, and that Reiter was unable to assign the team to other positions. Sherman accepted the news and the two men wished each other good luck.

item.title: Diggins, Schumacher make US cross-country skiing history with World Cup double
item.description:
• US men and women win World Cup races same day

  • Schumacher and Diggins sweep new 5km event

  • Tour de Ski milestone for American cross-country

American cross-country skiing reached a milestone on Wednesday when, for the first time, an American man and an American woman won World Cup races on the same day.

Gus Schumacher and Jessie Diggins delivered the historic double at stage three of the Tour de Ski in Toblach, Italy, both prevailing in a newly introduced 5km heat mass start free event that rewarded speed, pacing and collective tactics rather than head-to-head positioning.

Continue reading...

- Tour de Ski milestone for American cross-country
American cross-country skiing reached a milestone on Wednesday when, for the first time, an American man and an American woman won World Cup races on the same day.

item.title: US justice department reportedly reviewing more than 5m pages of Epstein files
item.description:
Figure represents significant expansion on earlier estimates as Democrats accuse Trump officials of ‚Äòhiding something‚Äô

The US justice department is believed to be reviewing more than 5m pages of documents relating to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein ‚Äì an effort that is drawing resources away from existing cases, according to the New York Times.

The figure represents a significant expansion on earlier estimates, which drew on calculations based on 300 gigabytes of data, papers, videos, photographs and audio files held within FBI archives that relate to investigations in Florida and New York.

item.title: Court allows White House to end Medicaid funding for Planned Parenthood in 22 states
item.description:
Appeals court reversed injunction blocking Trump administration‚Äôs defunding of reproductive healthcare giant

A US appeals court agreed on Tuesday to allow the Trump administration to strip Medicaid funding from Planned Parenthood health centers in 22 states and Washington DC.

The order from the three-judge panel of the Boston-based first US circuit court of appeals puts on hold an injunction issued by US district judge Indira Talwani. Talwani‚Äôs injunction had blocked the Trump administration from enforcing a provision of its massive tax-and-spending bill that blocks Planned Parenthood from receiving reimbursements from Medicaid, the US government‚Äôs health insurance program for low-income people, in the 22 states.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Appeals court reversed injunction blocking Trump administration‚Äôs defunding of reproductive healthcare giant
A US appeals court agreed on Tuesday to allow the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) to strip [Medicaid](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/medicaid) funding from [Planned Parenthood](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/planned-parenthood) health centers in 22 states and Washington DC.
The order from the three-judge panel of the Boston-based first US circuit court of appeals [puts on hold](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/02/trump-planned-parenthood-medicaid-funding) an injunction issued by US district judge Indira Talwani. Talwani‚Äôs injunction had blocked the Trump administration from enforcing a provision of its massive tax-and-spending bill that blocks Planned Parenthood from receiving reimbursements from Medicaid, the US government‚Äôs health insurance program for low-income people, in the 22 states.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/31/planned-parenthood-medicaid-funding-ends)

item.title: Mystery meat and maggot-infested produce: the disturbing reality of US prison food
item.description:
In Eating Behind Bars, author Leslie Soble details how food is used to further punish incarcerated people in the US

At best you get ‚Äúmystery meat‚Äù. Or ‚Äúsour-smelling heaps‚Äù of macaroni. In the worst cases, it‚Äôs undercooked chicken, spoiled milk and maggot-infested produce.

In prisons and jails across the US, people are routinely fed unhealthy, tasteless or inedible meals. Many are left hungry and malnourished, with devastating long-term health consequences. The hidden crisis affecting millions of incarcerated people is the subject of Eating Behind Bars, a new book offering a disturbing account of how correctional institutions punish their residents through the food they provide and withhold.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
In Eating Behind Bars, author Leslie Soble details how food is used to further punish incarcerated people in the US
At best you get ‚Äú [mystery meat](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jul/15/irish-tourist-ice-detention)‚Äù. Or ‚Äúsour-smelling heaps‚Äù of [macaroni](https://www.postandcourier.com/food/feeding-the-prison-system-some-inmates-buy-way-around-institutional-cooking/article_34755b6a-ab43-11e6-9077-5b2ef518ef63.html). In the worst cases, it‚Äôs [undercooked](https://www.businessinsider.com/san-quentin-on-lockdown-as-inmates-suffer-gastrointestinal-illness-2024-7) chicken, [spoiled milk](https://nbcmontana.com/news/local/report-montana-state-prison-inmates-served-spoiled-milk) and maggot-infested [produce](https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2015/06/02/aramark-michigan-prison-contractor-maggots-kitchen/28378435/).
In prisons and jails across the US, people are routinely fed unhealthy, tasteless or inedible meals. Many are left hungry and malnourished, with devastating long-term health consequences. The hidden crisis affecting millions of incarcerated people is the subject of [Eating Behind Bars](https://thenewpress.org/books/eating-behind-bars/?v=eb65bcceaa5f), a new book offering a disturbing account of how correctional institutions punish their residents through the food they provide and withhold.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/31/eating-behind-bars-book-prison-food)

item.title: Kennedy Center reportedly changed rules before vote to add Trump‚Äôs name
item.description:
Bylaws that would limit voting to Trump-appointed trustees appears to reveal long-held renaming plan

The Kennedy Center reportedly adopted bylaws earlier this year that would limit voting to Donald Trump-appointed trustees ‚Äì a controversial move that appears to reveal the long-held plan to install Trump‚Äôs name to the center.

The bylaws, in a possible breach of the institution‚Äôs charter, were revised in May and specified that board members appointed by Congress, known as ex-officio members, could not vote or count towards a quorum, according to the Washington Post.

Continue reading...

Bylaws that would limit voting to Trump-appointed trustees appears to reveal long-held renaming plan
The Kennedy Center reportedly adopted bylaws earlier this year that would limit voting to Donald Trump-appointed trustees ‚Äì a controversial move that appears to reveal the long-held plan to install Trump‚Äôs name to the center.
The bylaws, in a possible breach of the institution‚Äôs charter, were revised in May and specified that board members appointed by Congress, known as ex-officio members, could not vote or count towards a quorum, [according to the Washington Post.](https://www.washingtonpost.com/style/2025/12/31/kennedy-center-board-trustees-bylaws/)
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/31/trump-kennedy-center)

item.title: ‚ÄòHeartbreaking‚Äô: Florida wildlife groups decry state-sanctioned bear hunt
item.description:
Fifty-two black bears were killed in three-week hunt state officials said was necessary to reduce ursine population

Wildlife officials in Florida say the slaughter of dozens of black bears during a controversial three-week hunt this month was a success, despite the opposition of protesters who condemned the ‚Äúheartbreaking, bloody spectacle‚Äù.

The Florida fish and wildlife conservation commission (FWC) on Tuesday announced that 52 bears were killed between 6 and 28 December, and promised to release a ‚Äúfull harvest report‚Äù in the coming months that will provide details about where and how the animals died.

Continue reading...

The Florida fish and wildlife conservation commission (FWC) on Tuesday announced that [52 bears were killed](https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/FLFFWCC/bulletins/4021dea?reqfrom=share) between 6 and 28 December, and promised to release a ‚Äúfull harvest report‚Äù in the coming months that will provide details about where and how the animals died.

item.title: ‚ÄòA state of crisis‚Äô: record number of Americans are pessimistic about US healthcare system
item.description:
Costs, insurance delays and difficult-to-obtain mental health treatment plague the US health system

A record 23 % of Americans believe the United States healthcare system is ‚Äúin a state of crisis‚Äù and 47% think it has ‚Äúmajor problems,‚Äù according to a recent poll from the West Health-Gallup Center on Healthcare in America.

The poll also revealed that a record 29% of Americans see ‚Äúcost‚Äù as the most urgent health problem facing the US. Experts note that these two perceptions ‚Äì that the healthcare system is in a state of crisis and that costs are an urgent health problem ‚Äì are related.

Continue reading...

item.title: Skyrocketing health insurance premiums for millions after today
item.description: Enhanced subsidies for health insurance policies on the Affordable Care Act exchanges are set to expire at the end of today. That means skyrocketing premiums for some Obamacare enrollees. Premiums are expected to more than double, according to the nonpartisan health research organization KFF, and some healthier people are expected to drop their insurance. Plus, 2025 was the year that generative AI exploded, divided, and created trust issues. We'll take a look back.

The broadcaster ITV has agreed to invest up to ¬£3m into the health and fitness app The Body Coach, created by Joe Wicks, who shot to fame by getting people exercising in their living rooms during the Covid pandemic.

item.title: How the climate crisis showed up in Americans‚Äô lives this year: ‚ÄòThe shift has been swift and stark‚Äô
item.description:
Guardian US readers share how global heating and biodiversity loss affected their lives in ways that don‚Äôt always make the headlines

The past year was another one of record-setting heat and catastrophic storms. But across the US, the climate crisis showed up in smaller, deeply personal ways too.

Campfires that once defined summer trips were never lit due to wildfire risks. There were no bites where fish were once abundant, forests turned to meadows after a big burn and childhood memories of winter wonderlands turned to slush.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Guardian US readers share how global heating and biodiversity loss affected their lives in ways that don‚Äôt always make the headlines
The past year was another one of record-setting heat and catastrophic storms. But across the US, the [climate crisis](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-crisis) showed up in smaller, deeply personal ways too.
Campfires that once defined summer trips were never lit due to [wildfire](https://www.theguardian.com/world/wildfires) risks. There were no bites where fish were once abundant, forests turned to meadows after a big burn and childhood memories of winter wonderlands turned to slush.

item.title: Fed up: inside Trump‚Äôs unprecedented bid to exert control over the US central bank
item.description:
The US president and his allies spent 2025 attacking the Federal Reserve amid a rollercoaster year for the US economy

In the bowels of the US Federal Reserve this summer, two of the world‚Äôs most powerful men, sporting glistening white hard hats, stood before reporters looking like students forced to work together on a group project.

Allies of Donald Trump had spent weeks trying to manufacture a scandal around ongoing renovations of the central bank‚Äôs Washington headquarters and its costs. Now here was the US president, on a rare visit, examining the project for himself.

Continue reading...

item.title: An unwelcome surprise for some student loan borrowers
item.description: People who are in default on their federal student loans could start seeing their wages garnished in the new year. Next week, the Department of Education plans to start sending out letters to borrowers who have missed at least nine months of payments, letting them know the government will begin taking 15% from their paychecks. Also, the U.S. Mint pressed the final batch of pennies last month. We examine the penny's 232-year run.

item.title: A gig worker strike threatens New Year's Eve deliveries in India

item.title: A whiplash year for electric vehicles
item.description:
2025 brought some new speed bumps for electric vehicle sales, namely the Republicans' One Big Beautiful Bill Act. It cut federal EV tax credits ‚Äî up to $7,500 for new cars and $4,000 for used ones. Those incentives had been on the books in some form since 2008 and were expanded during the Biden administration. They expired at the end of September.


Consumers rushed to take advantage before they disappeared, leading to record high sales earlier this year. But now the market faces an uncertain road ahead.


Marketplace's Meghan McCarty Carino spoke with her colleague Henry Epp about the outlook for EV sales in the U.S. now that federal tax credits are gone.
item.source:markdown:
2025 brought some new speed bumps for electric vehicle sales, namely the Republicans' One Big Beautiful Bill Act. It cut federal EV tax credits ‚Äî up to $7,500 for new cars and $4,000 for used ones. Those incentives had been on the books in some form since 2008 and were expanded during the Biden administration. They expired at the end of September.
Consumers rushed to take advantage before they disappeared, leading to [record high sales](https://www.coxautoinc.com/insights-hub/q3-2025-ev-sales-report-commentary/) earlier this year. But now the market faces an uncertain road ahead.
Marketplace's Meghan McCarty Carino spoke with her colleague Henry Epp about the outlook for EV sales in the U.S. now that federal tax credits are gone.

item.title: Life after LeBron James: who will inherit the NBA‚Äôs future?
item.description:
As the millennial superstars near the end, an international generation reshapes the league. The question is whether an American can still carry the crown

That the NBA is reckoned in seasons is apt. To measure a legacy this way is as much existential as it is symbolic. Martin Heidegger argued that time is not something we pass through, but the condition of our being ‚Äì less a pathway than a pressure. Heavy stuff, yes, but the NBA has always operated under similar weight.

The millennial superstars who stabilized the league for two decades are now entering their twilight: LeBron James (who turned 41 on Tuesday), Stephen Curry, Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook, James Harden and Chris Paul. In their wake comes something genuinely new. For the first time, the league‚Äôs next dominant generation is unmistakably international. The NBA‚Äôs gen Z elite now emerge from Slovenia, Serbia, Greece, Canada and France.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump administration freezes childcare funding to Minnesota in wake of fraud scheme allegations
item.description:
Officials claim to find ‚Äòrampant fraud‚Äô in childcare funding, but prosecutions began in Biden era and Tim Walz says ‚Äòwe‚Äôve spent years cracking down on it‚Äô

The Trump administration announced on Tuesday that it is freezing federal funding for childcare programs in Minnesota after allegations of fraud ‚Äì first exposed and prosecuted during the Biden administration ‚Äì recently became the focus of conservative influencers and media outlets.

Jim O‚ÄôNeill, the deputy secretary of health and human services, said in a video statement that the funding freeze was in response to what he called ‚Äúblatant fraud that appears to be rampant in Minnesota and across the country ‚Ä¶ We have turned off the money spigot and we are finding the fraud.‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: National Guard arrives in New Orleans for 1st New Year‚Äôs since Bourbon Street attack
item.description:
Nearly a year after a New Year's Day truck attack on Bourbon Street left 14 dead, New Orleans officials are still seeking permanent security solutions. Ahead of the anniversary of the rampage, officials are ramping up security measures. Some 350 National Guard members arrived Tuesday. The attack happened when a man plowed a truck into revelers before police shot and killed him. The rampage revealed security vulnerabilities surrounding a famous street that is densely populated by bars and pedestrians. A police captain has urged the city to install permanent security gates to prevent future attacks.

The post National Guard arrives in New Orleans for 1st New Year‚Äôs since Bourbon Street attack first appeared on Federal News Network.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: California snowpack gets a boost from series of December downpours
item.description:
Water stored as snow during the winter months feeds waterways in the summer and supplies cities and farms

A series of December storms delivered a welcome boost to California‚Äôs snowpack, scientists said on Tuesday in a closely watched assessment of the state‚Äôs water resources for the year ahead.

The snowpack survey recorded a snow depth of 24in (61cm), said Angelique Fabbiani-Leon, state hydrometeorologist at the California department of water resources‚Äô snow surveys and water supply forecasting unit. The survey was conducted at the Phillips station in the Sierra Nevada, a mountain range that covers the eastern part of the state.

Continue reading...

item.title: Good news for prospective homebuyers
item.description:

Especially those who‚Äôve been waiting on the sidelines for a good deal. But, as with most housing issues, the slowdown is regional. item.title: Man banned from Nelson, B.C., sentenced for arson during heat of 2024 wildfire season
item.description: David Travis was sentenced to two years less a day and will spend 593 days in custody, accounting for time already served, after pleading guilty to three counts of arson. item.title: Three hikers found dead on southern California‚Äôs Mount Baldy
item.description:
One person had made an emergency call after companion fell 500ft, but rescue copter couldn‚Äôt land due to high winds

A man and two of his companions are dead after high winds prevented rescue crews from responding to a report of an injured hiker near a southern California mountain trail, the San Bernardino county sheriff‚Äôs department announced on Monday.

The three bodies were discovered Monday evening along the Devil‚Äôs Backbone trail at Mount Baldy, which rises more than 10,000ft and sits just east of Los Angeles, according to a statement from the San Bernardino county sheriff‚Äôs department.

item.title: Dodge dealers don‚Äôt need a new Charger ‚Äî they need a new Caravan
item.description:
If the market failures of the Dodge Charger Daytona and VW ID.Buzz have proved anything at all, it‚Äôs that the Baby Boomer era is over, and their kids ‚Äî GenX and Millenials alike ‚Äî aren‚Äôt willing to pay a premium for a vehicle that looks like something their dad once thought was cool. As GenX becomes the largest and richest new car-buying demographic, manufacturers need to find out what they are nostalgic about.

To that end, I propose the following nostalgia play: the ‚ÄúGoonies Never Say Die‚Äù edition 2027 Dodge Caravan BEV.

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2025/12/caravan_MAIN.jpg?quality=82&strip=all&w=1600)

To that end, I propose the following nostalgia play: **the ‚ÄúGoonies Never Say Die‚Äù edition 2027 Dodge Caravan BEV**.

item.title: Suspected DC pipe bomber appears at detention hearing after alleged confession
item.description:
Lawyers for Brian Cole argue he should be released ahead of trial for allegedly planting devices in DC in 2021

The man accused of planting pipe bombs outside the headquarters of both the Democratic and Republican national committees the night before the January 6 insurrection at the US Capitol appeared at a federal detention hearing before a magistrate judge on Tuesday.

Earlier this month, authorities arrested Brian Cole Jr of Woodbridge, Virginia. He has yet to enter a plea. Cole‚Äôs lawyers argued that he should be released while he awaits trial, as he does not present any danger. They also noted that Cole had agreed to home detention enforced by GPS monitoring, and would live under the supervision of a relative. The defense rebuked federal prosecutors who pushed for the suspect to remain in custody.

Continue reading...

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of JFK, dies after rare leukemia diagnosis
item.description:
Schlossberg, 35, revealed in November diagnosis of mutation of cancer of blood and bone marrow

Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of the 35th US president, John F Kennedy, died on Tuesday after revealing in November she had been diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia. She was 35.

Her passing was announced in a social media post by the John F Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum. ‚ÄúOur beautiful Tatiana passed away this morning. She will always be in our hearts,‚Äù the post said. It was signed ‚ÄúGeorge, Edwin and Josephine Moran, Ed, Carolina, Jack, Rose and Rory‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Minutes of latest Federal Reserve meeting reveal deep divide over interest rates
item.description:
In an unusual turn, the central bank‚Äôs board debated over monetary policy before the latest quarter-point cut

The US Federal Reserve agreed to cut interest rates at its December meeting only after a deeply nuanced debate about the risks facing the US economy right now, according to minutes of the latest two-day session.

Even some of those who supported the rate cut acknowledged ‚Äúthe decision was finely balanced or that they could have supported keeping the target range unchanged‚Äù, given the different risks facing the US economy, according to the minutes released on Tuesday.

Continue reading...

item.title: US judge halts ending of temporary protected status for South Sudanese migrants
item.description:
Emergency request by several of the country‚Äôs nationals and an immigrants rights group was granted by the court

A federal judge on Tuesday blocked plans by the Trump administration to end temporary protections from deportation that had been granted to hundreds of South Sudanese nationals living in the United States.

US district judge Angel Kelley in Boston granted an emergency request by several South Sudanese nationals and an immigrant rights group to prevent the temporary protected status they had been granted from expiring as planned after 5 January.

item.title: Judge says Trump administration must continue funding consumer watchdog
item.description:
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is at risk after Donald Trump vowed to shutter it since his return to office

A federal judge has ordered that the Trump administration must allow funding for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to continue.

The watchdog, which supporters say protects US consumers from financial harm by powerful banks, lenders and corporations, is at risk of collapsing after Donald Trump vowed to shutter it since he returned to office this year.

Continue reading...

item.title: Mamdani to be sworn in as New York mayor in abandoned subway station
item.description:
Mamdani to take oath of office on New Year‚Äôs Eve in gilded age subway station beneath city hall

While tens of thousands of New Yorkers will be in Times Square for the countdown to 2026, the city‚Äôs mayor-elect, Zohran Mamdani, has said he will be sworn into office in an underground midnight private ceremony at an abandoned subway station built during the gilded age.

Mamdani, 34, plans to take the oath of office on New Year‚Äôs Eve in a disused subway station beneath city hall that acts as turnaround for the local 5 train. The unusual choice of venue for the ceremony, Mamdani said, is symbolically resonant of the ‚Äúinauguration of a new era‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Patriots‚Äô Stefon Diggs faces strangulation and assault charges in Massachusetts
item.description:
• Diggs charged with felony strangulation, denies claims

  • Judge considers sealing records before arraignment

  • Case unfolds as Patriots chase NFL playoff bye

New England Patriots star wide receiver Stefon Diggs is facing strangulation and other criminal charges in connection with a dispute with his former private chef, police said.

News of the charges emerged after a court hearing on Tuesday in Dedham, Massachusetts. Diggs is charged with felony strangulation or suffocation and misdemeanor assault and battery.

News of the charges emerged after a court hearing on Tuesday in Dedham, Massachusetts. Diggs is charged with felony strangulation or suffocation and misdemeanor assault and battery.

item.title: Nascar driver Denny Hamlin‚Äôs father dies in North Carolina house fire
item.description:
• Fire destroyed home near Stanley, North Carolina

  • Hamlin‚Äôs father Dennis died; mother critically injured

  • Cause of blaze remains under investigation

The father of Nascar driver Denny Hamlin died and his mother was critically injured after a weekend fire heavily damaged the North Carolina home where they lived, officials said Monday.

Firefighters arrived Sunday night at a two-story home near Stanley that was mostly engulfed in fire, with flames showing through the attic, the Gaston county office of emergency management and fire services said in a news release.

item.title: Winter storm brings heavy snow and strong winds across parts of the US
item.description:
Frigid temperatures in Great Lakes, north-east and midwest as tens of thousands face power outages and icy travel

A wild winter storm brought strong winds, heavy snow and frigid temperatures to the Great Lakes and north-east on Tuesday, a day after a bomb cyclone barreled across the midwest and left tens of thousands of customers without power.

The storm hit parts of the Plains and Great Lakes on Monday with sharply colder air, strong winds and a mix of snow, ice and rain, leading to treacherous travel. Forecasters said it intensified quickly enough to meet the criteria of a bomb cyclone, a system that strengthens rapidly as pressure drops.

Continue reading...

Forecasters said it intensified quickly enough to meet the criteria of a bomb cyclone, a system that strengthens rapidly as pressure drops.

item.title: More musicians drop out of Kennedy Center shows after Trump name change
item.description:
The Cookers on Monday pulled out of a New Year‚Äôs Eve jazz gig at the controversially renamed ‚ÄòTrump-Kennedy‚Äô center

A second jazz band has pulled out of performing at the controversially renamed ‚ÄúTrump-Kennedy‚Äù center in Washington DC, giving just two days‚Äô notice before their New Year‚Äôs Eve gig was set to take place.

The Cookers, described as a Grammy-nominated, all-star septet of legendary post-bop jazz musicians, have not given an explicit reason for their decision but in a statement posted on their website said: ‚ÄúJazz was born from struggle and from a relentless insistence on freedom: freedom of thought, of expression, and of the full human voice.‚Äù

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

The Cookers, described as a Grammy-nominated, all-star septet of legendary post-bop jazz musicians, have not given an explicit reason for their decision but in a [statement posted on their website](https://www.thecookersmusic.com/) said: ‚ÄúJazz was born from struggle and from a relentless insistence on freedom: freedom of thought, of expression, and of the full human voice.‚Äù

item.title: A housing roundup and lookahead
item.description: This morning, we're recapping the 2025 housing market, which was ‚Äî¬†in a word ‚Äî sluggish. Even though mortgage rates have come down, affordability remains an issue, and many would-be sellers are locked into ultra-low rates. But economists and real estate agents expect some modest pickup in the year ahead. Then, there's renewed focus on the vulnerability of the global auto supply chain after hackers targeted Jaguar Land Rover in September.
item.source:markdown: This morning, we're recapping the 2025 housing market, which was ‚Äî¬†in a word ‚Äî sluggish. Even though mortgage rates have come down, affordability remains an issue, and many would-be sellers are locked into ultra-low rates. But economists and real estate agents expect some modest pickup in the year ahead. Then, there's renewed focus on the vulnerability of the global auto supply chain after hackers targeted Jaguar Land Rover in September.

item.title: Frustrations over state of Iran‚Äôs economy
item.description: From the BBC World Service: Annual inflation in Iran is running at more than 40%, and business owners are angry at the rapid devaluation of the nation's currency, in part due to the pressure of Western sanctions. In response, shopkeepers in the capital, Tehran, have been demonstrating for a third successive day. Plus, this year's hack at British carmaker Jaguar Land Rover showed just how vulnerable the global auto supply chain could be.

item.title: Despair for would-be US citizens as American dream blocked by Trump
item.description:
Aspirant Americans tell of exclusions from ceremonies by sudden policy introduced on ‚Äòsecurity‚Äô grounds

The occasion should have been marked by the joy of reaching the destination of US citizenship following the long odyssey of immigration.

Instead, the ceremony at Boston‚Äôs Faneuil Hall ‚Äì renowned as a ‚Äúcradle of liberty‚Äù for its role as a protest hub in the run-up to the American revolution ‚Äì felt like a nightmarish end of the road for some aspirant new Americans who had turned up full of hope.

item.title: Shawn Harris was ready to defeat Marjorie Taylor Greene. Now he awaits Republicans‚Äô next move
item.description:
After the far-right US representative‚Äôs resignation, Harris wonders who his opponent for Georgia‚Äôs 14th district will be

Retired brigadier general Shawn Harris had been all geared up for a campaign to defeat Marjorie Taylor Greene next November, and then the far-right representative quit the field. Now he‚Äôs wondering what Republicans will throw at him.

In November, Greene announced she would resign from Congress rather than face a challenger backed by the president after she began disagreeing with Donald Trump‚Äôs policies on Iran, healthcare and the release of the Epstein files, opening the field for a successor.

Continue reading...

item.title: AI-powered chatbots sent some users into a spiral
item.description:
AI psychosis became a thing in 2025. That's when a chatbot leads a user into a delusional spiral.


The technology's tendency to affirm what people say can result in conversations that become untethered from reality and, in the worst cases, has ended with real-world harms. Kashmir Hill has been reporting on this phenomenon for The New York Times.


Content warning: This episode includes mention of self harm and suicide.

item.title: Online school and junior tennis: freedom, focus ‚Äì and a quiet cost
item.description:
Elite junior tennis players are flocking to online schools. The model offers flexibility and focus ‚Äì but raises deeper questions about growth, pressure and childhood

In a major study released recently in Epidemiology, conclusions were drawn ‚Äì yet again ‚Äì regarding how shutdowns and online learning were ultimately very damaging to kids‚Äô emotional and mental health (obviously some cohorts of kids were more affected than others with financial security a big part of the calculation). This is no major surprise as parents and students alike weren‚Äôt happy with the remote learning environment.

Yet despite this general consensus about online schooling not being as healthy as regular school, a new trend has exploded since Covid: the rapid growth of online schooling for tennis players and other athletes. Parents and their junior athletes feel that by being able to play several hours in the day instead of after school it will accelerate their progress in the sport while still leaving room for academics. And from my perspective, as a parent of a competitive tennis player who attends a ‚Äúregular‚Äù school, it appears to be the rule, not the exception, that most advanced junior players are in online school and not in a physical building. I often find myself bonding with the few other parents whose kids remain in regular school as we‚Äôre a rapidly dwindling species.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Elite junior tennis players are flocking to online schools. The model offers flexibility and focus ‚Äì but raises deeper questions about growth, pressure and childhood
In a major study [released recently in Epidemiology](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/08/health/school-closures-mental-health.html), conclusions were drawn ‚Äì yet again ‚Äì regarding how shutdowns and online learning were ultimately very damaging to kids‚Äô emotional and mental health (obviously some cohorts of kids were more affected than others with financial security a big part of the calculation). This is no major surprise as parents and students alike weren‚Äôt happy with the remote learning environment.
Yet despite this general consensus about online schooling not being as healthy as regular school, a new trend has exploded since Covid: the rapid growth of online schooling for tennis players and other athletes. Parents and their junior athletes feel that by being able to play several hours in the day instead of after school it will accelerate their progress in the sport while still leaving room for academics. And from my perspective, as a parent of a competitive tennis player who attends a ‚Äúregular‚Äù school, it appears to be the rule, not the exception, that most advanced junior players are in online school and not in a physical building. I often find myself bonding with the few other parents whose kids remain in regular school as we‚Äôre a rapidly dwindling species.

item.title: ‚ÄòBe fearful when others are greedy‚Äô: Warren Buffett‚Äôs sharpest lessons in investing
item.description:
As the billionaire retires, he leaves memorable advice from his annual letters that include pithy takes on bubbles, discipline and long-term goals

Warren Buffett, the billionaire investor who is retiring at the end of 2025, has entertained and educated shareholders in his Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate for many years with his pithy annual letters outlining the firm‚Äôs performance.

Every year since 1965 he has updated his investors on the journey as Berkshire morphed from a ‚Äústruggling northern textile business‚Äù with $25m of shareholder equity when he took over, to an empire worth more than $1tn.

Though the price I paid for Berkshire looked cheap, its business ‚Äì a large northern textile operation ‚Äì was headed for extinction.

My error caused Berkshire shareholders to give far more than they received (a practice that ‚Äì despite the biblical endorsement ‚Äì is far from blessed when you are buying businesses).

Woody Allen once explained why eclecticism works: ‚ÄòThe real advantage of being bisexual is that it doubles your chances for a date on Saturday night.‚Äô

When such a CEO is encouraged by his advisers to make deals, he responds much as would a teenage boy who is encouraged by his father to have a normal sex life. It‚Äôs not a push he needs.

Andrew destroyed a few small insurers. Beyond that, it awakened some larger companies to the fact that their reinsurance protection against catastrophes was far from adequate. (It‚Äôs only when the tide goes out that you learn who‚Äôs been swimming naked.)

In our view, however, derivatives are financial weapons of mass destruction, carrying dangers that, while now latent, are potentially lethal.

Participants seeking to dodge troubles face the same problem as someone seeking to avoid venereal disease: it‚Äôs not just whom you sleep with, but also whom they are sleeping with.

From this irritating reality comes the first law of corporate survival for ambitious CEOs who pile on leverage and run large and unfathomable derivatives books: modest incompetence simply won‚Äôt do; it‚Äôs mind-boggling screw-ups that are required.

When downpours of that sort occur, it‚Äôs imperative that we rush outdoors carrying washtubs, not teaspoons. And that we will do.

Naturally, I was delighted to attend Mrs B‚Äôs birthday party. After all, she‚Äôs promised to attend my 100th.

She sold me our interest when she was 89 and worked until she was 103. (After retiring, she died the next year, a sequence I point out to any other Berkshire manager who even thinks of retiring.)

The candidates are young to middle-aged, well-to-do to rich, and all wish to work for Berkshire for reasons that go beyond compensation.

(I‚Äôve reluctantly discarded the notion of my continuing to manage the portfolio after my death ‚Äì abandoning my hope to give new meaning to the term ‚Äòthinking outside the box‚Äô.)

Continue reading...

Warren Buffett, the billionaire investor [who is retiring at the end of 2025](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2025/may/03/warren-buffett-retirement-berkshire-hathaway), has entertained and educated shareholders in his Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate for many years with his pithy annual letters outlining the firm‚Äôs performance.
Every year since 1965 he has updated his investors on the journey as Berkshire morphed from a ‚Äústruggling northern textile business‚Äù with $25m of shareholder equity when he took over, to an empire worth more than $1tn.
Though the price I paid for Berkshire looked cheap, its business ‚Äì a large northern textile operation ‚Äì was headed for extinction.
My error caused Berkshire shareholders to give far more than they received (a practice that ‚Äì despite the biblical endorsement ‚Äì is far from blessed when you are buying businesses).
Woody Allen once explained why eclecticism works: ‚ÄòThe real advantage of being bisexual is that it doubles your chances for a date on Saturday night.‚Äô
When such a CEO is encouraged by his advisers to make deals, he responds much as would a teenage boy who is encouraged by his father to have a normal sex life. It‚Äôs not a push he needs.

In our view, however, derivatives are financial weapons of mass destruction, carrying dangers that, while now latent, are potentially lethal.
Participants seeking to dodge troubles face the same problem as someone seeking to avoid venereal disease: it‚Äôs not just whom you sleep with, but also whom they are sleeping with.
From this irritating reality comes the first law of corporate survival for ambitious CEOs who pile on leverage and run large and unfathomable derivatives books: modest incompetence simply won‚Äôt do; it‚Äôs mind-boggling screw-ups that are required.
When downpours of that sort occur, it‚Äôs imperative that we rush outdoors carrying washtubs, not teaspoons. And that we will do.
Naturally, I was delighted to attend Mrs B‚Äôs birthday party. After all, she‚Äôs promised to attend _my_ 100th.
She sold me our interest when she was 89 and worked until she was 103. (After retiring, she died the next year, a sequence I point out to any other Berkshire manager who even thinks of retiring.)
The candidates are young to middle-aged, well-to-do to rich, and all wish to work for Berkshire for reasons that go beyond compensation.
(I‚Äôve reluctantly discarded the notion of my continuing to manage the portfolio after my death ‚Äì abandoning my hope to give new meaning to the term ‚Äòthinking outside the box‚Äô.)

item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard is still in pursuit of an oil tanker over a week after they first tried to intercept the ship. item.title: Falcons upend playoff-bound Rams as Bijan Robinson runs wild
item.description:
• Robinson‚Äôs 93-yard run sets Falcons franchise mark

  • Atlanta survives blown leads to upset playoff Rams

  • Gonzalez‚Äôs late kick seals third straight Falcons win

Bijan Robinson rushed for 195 yards, including a 93-yard touchdown, Zane Gonzalez kicked a 51-yard field goal with 21 seconds remaining and the Atlanta Falcons recovered after blowing two 21-point leads to upset the playoff-bound Los Angeles Rams 27-24 on Monday night.

Robinson‚Äôs 93-yard touchdown run was the longest in Atlanta history and Jessie Bates III scored on a 34-yard interception return. Bolstered by those big plays, the Falcons led 21-0 at halftime and 24-3 early in the second half.

Continue reading...

- Robinson‚Äôs 93-yard run sets Falcons franchise mark
- Atlanta survives blown leads to upset playoff Rams
- Gonzalez‚Äôs late kick seals third straight Falcons win
Bijan Robinson rushed for 195 yards, including a 93-yard touchdown, Zane Gonzalez kicked a 51-yard field goal with 21 seconds remaining and the Atlanta Falcons recovered after blowing two 21-point leads to upset the playoff-bound Los Angeles Rams 27-24 on Monday night.
Robinson‚Äôs [93-yard touchdown run](https://x.com/i/status/2005828580815536411) was the longest in Atlanta history and Jessie Bates III scored on a 34-yard interception return. Bolstered by those big plays, the Falcons led 21-0 at halftime and 24-3 early in the second half.

item.title: Elbows up in 2025: How a year of Canadian boycotts on U.S. products played out

item.title: After years on their back foot, here's why Democrats are feeling good about 2026
item.description: For much of the last two years, the U.S. Democratic Party has been on its back foot, enduring painful electoral defeats to an omnipresent Republican opponent while grappling with a troubling decline in voter registration and a listless party base. But in the closing days of 2025, the political pendulum appears to be swinging in their direction.

For much of the last two years, the U.S. Democratic Party has been on its back foot, enduring painful electoral defeats to an omnipresent Republican opponent while grappling with a troubling decline in voter registration and a listless party base. item.title: US military says two were killed in strike on suspected drug vessel in Pacific
item.description:
Two men killed in Hegseth-led attack on boat suspected of carrying drugs in international waters, Pentagon says

The US military announced the killing of another two men in ‚Äúa lethal kinetic strike‚Äù on a boat suspected of carrying drugs in international waters in the eastern Pacific Ocean on Monday.

The Pentagon released video of the strike, which brings the total number of known naval attacks on suspected drug smugglers to 30 since September, and raises the death toll to at least 107 people, according to US military figures.

Continue reading...

item.title: Beyonc√© is now the fifth billionaire musician, Forbes reports
item.description:
Grammy-winning artist joins husband Jay-Z and artists like Taylor Swift following the success of Cowboy Carter tour

Beyonc√© is now a billionaire, according to a report from Forbes ‚Äì becoming the fifth musician to obtain the status.

The Grammy award-winning artist, 44, has joined the world‚Äôs wealthiest people following the success of her Cowboy Carter tour, which grossed more than $400m in ticket sales, and an additional $50m in merchandise sales. Her previous Renaissance world tour brought in about more than $579m.

item.title: A glimmer of hope for the housing market
item.description:
The housing market is showing modest improvement, with pending home sales rising over 3% in November and prices growing just 1.2% year over year. Rising inventory and falling mortgage rates mean affordability is improving, though rates likely need to dip below 6% for demand to really pick up. Also in this episode: The 2026 outlook for oil prices and production, a look at which states are getting a minimum wage increase, and what's going on with AI travel influencers.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.

item.title: Trump says ‚Äòthere‚Äôll be hell to pay‚Äô if Hamas does not disarm as he meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago ‚Äì as it happened
item.description:
This live blog is now closed.

Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to tell Donald Trump on Monday that Hamas must return the remains of the last Israeli hostage left in Gaza before the next stages of the stalled ceasefire can be implemented, Israeli officials and analysts say.

The trip comes amid a new push by officials in Washington to force concessions from Israel to allow progress towards a second stage of the ceasefire in Gaza, which began in October after two years of devastating war.

He feels he has a number of cards to play yet and the remains of Gvili is the easiest one to play now but there are others.

Netanyahu knows exactly what he wants for Christmas ‚Äì more of the same. Israeli troops stay in 51% of Gaza, periodically striking Hamas ‚Ä¶ without the shadow of withdrawal looming over him. None of this requires a denunciation of the [Trump] plan itself and Trump can very easily justify Israel‚Äôs extended stay on Hamas‚Äôs unwillingness to disarm.

Continue reading...

He feels he has a number of cards to play yet and the remains of Gvili is the easiest one to play now but there are others.

item.title: Authorities identify the two victims of New Jersey helicopter crash: ‚ÄòThey were always together‚Äô
item.description:
Kenneth Kirsch, 65, and Michael Greenberg, 71, died after the Sunday middair collision near Hammonton airport

Two men who died after their helicopters collided midair in New Jersey over the weekend both earned their private pilot licenses over a decade ago and would often have breakfast together at a cafe near the crash site before taking to the skies from the local airport.

Authorities on Monday identified the two New Jersey men as Kenneth Kirsch, 65, and Michael Greenberg, 71. Witnesses told police that the two helicopters they were piloting Sunday were flying close together just before they crashed in a farm field near the airport in Hammonton, about 35 miles (56km) south-east of Philadelphia.

Continue reading...

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says she was ‚Äònaive‚Äô for believing Trump is man of the people
item.description:
Greene gave lengthy interview with New York Times days before stepping down as congresswoman for Georgia

Marjorie Taylor Greene, now just days away from stepping down as a congresswoman for Georgia, has said in her latest mea culpa interview that she ‚Äúwas just so naive‚Äù for believing that Donald Trump was a man of the people.

In a lengthy interview with the New York Times that examines her break with the president after years of devotion, Greene explained that a series of minor ruptures with the president culminated in a total breach after conservative influencer Charlie Kirk was killed in September.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Greene gave lengthy interview with New York Times days before stepping down as congresswoman for Georgia
[Marjorie Taylor Greene](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/marjorie-taylor-greene), now just days away from stepping down as a congresswoman for [Georgia](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/state-of-georgia), has said in her latest mea culpa interview that she ‚Äúwas just so naive‚Äù for believing that Donald Trump was a man of the people.
[In a lengthy interview with the New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/29/magazine/marjorie-taylor-greene-trump-maga-split.html) that examines her break with the president after years of devotion, Greene explained that a series of minor ruptures with the president culminated in a total breach after conservative influencer Charlie Kirk was killed in September.

item.title: EIA: All net new generating capacity in 2026 may be renewables
item.description:
During the first 10 months of 2025, solar and battery storage have dominated growth among competing energy sources. Further, all net new generating capacity in 2026 is forecast to be provided by renewable energy and batteries, according to data recently released by the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) reviewed by the SUN DAY Campaign.

During the first 10 months of 2025, solar and battery storage have dominated growth among competing energy sources. Further, all net new generating capacity in 2026 is forecast to be provided by renewable energy and batteries, according to data recently released by the US Energy Information Administration ( [EIA](https://electrek.co/guides/eia/)) reviewed by the SUN DAY Campaign.

item.title: US pledges $2bn in new UN model for delivery of humanitarian assistance
item.description:
Gaza not covered in announcement and will be handled on separate track, says US state department official

The United States on Monday pledged $2bn in assistance to tens of millions of people facing hunger and disease in more than a dozen countries next year, part of what it said was a new mechanism for the delivery of life-saving assistance following major foreign aid cuts by the Trump administration.

The US slashed its aid spending this year, and leading western donors such as Germany also pared back assistance as they pivoted to increased defense spending, triggering a severe funding crunch for the UN. The billions of dollars in assistance pledged by Washington on Monday will be overseen by the UN office for the coordination of humanitarian affairs, the state department said, under what it described as new model of assistance agreed with the UN that aims to make aid funding and delivery more efficient and increase accountability for the spending of funds.

Continue reading...

item.description:

item.title: China is running out of critical battery material: here are the countdowns
item.description:
We talk a lot here at¬†Electrek¬†about the exponential growth of electric vehicles and the massive strain that puts on the battery supply chain. Literally, the majority of that demand and production comes from China.

But there is a massive difference between¬†processing¬†materials and actually having them in the ground.

A new image from a gigantic materials mining and recycling company in China,¬†gives us a sobering look at the reality of their domestic reserves.¬†The data suggests that China‚Äôs own supply of the most critical battery metals isn‚Äôt just running low; in some cases,¬†it‚Äôs already gone.

item.title: Body of triathlete apparently killed by shark found on California beach
item.description:
Erica Fox‚Äôs remains were found after nearly weeklong search, marking a rare shark-related fatality for California

California firefighters have found the body of a California triathlete on a beach north-west of Santa Cruz, almost a week after she went missing amid speculation that she was killed by a shark.

The remains of Erica Fox were found on Saturday, her father and husband confirmed to local news outlets. Fox, 55, was part of a group of more than a dozen swimmers who left from Lovers Point near Monterey, California, on 21 December, but she never returned to shore. A witness driving by the area reported to authorities that they saw a shark with what appeared to be a human body in its mouth emerge from the water, according to the San Francisco Chronicle.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Erica Fox‚Äôs remains were found after nearly weeklong search, marking a rare shark-related fatality for California
[California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california) firefighters have found the body of a California triathlete on a beach north-west of Santa Cruz, almost a week after she went missing amid speculation that she was killed by a shark.
The remains of Erica Fox were found on Saturday, her father and husband [confirmed](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/body-found-california-coast-triathlete-went-missing-shark-sighting-rcna251171) to [local news](https://www.mercurynews.com/2025/12/28/lovers-point-shark-attack-victim-identified-by-watch-shark-band-on-ankle/?clearUserState=true) outlets. Fox, 55, was part of a group of more than a dozen swimmers who left from Lovers Point near Monterey, California, on 21 December, but she never returned to shore. A witness driving by the area reported to authorities that they saw a shark with what appeared to be a human body in its mouth emerge from the water, [according to the San Francisco Chronicle](https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/swimmer-missing-pacific-grove-identified-21259455.php).
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/29/california-triathlete-body-found-shark)

item.title: FBI deploys more resources to Minnesota amid Trump‚Äôs targeting of state
item.description:
Kash Patel claims $250m Covid aid fraud scheme is ‚Äòtip of iceberg‚Äô and blames state‚Äôs Somali population

The FBI has deployed additional personnel and investigative resources to Minnesota to ‚Äúdismantle large-scale fraud schemes exploiting federal programs‚Äù, director Kash Patel said on social media on Sunday.

Amid the Trump administrations attacks on the state and its Somali immigration population, the FBI director said the agency had already dismantled a $250m fraud scheme that stole federal food aid meant for vulnerable children during the Covid pandemic in a case that led to 78 indictments and 57 convictions.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Kash Patel claims $250m Covid aid fraud scheme is ‚Äòtip of iceberg‚Äô and blames state‚Äôs Somali population
The [FBI](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/fbi) has deployed additional personnel and investigative resources to [Minnesota](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/minnesota) to ‚Äúdismantle large-scale fraud schemes exploiting federal programs‚Äù, director Kash Patel said on social media on Sunday.
Amid the Trump administrations attacks on the state and its Somali immigration population, the FBI director said the agency had already dismantled a [$250m fraud scheme](https://www.justice.gov/usao-mn/pr/federal-jury-finds-feeding-our-future-mastermind-and-co-defendant-guilty-250-million) that stole federal food aid meant for vulnerable children during the Covid pandemic in a case that led to 78 indictments and 57 convictions.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/28/fbi-minnesota-fraud-schemes-somalia)

item.title: US struck ‚Äòbig facility‚Äô in Venezuela, Trump claimed without offering details
item.description:
Trump alleged that US forces hit ‚Äòvery hard‚Äô in what would mark his team‚Äôs first land strike on Venezuela if confirmed

Donald Trump has claimed that US forces struck a ‚Äúbig facility‚Äù in Venezuela last week ‚Äì but the president did not specify what it was, or where, and the White House has not commented further.

‚ÄúWe just knocked out ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know if you read or you saw ‚Äì they have a big plant, or a big facility, where the ships come from. Two nights ago, we knocked that out. So we hit them very hard,‚Äù Trump told Republican donor and New York supermarket owner John Catsimatidis on Friday.

item.title: Hundreds of Detroit home demolition sites may have been filled with toxic dirt
item.description:
Toxic chemicals like lead and asbestos are likely in dirt used to backfill demolished structures in city, experts say

Hundreds of Detroit home demolition sites were potentially backfilled with toxic construction debris from a demolished shopping mall and other sources, creating an unfolding public health threat in the city‚Äôs neighborhoods.

Detroit, the nation‚Äôs lowest income big city, is in the US industrial heartland. It was left with tens of thousands of empty structures as industrial plants closed and people left the city in past decades ‚Äì Detroit‚Äôs population dropped from nearly 2 million people around 1950 to fewer than 700,000 today. The city‚Äôs demolition program is widely considered the largest ever in the US.

Continue reading...

item.title: The Las Vegas Raiders and the thin line between tanking and incompetence
item.description:
Las Vegas shut down their two stars, angered their leader and were humiliated by the Giants. Whether it‚Äôs strategy or dysfunction, the result looks the same

The Las Vegas Raiders made waves this week by putting its two, and only, stars on injured reserve ahead of the final two games that will decide the 2026 NFL draft order. Tight end Brock Bowers and edge rusher Maxx Crosby were shut down from a consequential battle for the top draft pick against the Giants and a Week 18 game against Kansas City due to nagging knee injuries. Bowers had scored four touchdowns over the past five weeks for a team that doesn‚Äôt score many points. Crosby is a human wrecking ball who has amassed 28 tackles for loss this season. He‚Äôs the player that causes opponents to lose sleep. Both Bowers and Crosby were recently named to the Pro Bowl despite their nagging injuries. Bowers stepped away quietly. Crosby did not.

A fuming Crosby left the Raiders facility Friday. The next day he sent a message to the organization by posting videos of himself playing basketball with his young daughter. He did not appear particularly injured.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Las Vegas shut down their two stars, angered their leader and were humiliated by the Giants. Whether it‚Äôs strategy or dysfunction, the result looks the same
The Las Vegas Raiders made waves this week by putting its two, and only, stars on injured reserve ahead of the final two games that will decide the 2026 NFL draft order. Tight end Brock Bowers and edge rusher Maxx Crosby were shut down from a consequential battle for the top draft pick against the Giants and a Week 18 game against Kansas City due to nagging knee injuries. item.title: As the US media floundered this year, I couldn‚Äôt help but think: ‚ÄòThank God I‚Äôm at the Guardian‚Äô | Moira Donegan
item.description:
Other outlets have asked their writers to compromise, but the Guardian has never ‚Äì and would never ‚Äì ask me to pull a punch

  • Funded by readers, the Guardian‚Äôs fierce independence is guaranteed. Please help us reach our year-end fundraising goal in these final crucial hours

It might be most generous to characterize the behavior of major US media organizations since 2024 as negotiating between competing incentives.

On the one hand, billionaires have consolidated their ownership over major news outlets and platforms. The Murdochs are squabbling over Fox. Jeff Bezos has remade the Washington Post in his own image. The pharmaceutical magnate Patrick Soon-Shiong places a thumb on the scale at the Los Angeles Times, and the Trump-aligned Ellison family has taken over Paramount and CBS, and spent the final weeks of this year making hostile takeover bids for CNN owner Warner Bros. The influence of these billionaire personalities has often reshaped their organizations‚Äô newsrooms and editorial boards, directing investigations and particularly opinion sections towards ownership‚Äôs pet projects and preferred policies.

Continue reading...

In California, they promised, she would have a place to stay and a stable job. They would look after her just as she had cared for their grandmother.

item.title: Tesla‚Äôs 4680 battery supply chain collapses as partner writes down deal by 99%
item.description:
A major link in Tesla‚Äôs 4680 battery supply chain has just snapped. South Korean battery material supplier L&F Co. announced today that the value of its massive supply deal with Tesla has been slashed by over 99%, signaling a catastrophic drop in demand for the automaker‚Äôs in-house battery cells.

This is arguably the strongest evidence yet that Tesla‚Äôs 4680 program, and the vehicle that relies on it, the Cybertruck, is in serious trouble.
