item.title: Democratic lawmaker sues Trump over Kennedy Center‚Äôs name change
item.description:
Joyce Beatty seeks to remove the president‚Äôs name from the newly minted ‚ÄòTrump-Kennedy Center‚Äô

Democratic US representative Joyce Beatty of Ohio sued Donald Trump on Monday to seek the removal of his name from the John F Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington DC.

The lawsuit from Beatty, an ex-officio trustee on the board, argued that the vote to rename the Kennedy Center is a ‚Äúflagrant violation‚Äù of law as congressional approval is required for such an action.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Joyce Beatty seeks to remove the president‚Äôs name from the newly minted ‚ÄòTrump-Kennedy Center‚Äô
Democratic US representative Joyce Beatty of Ohio sued [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) on Monday to seek the removal of his name from the John F Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington DC.
The [lawsuit from Beatty](https://washingtonlitigationgroup.org/news/new-lawsuit-challenges-illegal-renaming-of-the-kennedy-center/), an ex-officio trustee on the board, argued that the vote to rename the Kennedy Center is a ‚Äúflagrant violation‚Äù of law as congressional approval is required for such an action.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/24/democratic-lawmaker-sues-trump-over-kennedy-center-name)

item.description: Trump-backed candidate Nasry Asfura won Honduras' presidential election, electoral authorities said Wednesday afternoon, ending a weeks-long count that has whittled away at the credibility of the Central American nation's fragile electoral system.

Trump-backed candidate Nasry Asfura won Honduras' presidential election, electoral authorities said Wednesday afternoon, ending a weeks-long count that has whittled away at the credibility of the Central American nation's fragile electoral system.

A federal judge has blocked the Trump administration‚Äôs efforts to reduce federal homeland security funding, including for disasters, for states that do not comply with immigration enforcement policies.

US district judge Mary McElroy of Rhode Island, a 2018 Trump appointee, ruled on Monday that the latest case was ‚Äúanother example‚Äù of the Trump administration tying state and local government assistance to its immigration crackdown.

item.title: NHTSA opens probe into Tesla emergency door releases following reports of deaths
item.description:
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has officially opened a defect petition to evaluate the emergency door release mechanisms in the Tesla Model 3. The probe covers approximately 180,000 vehicles and focuses on allegations that the manual releases are too difficult to locate during emergencies.

item.title: North Carolina Christmas tree farmers are optimistic after Hurricane Helene
item.description:
More than a year after the storm ripped apart families and farms, growers are bullish about strength of their industry

Christmas tree farmers in western North Carolina are still rebuilding from last year‚Äôs devastating Hurricane Helene, but growers are optimistic about business and the overall strength of their industry in the region.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still a lot of recovery that needs to happen, but we‚Äôre in much better shape than we were this time last year ‚Ä¶ sales are good,‚Äù Kevin Gray, owner of Hickory Creek Farm Christmas Trees in Greensboro, said earlier this month, while the buying season was in full swing.

item.title: The 12 days of Trump-mas
item.description:
What has Donald Trump given us in his second term? We look at some of the numbers

  • This was originally published in This Week in Trumpland; sign up to receive it in your inbox every Wednesday

Happy holidays! Across the 12 days of Christmas one very keen individual once gifted their lover a partridge in a pear tree, two turtle doves, three French hens, four calling birds, five gold rings, six geese a-laying, seven swans a-swimming, eight maids a-milking, nine ladies dancing, 10 lords a-leaping, 11 pipers piping and 12 drummers drumming.

An extravagant expression of what was allegedly ‚Äútrue love‚Äù, the spree amounted to a total of 364 presents ‚Äì more if you include the eggs that the geese a-laid.

Continue reading...

item.title: Boston taps into ‚Äòspirit of rebellion‚Äô as it resists ICE‚Äôs immigration crackdown
item.description:
The city is responding with ‚Äòstrategized resistance‚Äô as masked men roam the streets carrying out immigration raids at traffic stops, supermarkets and courthouses

Any Lucia L√≥pez Belloza will not be home for Christmas. The 19-year-old freshman was on a business scholarship at Babson College near Boston, when she decided to take a surprise flight home to Austin, Texas, to spend Thanksgiving with her parents and sisters.

Just before she boarded her flight at Logan airport on 20 November, she was arrested by federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and within 48 hours was deported back to Honduras, a country she left aged seven seeking asylum, with chains on her waist, ankles and wrists.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
The city is responding with ‚Äòstrategized resistance‚Äô as masked men roam the streets carrying out immigration raids at traffic stops, supermarkets and courthouses
Any Lucia L√≥pez Belloza will not be home for Christmas. The 19-year-old freshman was on a business scholarship at Babson College near Boston, when she decided to take a surprise flight home to Austin, Texas, to spend Thanksgiving with her parents and sisters.
Just before she boarded her flight at Logan airport on 20 November, she was [arrested by federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/08/ice-family-college-student-deported-honduras) and within 48 hours was deported back to Honduras, a country she left aged seven seeking asylum, with chains on her waist, ankles and wrists.

item.title: Fresh ‚Äòmanty‚Äô and cheap figs: a post-Soviet supermarket becomes a must-visit spot in NYC
item.description:
Tashkent Supermarket‚Äôs new West Village location offers staples like plov and samsas hot and fresh ‚Äì a taste of Central Asia for everyone

When I first stepped into the Tashkent Supermarket in Brighton Beach, I could barely get around. The store was bustling, packed with the familiar unsmiling faces of post-Soviet people eager to get their hands on foods like manty ‚Äì intricately shaped dumplings filled with minced beef, onion and, depending on where you‚Äôre from, pumpkin for the subtle sweetness. Or chak-chak, a dessert made of small pieces of fried golden dough held together by honey syrup. Kompot, too, a drink made by simmering seasonal or dried fruits.

Growing up in Kazakhstan, these were staples in school cafeterias and at home. Manty was one of the first dishes my mom taught me to make ‚Äì I thought she was a magician, the way she rolled the stretchy dough out so wide and thin, yet thick enough to hold the filling without tearing. I was rarely allowed to have soda or sugary drinks, but homemade kompot with fruits and berries from our garden was an exception. And though I never mastered chak-chak, the store-bought version was always a treat. As I got older and traveled across other former Soviet republics, I found comfort in knowing I would always find plov and samsas at eateries in Moscow, Baku and Tbilisi.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Tashkent Supermarket‚Äôs new West Village location offers staples like _plov_ and _samsas_ hot and fresh ‚Äì a taste of Central Asia for everyone
When I first stepped into the Tashkent Supermarket in Brighton Beach, I could barely get around. The store was bustling, packed with the familiar unsmiling faces of post-Soviet people eager to get their hands on foods like _manty_ ‚Äì intricately shaped dumplings filled with minced beef, onion and, depending on where you‚Äôre from, pumpkin for the subtle sweetness. Or _chak-chak_, a dessert made of small pieces of fried golden dough held together by honey syrup. _Kompot,_ too, a drink made by simmering seasonal or dried fruits.
Growing up in Kazakhstan, these were staples in school cafeterias and at home. _Manty_ was one of the first dishes my mom taught me to make ‚Äì I thought she was a magician, the way she rolled the stretchy dough out so wide and thin, yet thick enough to hold the filling without tearing. I was rarely allowed to have soda or sugary drinks, but homemade _kompot_ with fruits and berries from our garden was an exception. And though I never mastered _chak-chak_, the store-bought version was always a treat. As I got older and traveled across other former Soviet republics, I found comfort in knowing I would always find _plov_ and _samsas_ at eateries in Moscow, Baku and Tbilisi.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/24/tashkent-supermarket-west-village)

item.title: Republicans aim to exempt major polluters from Pfas cleanup costs
item.description:
Water treatment and landfill companies given chance to make case that EPA rules should not apply to them

Republicans are attempting to exempt some major polluters from paying for Pfas ‚Äúforever chemical‚Äù cleanup. If successful, it could mark a major setback in US effort to rein in Pfas pollution.

The Republican-led House energy and commerce committee recently held a hearing at which it invited representatives from the water treatment and landfill industries, among others, to make the case about why they should be exempted from rules that hold polluters financially accountable for the cleanup of two types of dangerous Pfas.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:

Republicans are attempting to exempt some major polluters from paying for Pfas ‚Äúforever chemical‚Äù cleanup. If successful, it could mark a major setback in US effort to rein in Pfas pollution.
The Republican-led House energy and commerce committee recently [held a hearing](https://energycommerce.house.gov/posts/environment-subcommittee-holds-hearing-on-the-current-statutory-and-regulatory-landscape-of-pfas) at which it invited representatives from the water treatment and landfill industries, among others, to make the case about why they should be exempted from rules that hold polluters financially accountable for the cleanup of two types of dangerous Pfas.

item.title: Trump‚Äôs claims to Venezuelan oil are part of broader ‚Äòresource imperialism‚Äô, experts say
item.description:
Critics compare offensive to Iraq war, citing familiar mix of regime-change rhetoric, security pretexts and oil interests

Donald Trump‚Äôs recent claims that the US should keep Venezuelan oil from seized tankers are part of a broader belief in rightwing ‚Äúresource imperialism‚Äù, experts say.

In recent weeks, the Trump administration has escalated pressure on Venezuela, invoking drug-trafficking claims. This month, the US intercepted two tankers carrying Venezuelan oil and began pursuing a third, while intensifying its campaign against the country‚Äôs president, Nicol√°s Maduro.

item.title: RCMP say 70 trees deliberately cut, left to die in Powell River, B.C.
item.description: Police say municipal staff inspected the site and found the trees were left standing but had been cut around their bases, likely with a chainsaw. Many of the trees that were cut were older-growth Douglas fir trees, valuable to the community and ecosystem.

item.title: Trump approves deployment of 350 national guard members to New Orleans
item.description:
Critics say deployment is unwarranted and could cause fear in the city, which has seen a decrease in violent crime rates

The Trump administration is deploying 350 national guard troops to New Orleans ahead of the new year, launching another federal deployment in the city at the same time that an immigration crackdown led by border patrol is under way.

Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell said on Tuesday that guard members, as they have in other deployments in large cities, will be tasked with supporting federal law enforcement partners, including the Department of Justice and the Department of Homeland Security. Parnell added that the national guard troops will be deployed through February.

Continue reading...

item.title: 5th person hospitalized in E. coli outbreak linked to Pillsbury brand Pizza Pops
item.description: The Public Health Agency of Canada is reporting a fifth hospitalization in an E. coli outbreak linked to recalled Pillsbury brand Pizza Pops. item.title: Is Trump mentally OK? A look back at the president‚Äôs unusual behavior in 2025
item.description:
Trump has shown erratic and bizarre behavior throughout the year, leading to questions about his mental acuity

In an address from the White House in December, Donald Trump claimed that, over the past 11 months, his administration had brought ‚Äúmore positive change‚Äù than any government in US history.

‚ÄúThere has never been anything like it,‚Äù Trump added.

America is respected again as a country. We were not respected with Biden. They looked at him falling down stairs every day. Every day, the guy‚Äôs falling down stairs.‚Äù

I said: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not our president. We can‚Äôt have it.‚Äô I‚Äôm very careful, you know, when I walk downstairs for ‚Äì like I‚Äôm on stairs, like these stairs, I‚Äôm very ‚Äì I walk very slowly. Nobody has to set a record, just try not to fall because it doesn‚Äôt work out well. A few of our presidents have fallen and it became a part of their legacy.

We don‚Äôt want that. Need to walk nice and easy. You not have ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to set any record. Be cool, be cool when you walk down, but don‚Äôt, don‚Äôt bop down the stairs. That‚Äôs the one thing with Obama, I had zero respect for him as a president, but he would bop down those stairs, I‚Äôve never seen ‚Äì da da da da da da, bop, bop, bop, he‚Äôd go down the stairs, wouldn‚Äôt hold on. I said, it‚Äôs great, I don‚Äôt want to do it. I guess I could do it, but eventually bad things are going to happen and it only takes once, but he did a lousy job as president.‚Äù

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trump has shown erratic and bizarre behavior throughout the year, leading to questions about his mental acuity
In an address from the White House in December, Donald Trump [claimed](https://x.com/RapidResponse47/status/2001474404899807408) that, over the past 11 months, his administration had brought ‚Äúmore positive change‚Äù than any government in US history.
‚ÄúThere has never been anything like it,‚Äù Trump added.
America is respected again as a country. We were not respected with Biden. They looked at him falling down stairs every day. Every day, the guy‚Äôs falling down stairs.‚Äù
I said: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not our president. We can‚Äôt have it.‚Äô I‚Äôm very careful, you know, when I walk downstairs for ‚Äì like I‚Äôm on stairs, like these stairs, I‚Äôm very ‚Äì I walk very slowly. Nobody has to set a record, just try not to fall because it doesn‚Äôt work out well. A few of our presidents have fallen and it became a part of their legacy.
We don‚Äôt want that. Need to walk nice and easy. You not have ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to set any record. Be cool, be cool when you walk down, but don‚Äôt, don‚Äôt bop down the stairs. That‚Äôs the one thing with Obama, I had zero respect for him as a president, but he would bop down those stairs, I‚Äôve never seen ‚Äì da da da da da da, bop, bop, bop, he‚Äôd go down the stairs, wouldn‚Äôt hold on. I said, it‚Äôs great, I don‚Äôt want to do it. I guess I could do it, but eventually bad things are going to happen and it only takes once, but he did a lousy job as president.‚Äù
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/24/trump-mental-health-speech-address-2025-review)

item.title: Throwing out flame-retardant furniture can reduce toxic chemicals in blood, study finds
item.description:
Flame retardants commonly used in furniture are linked to serious health issues, including cancer and thyroid disease

Removing old furniture made with flame retardants from people‚Äôs homes can significantly reduce the amount of the toxic chemicals in blood, a new 10-year, peer-reviewed study by California regulators and public health groups has found.

The drop that researchers found was a ‚Äúsuper big deal‚Äù, said Arlene Blum, the director of the Green Science Policy Institute who has for decades worked to reduce the level of flame retardants in consumer goods.

Continue reading...

item.title: The Trump administration can't withhold disaster relief
item.description: A federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to restore Homeland Security funding to 12 states and the District of Columbia. The administration had held back hundreds of millions of dollars from what it called "sanctuary jurisdictions." The cuts affected programs intended to support local police and emergency response in urban areas. Plus, food banks are bracing for strain ahead of changes to SNAP. We hear how services will be impacted on the ground in Kentucky.

item.title: 'It just fills my heart': Community rallies behind N.S. fish market after fire
item.description: When Tammy Victor arrived at Fisherman's Wharf in Eastern Passage, N.S., at 7:45 a.m. AT Wednesday to sell some lobster in an improvised storefront, a crowd was already waiting for her in the frigid outdoors. Victor co-owns The Lobster Dive, which burned down Monday in what is believed to be an electrical fire.

item.title: Venus Williams marries actor and model Andrea Preti in Palm Beach ceremony

Venus Williams married actor and model Andrea Preti over the weekend, the tennis great announced Tuesday on social media.

Williams, 45, and Preti were married in Palm Beach, Florida, following a five-day celebration that included family and close friends. The couple also held a non-official ceremony in Italy earlier this year.

item.title: China puts the brakes on driverless taxis
item.description: From the BBC World Service: Plans to mass-produce and sell self-driving vehicles in China have been delayed after news spread of a crash involving one earlier this year. Chinese regulators gave narrow approval to just two out of nine companies to operate autonomous taxis on highways. We learn more. Then, we hear why 2025 was a mixed picture for commodities. And later, Martha Stewart joins her friend Snoop Dogg as she invests in the U.K. soccer team, Swansea.

item.title: Woman deported before she could see dying husband in ICE custody: ‚ÄòI never saw him again‚Äô
item.description:
Francisco Gaspar-Andr√©s died in El Paso hospital after being detained at Fort Bliss ‚Äì his wife was deported to Guatemala without a chance to see him

A Guatemalan man has become the first person to die in the custody of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at the Fort Bliss army base in Texas. His wife of 25 years was deported from the same camp without a chance to see her dying husband.

Francisco Gaspar-Andr√©s, 48, died on 3 December at a hospital in El Paso, as Democratic lawmakers and immigration advocates were ramping up demands that the camp be closed down amid allegations of inhumane conditions there. The DHS has said such allegations are ‚Äúcategorically false‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Francisco Gaspar-Andr√©s died in El Paso hospital after being detained at Fort Bliss ‚Äì his wife was deported to Guatemala without a chance to see him
A Guatemalan man has become the first person to die in the custody of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at the [Fort Bliss army base](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/08/texas-army-fort-bliss-deportation-detention) in Texas. His wife of 25 years was deported from the same camp without a chance to see her dying husband.
Francisco Gaspar-Andr√©s, 48, died on 3 December at a hospital in El Paso, as Democratic lawmakers and [immigration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/usimmigration) advocates were ramping up [demands](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/23/democrats-texas-immigration-jail) that the camp be closed down [amid allegations](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/09/texas-ice-camp-abuse-immigration) of inhumane conditions there. The DHS has [said](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/09/texas-ice-camp-abuse-immigration) such allegations are ‚Äúcategorically false‚Äù.

item.title: Mushrooms could help curb plastic waste
item.description:
Polystyrene is the chemical compound that makes up styrofoam, which is used for packaging and insulation. But it‚Äôs not the most environmentally friendly.


By one estimate, 40 million tons of polystyrene were produced globally in 2024, leaving millions of tons of plastic waste. The search for an earth-friendly alternative has led researchers to dig deep and come up with an unlikely solution: fungus. The BBC‚Äôs Anna Holligan has this story.

item.title: How the Guardian reported 2025, with editor-in-chief Katharine Viner
item.description:
It has been a year dominated by Donald Trump. It has not yet even been 12 full months since his return to the White House in January but already the changes he has wrought ‚Äì both in the US and around the world ‚Äì seemed scarcely conceivable in 2024.
Katharine Viner, the Guardian‚Äôs editor-in-chief, tells Annie Kelly what it has looked like from the editor‚Äôs chair: from the deployment of the national guard on American streets, to the humiliation of Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the Oval Office, to the erosion of the rules that once governed peace and war.

In the UK, she describes a Labour government failing to tell its story and missing chance after chance to tackle the rise of Reform and the far right. ‚ÄòPolitics is about timing,‚Äô she says of the government‚Äôs notable silence over the summer, ‚Äòand I think a lot of those opportunities were missed.‚Äô
It has not been a year without hope, from the unexpected success of leftwing figures such as Zohran Mamdani and Zack Polanski, to the Guardian‚Äôs decisive victories in court defending its reporting, in a case described as a landmark ruling for #MeToo journalism.
Support the Guardian today: theguardian.com/todayinfocuspod

  • This is our last episode of 2025. Thank you to everyone who has listened and watched this year. We will return with new episodes on 5 January 2026.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
It has been a year dominated by Donald Trump. It has not yet even been 12 full months since his return to the White House in January but already the changes he has wrought ‚Äì both in the US and around the world ‚Äì seemed scarcely conceivable in 2024.
**Katharine Viner**, the Guardian‚Äôs editor-in-chief, tells **Annie Kelly** what it has looked like from the editor‚Äôs chair: from the deployment of the national guard on American streets, to the humiliation of Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the Oval Office, to the erosion of the rules that once governed peace and war.
In the UK, she describes a Labour government failing to tell its story and missing chance after chance to tackle the rise of Reform and the far right. ‚ÄòPolitics is about timing,‚Äô she says of the government‚Äôs notable silence over the summer, ‚Äòand I think a lot of those opportunities were missed.‚Äô
It has not been a year without hope, from the unexpected success of leftwing figures such as Zohran Mamdani and Zack Polanski, to the Guardian‚Äôs decisive victories in court defending its reporting, in a case described as a landmark ruling for #MeToo journalism.
_Support the Guardian today:_ [_theguardian.com/todayinfocuspod_](http://theguardian.com/todayinfocuspod)
- _This is our last episode of 2025. Thank you to everyone who has listened and watched this year. We will return with new episodes on 5 January 2026._

item.title: Trump loomed over sport like never before in 2025. Next year he will take even more
item.description:
From the Super Bowl to UFC cards to the US Open to the Ryder Cup, the US president has turned sport into his own personal stage. There‚Äôs more to come

Considering he‚Äôs the self-declared hardest working president to ever hold the office, Donald Trump has spent a remarkable amount of the past year away from it. In 2025, he loomed over sports like no American politician before him, his visits to stadiums and arenas and golf courses and race tracks so frequent they began to feel like part of the job description. But if Trump‚Äôs presence on the sporting scene has seemed hard to escape, gird yourselves for 2026, when the American presidency no longer merely intersects with sport but threatens to subsume it. The World Cup is on the way, the Olympics are right behind it, a UFC card is coming to the White House lawn (not a joke) and the commander-in-chief‚Äôs well-documented fondness for jumbotrons is becoming less of a habit than a dependency.

Trump‚Äôs grand tour sportif began less than three weeks after his second inauguration, when he become the first sitting president to attend the Super Bowl. One week later he was at the Daytona 500, where Air Force One buzzed the speedway on arrival before his armored limousine, ‚ÄúThe Beast‚Äù, paced the field for a couple of ceremonial laps.

Continue reading...

From the Super Bowl to UFC cards to the US Open to the Ryder Cup, the US president has turned sport into his own personal stage. There‚Äôs more to come
Considering he‚Äôs the [self-declared hardest working](https://edition.cnn.com/2019/02/11/politics/donald-trump-hard-work) president to ever hold the office, Donald Trump has spent a remarkable amount of the past year away from it. In 2025, he loomed over sports like no American politician before him, his visits to stadiums and arenas and golf courses and race tracks so frequent they began to feel like part of the job description. But if Trump‚Äôs presence on the sporting scene has seemed hard to escape, gird yourselves for 2026, when the American presidency no longer merely intersects with sport but threatens to subsume it. The World Cup is on the way, the Olympics are right behind it, a UFC card is coming to the White House lawn (not a joke) and the commander-in-chief‚Äôs well-documented fondness for jumbotrons is becoming less of a habit than a dependency.
Trump‚Äôs grand tour sportif began less than three weeks after his second inauguration, when he become the first sitting president [to attend the Super Bowl](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/feb/08/super-bowl-trump-end-racism-politics). One week later he was at the Daytona 500, where Air Force One [buzzed the speedway on arrival](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/FMzOKEKA4to) before his armored limousine, ‚ÄúThe Beast‚Äù, [paced the field](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xMNHoprgcAw) for a couple of ceremonial laps.

item.title: Alex Sarama: how a 30-year-old Englishman became an WNBA head coach
item.description:
Portland Fire are set for their debut season in the WNBA. Their coach has completed an unlikely journey to the top of his sport

As an aspiring basketball coach in his teens and early 20s, Alex Sarama was often met with snickers when he talked about the game he loved. For the British-born Sarama, who on 28 October was named the head coach of the WNBA‚Äôs newest expansion team, the Portland Fire, people doubted him before he even put two sentences together.

‚ÄúThere was a lot of skepticism,‚Äù he tells the Guardian. ‚ÄúA lot of coaches heard the accent and they‚Äôd say straight away this Alex guy can‚Äôt coach!‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: Medicaid paid more than $207 million for dead people. A new law could help fix that
item.description:
A new Department of Health and Human Services report reveals Medicaid programs made over $200 million in improper payments to health care providers between 2021 and 2022 for people who had already died. The inspector general report, released Tuesday, suggests that a new mandate in Republicans‚Äô One Big Beautiful Bill could help reduce these kind of payments. The bill requires states to audit Medicaid beneficiary lists against the Social Security Administration‚Äôs Death Master File. Privacy laws currently restrict access to this file. The report recommends states comply with the new mandate to conduct quarterly death checks to prevent further improper payments.

The post Medicaid paid more than $207 million for dead people. A new law could help fix that first appeared on Federal News Network.

item.title: Brooks Koepka quits LIV Golf after three years but PGA Tour return uncertain
item.description:
• The 35-year-old joined Saudi-funded tour in 2022

  • ‚ÄòBrooks is prioritising the needs of his family‚Äô

Brooks Koepka, the five-time major champion, has become the first player to defect from LIV Golf, a significant blow to the league funded by Saudi Arabia‚Äôs public investment fund and raises questions whether the PGA Tour will find a way for him to return.

The 35-year-old American has made the decision in order to spend more time with his family. He joined the rival tour in 2022 and won five events over four seasons ‚Äì he was also the first LIV player to win a major at the 2023 PGA Championship.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
- The 35-year-old joined Saudi-funded tour in 2022
- ‚ÄòBrooks is prioritising the needs of his family‚Äô
Brooks Koepka, the five-time major champion, has become the first player to defect from LIV Golf, a significant blow to the league funded by Saudi Arabia‚Äôs public investment fund and raises questions whether the PGA Tour will find a way for him to return.
The 35-year-old American has made the decision in order to spend more time with his family. He joined [the rival tour in 2022](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jun/22/rory-mcilroy-brands-liv-golf-players-duplicitous-as-koepka-is-latest-to-move) and won five events over four seasons ‚Äì he was also the first LIV player to win a major at [the 2023 PGA Championship](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/may/21/brooks-koepka-becomes-first-liv-golfer-to-win-major-with-us-pga-triumph).
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/dec/23/brooks-koepka-liv-golf-pga-tour)

item.title: U.S. GDP sees healthy growth
item.description:
From July through September, U.S. gross domestic product rose 4.3%, the highest in two years. At a time when many consumers are feeling economic pressure, higher earners and certain businesses are doing very well ‚Äî and spending to match it. In this episode, can the impressive rate of growth continue? Plus: Affordable Care Act marketplace insurance alternatives fall short, winter surfing boosts Great Lakes tourism revenue, and holiday spending is up, according to credit card companies.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.


Marketplace is more than a radio show. Check out our original reporting and financial literacy content at¬†marketplace.org¬†‚Äî and consider¬†making an investment¬†in our future.

item.title: US supreme court blocks Trump bid to deploy national guard to Chicago
item.description:
In a 6-3 decision, the high court sided with a lower court ruling that blocked deployment of troops to the Illinois city

The US supreme court refused on Tuesday to let Donald Trump send national guard troops to the Chicago area, in an important reining-in of the US president‚Äôs efforts to expand the use of the military for domestic purposes in historic moves against a growing number of Democratic-led jurisdictions.

The nation‚Äôs highest court denied the US justice department‚Äôs request to lift a judge‚Äôs order in October that has blocked the deployment of hundreds of national guard personnel in a legal challenge brought by Illinois state officials and local leaders, who had opposed any federalization of those troops to offer backup to immigration enforcement.

Continue reading...

item.description:
Justice department says FBI confirmed letter is fake and lists why it was not deemed genuine by authorities

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

The Department of Justice said on Tuesday afternoon that a disturbing letter released as part of the Epstein files and appearing to be from the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein to convicted sex abuser and former Olympic gymnastics coach Larry Nassar is a fake.

The contents of the purported letter dated 2019 were released by the DoJ early on Tuesday and had appeared to have been written by Epstein to Nassar and discussed a love of ‚Äúyoung ladies‚Äù.

The NWSL introduced a new ‚ÄúHigh Impact Player Rule‚Äù on Tuesday that allows teams to exceed the salary cap by up to $1m to help attract and retain star players. The rule goes into effect on 1 July 2026.

One of the first players who could potentially benefit from the new rule is Washington Spirit forward Trinity Rodman, who reportedly has received lucrative offers from teams in Europe.

item.title: Trump administration bans US veterans agency from providing abortions
item.description:
Department of Veterans Affairs says justice department found procedure not to be legally sound

The Department of Veterans Affairs can no longer provide abortions to veterans, including in cases of rape or incest, following a Department of Justice memo that found last week that the practice was not legally sound.

The ban follows months of efforts by the Trump administration to roll back a Biden-era policy that, for the first time, permitted the VA to counsel veterans and their families about abortion, as well as offer the procedure in cases of rape or incest, or when a veteran‚Äôs pregnancy imperiled their health. In August, the administration filed paperwork to officially roll back the policy, which had helped the VA‚Äôs network of 1,300-plus healthcare facilities ‚Äì which treat nearly 10 million veterans each year ‚Äì expand access to abortion, especially in the wake of the US supreme court‚Äôs 2022 overturning of Roe v Wade.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Department of Veterans Affairs says justice department found procedure not to be legally sound
The Department of Veterans Affairs can no longer provide abortions to veterans, including in cases of rape or incest, following a Department of Justice memo that found last week that the practice was not legally sound.
The ban follows months of efforts by the Trump administration to roll back a Biden-era policy that, for the first time, permitted the VAto counsel veterans and their families about abortion, as well as offer the procedure in cases of rape or incest, or when a veteran‚Äôs pregnancy imperiled their health. In August, [the administration filed paperwork](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/04/trump-abortion-veterans-affairs-hospitals) to officially roll back the policy, which had helped the VA‚Äôs network of 1,300-plus healthcare facilities ‚Äì which treat nearly 10 million veterans each year ‚Äì expand access to abortion, especially in the wake of the US supreme court‚Äôs 2022 overturning of Roe v Wade.

item.title: We‚Äôve been lied to ‚Äì electric bike motors CAN do regen, at least with this genius trick
item.description:
If you‚Äôve covered e-bikes as long as I have, you‚Äôll know two things about them: they‚Äôre an awesome way to get around, and the basic technology behind an e-bike motor hasn‚Äôt radically changed in a long, long time. However, based on the new e-bike motor design I just tested from a powertrain technology company called CHARGE, the e-bike world may be about to get turned on its head. These guys discovered that nearly any e-bike hub motor can perform regenerative braking, but everyone has just been building them wrong this whole time.

more‚Ä¶
item.source:markdown:
![](https://electrek.co/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2025/12/chargebikehead-1.jpg?quality=82&strip=all&w=1600)
If you‚Äôve covered e-bikes as long as I have, you‚Äôll know two things about them: they‚Äôre an awesome way to get around, and the basic technology behind an e-bike motor hasn‚Äôt radically changed in a long, long time. However, based on the new e-bike motor design I just tested from a powertrain technology company called [CHARGE](https://www.chargebike.co/), the e-bike world may be about to get turned on its head. These guys discovered that nearly any e-bike hub motor can perform regenerative braking, but everyone has just been building them wrong this whole time.

item.title: Epstein files appear to show Andrew asking Ghislaine Maxwell for ‚Äòinappropriate friends‚Äô
item.description:
Documents give further insight into former royal‚Äôs ties to sex offender and raise fresh questions for Donald Trump

Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor asked Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs fixer Ghislaine Maxwell to arrange meetings with ‚Äúinappropriate friends‚Äù while she sought ‚Äúfriendly and discreet and fun‚Äù girls on his behalf, the latest documents from the Epstein files appear to show.

The largest release yet of files concerning the financier and convicted child sex offender ‚Äì which also raise fresh questions for the US president, Donald Trump ‚Äì include emails in the name of ‚ÄúA‚Äù exchanging detailed messages with Maxwell that appeared to identify the author as Andrew.

Emails recording that Britain‚Äôs Metropolitan police contacted the FBI last month to inquire whether there were any ongoing investigations related to the disgraced former prince‚Äôs association with Epstein.

Emails showing US lawyers claiming ‚Äúvarious factual inaccuracies‚Äù in a statement provided on Andrew‚Äôs behalf during their investigation of Epstein.

Multiple references to Donald Trump, including a claim by a senior US attorney that Trump was on a flight in the 1990s with Epstein and a 20-year-old woman. There is no indication of whether the woman was a victim of any crime, and Trump has consistently denied wrongdoing.

Files featuring redactions that were found to be removable through Photoshop techniques or simply highlighting text to paste into a word processing file.

Continue reading...

Documents give further insight into former royal‚Äôs ties to sex offender and raise fresh questions for Donald Trump
Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor asked Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs fixer Ghislaine Maxwell to arrange meetings with ‚Äúinappropriate friends‚Äù while she sought ‚Äúfriendly and discreet and fun‚Äù girls on his behalf, the latest documents from the Epstein files appear to show.
The largest release yet of files concerning the financier and convicted child sex offender ‚Äì which also raise fresh questions for the US president, Donald Trump ‚Äì include emails in the name of ‚ÄúA‚Äù exchanging detailed messages with Maxwell that appeared to identify the author as Andrew.
Emails recording that Britain‚Äôs Metropolitan police contacted the FBI last month to inquire whether there were any ongoing investigations related to the disgraced former prince‚Äôs association with Epstein.
Emails showing US lawyers claiming ‚Äúvarious factual inaccuracies‚Äù in a statement provided on Andrew‚Äôs behalf during their investigation of Epstein.
[Multiple references to Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/23/trump-flew-alone-on-jet-with-epstein-and-unnamed-20-year-old-files-suggests), including a claim by a senior US attorney that Trump was on a flight in the 1990s with Epstein and a 20-year-old woman. There is no indication of whether the woman was a victim of any crime, and Trump has consistently denied wrongdoing.
Files featuring redactions that were [found to be removable](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/23/epstein-unredacted-files-social-media) through Photoshop techniques or simply highlighting text to paste into a word processing file.

item.title: The valet, the burnt toast, and the trip to Peru: evidence that suggests Andrew link to Ghislaine Maxwell emails
item.description:
Documents released in relation to Jeffrey Epstein contain emails between Maxwell and an individual signing off as ‚ÄòA‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Invisible Man‚Äô

Emails between Ghislaine Maxwell and an individual signing off as ‚ÄúA‚Äù are among the largest dump yet of documents released by the US Department of Justice in relation to the convicted child sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

While ‚ÄúA‚Äù ‚Äì who also refers to themselves as ‚ÄúThe Invisible Man‚Äù ‚Äì is not explicitly identified in the emails, they include key details that corroborate the suggestion that they are Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who was then still a working royal known as Prince Andrew.

Continue reading...

item.title: Some Epstein file redactions are being undone with hacks
item.description:
Un-redacted text from released documents began circulating on social media on Monday evening

People examining documents released by the Department of Justice in the Jeffrey Epstein case discovered that some of the file redaction can be undone with Photoshop techniques, or by simply highlighting text to paste into a word processing file.

Un-redacted text from these documents began circulating through social media on Monday evening. An exhibit in a civil case in the Virgin Islands against Darren K Indyke and Richard D Kahn, two executors of Epstein‚Äôs estate, contains redacted allegations explaining how Epstein and his associates had facilitated the sexual abuse of children. The exhibit was the second amended complaint in the state case against Indyke and Kahn.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Un-redacted text from released documents began circulating on social media on Monday evening
People examining documents released by the Department of Justice in the Jeffrey Epstein case discovered that some of the file redaction can be undone with Photoshop techniques, or by simply highlighting text to paste into a word processing file.
Un-redacted text from these documents began circulating through social media on Monday evening. An [exhibit](https://web.archive.org/web/20251219222621/https://www.justice.gov/multimedia/Court%20Records/Matter%20of%20the%20Estate%20of%20Jeffrey%20E.%20Epstein,%20Deceased,%20No.%20ST-21-RV-00005%20(V.I.%20Super.%20Ct.%202021)/2022.03.17-1%20Exhibit%201.pdf) in a civil case in the Virgin Islands against Darren K Indyke and Richard D Kahn, two executors of Epstein‚Äôs estate, contains redacted allegations explaining how Epstein and his associates had facilitated the sexual abuse of children. item.title: Ravens head NFL with six Pro Bowl nods despite season of struggle
item.description:
• Broncos, 49ers and Seahawks also have six selections

  • Vikings, Saints and Jets have zero Pro Bowlers

Six Baltimore Ravens players have been selected for this season‚Äôs Pro Bowl Games despite the team almost certainly missing the playoffs. The Ravens lead the league in Pro Bowl nods, alongside the Denver Broncos, San Francisco 49ers and Seattle Seahawks.

Baltimore‚Äôs Pro Bowlers are fullback Patrick Ricard, wide receiver Zay Flowers, center Tyler Linderbaum, linebacker Roquan Smith, safety Kyle Hamilton and punter Jordan Stout. However, they are 7-8 this season and have only a 9% chance of making the playoffs according to Next Gen Stats.

Continue reading...

item.title: Washington state officials warn of toilet rats after floods: ‚ÄòTry to stay calm‚Äô
item.description:
Tips include flushing rat, squirt soap into toilet or if the rat is too large close toilet lid and call pest control experts

Residents in Washington state have been told to be aware of unwanted festive visitors before Santa comes down the chimney ‚Äì rats coming up from the toilet.

Health officials in Washington warned that recent flooding in the state ‚Äúmay sweep rodents into the sewer systems‚Äù. In a Facebook post, the Seattle and King county public health department wrote: ‚ÄúIf a rat visits your toilet, take a deep breath and follow these tips,‚Äù before outlining the steps to take if a rodent emerges from your commode.

item.title: Ben Sasse, ex-Republican senator, says he has terminal pancreatic cancer
item.description:
Sasse, who is 53 and voted to impeach Trump, says he has ‚Äòmetastasized, stage-four pancreatic cancer‚Äô

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

Ben Sasse announced on Tuesday that he has terminal stage-four pancreatic cancer. The former Republican senator revealed his diagnosis in a post on X, calling it a ‚Äúdeath sentence‚Äù.

‚ÄúFriends - This is a tough note to write, but since a bunch of you have started to suspect something, I‚Äôll cut to the chase: Last week I was diagnosed with metastasized, stage-four pancreatic cancer, and am gonna die,‚Äù he wrote.

item.title: Disney and OpenAI and short videos, oh my!
item.description: A little over a week ago, Disney became the first major media company to strike a content licensing deal with Sora, OpenAI's short-form video platform. This means that people on Sora can start making videos with Disney characters. Today, we'll chat about what it means for consumers, the companies, and artists in the entertainment industry. But first: GDP growth jumped in the third quarter, and it was not just consumers buying stuff.

item.title: Jes Staley and Larry Summers made executors of Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs estate, files reveal
item.description:
Former Barclays boss and ex-US Treasury secretary named in versions of will of convicted child sex offender

The former Barclays chief executive Jes Staley and the ex-US Treasury secretary Larry Summers were appointed as executors of Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs estate, according to a newly released tranche of documents linked to the deceased child sex offender.

Filings published on Tuesday by the US Department of Justice included various versions of Epstein‚Äôs last will and testament, which showed the financier intended to hand responsibility of managing his affairs to associates including the two high-profile men in the event of his death.

item.title: Three inmates captured in Florida after escaping jail near Atlanta
item.description:
Inmates‚Äô escape from DeKalb county jail discovered during routine security check early Monday

Three inmates who escaped from a jail east of Atlanta, including one who was being held on a murder charge, have been apprehended in Florida, a member of a federal fugitive taskforce confirmed.

Eric Heinze, assistant chief inspector with the US Marshals Service Southeast Regional Fugitive Task Force, declined to share further details ahead of a news conference planned in Atlanta later on Tuesday.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòHaunted and cursed‚Äô: Lake Lanier has a deadly reputation. A darker tale hides beneath the surface
item.description:
After years of fatalities and bizarre incidents, the Georgia reservoir has spawned countless ghost stories. Are they merely legend or the aftereffects of a history steeped in racial trauma?

Kile Glover was the entertainer in the family, the pride of his stepfather, the R&B superstar Usher. He sang, he danced ‚Äì he burned CDs of his own music, styled the covers with self-made art and was otherwise expressing his creativity in internet videos before it was trendy. ‚ÄúHe would‚Äôve been a YouTube sensation by now,‚Äù says his mother, the celebrity stylist Tameka Foster. But that future was thwarted on a family trip to Lake Lanier, just outside his Atlanta home town, in July 2012.

Kile was only 11 when he was struck by a speeding jetski while tubing and knocked unconscious. Foster, on the island of Saint Martin at the time, managed to get to Kile‚Äôs hospital bedside within hours thanks to Usher sending a private plane ‚Äì an olive branch that came amid a bitterly public custody battle over their two younger sons. As Kile lay on life support, Foster passed the time Googling for information about Lake Lanier. She is still horrified by what she learned.

Continue reading...

A man identified as ‚ÄúA‚Äù who appears to be Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor discussed facilitating meetings with ‚Äúinappropriate friends‚Äù with Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: ‚ÄòRare‚Äô squirrels set free together after bonding at Florida wildlife hospital
item.description:
Big Cypress fox squirrels released as a pair to reduce stress and support natural behaviors during return to the wild

Two ‚Äúrare and elusive‚Äù juvenile squirrels have a new home for the holidays after they were injured falling from their nests and spent several weeks in a Florida wildlife ‚Äúrehab‚Äù facility.

The pair of Big Cypress fox squirrels, a threatened species so uncommon that the Conservancy of Southwest Florida hasn‚Äôt treated one in at least a decade, was released back into the wild at a carefully selected site rich in ‚Äúhigh-quality pine and cypress habitat‚Äù near the nest where one of them was originally found.

Continue reading...

item.title: US economy grew strongly in third quarter, GDP report says
item.description:
GDP rose at an annualized rate of 4.3% over the third quarter, far higher than expected

The US economy surged over the summer, the commerce department announced on Tuesday in one of the final snapshots of the nation‚Äôs finances to be released in 2025.

Gross domestic product (GDP) ‚Äì a broad measure of the value of goods and services ‚Äì rose at an annualized rate of 4.3% over the third quarter, far higher than expected and its fastest rate in two years.

Continue reading...

item.title: A new era for weight-loss drugs
item.description: GLP-1 weight-loss drug injections have slimmed many waistlines and wallets. U.S. regulators have now approved a much less expensive alternative; Novo Nordisk has gotten the green light for an oral version of Wegovy. Pills are cheaper to manufacture than injectables, and that could be a game-changer. Then, consumers still feel pessimistic heading into the new year, and more Americans are staying unemployed for longer.

item.title: Mauritanian immigrants in Ohio face deportations home, where abuses persist

A growing group has found community around Cincinnati. Trump‚Äôs ICE crackdown threatens to send them back to Mauritania, rife with human rights issues

Musician Khalidou Sy recalls the night his concert was shut down before he was taken away by the Mauritanian police and jailed for five days.

While he was never given a reason for his detention, in his show Sy criticized the lack of electricity available to the Mauritanian public and called on the authorities to make a change.

item.title: ‚ÄòAn air of repression‚Äô: Cop City case hangs over heads of 61 defendants
item.description:
US government continues holding on to massive amounts of seized personal property, from diaries to cellphones

Georgia‚Äôs historic racketeering case in connection with opposition to the police training center known as Cop City continues hanging over the heads of 61 defendants, drawing into focus the state‚Äôs continuing possession of hundreds of cellphones, laptops and personal items.

The state‚Äôs case is believed to be the largest ever leveled against a protest or social movement using Rico, a law created to go after the mafia and usually associated with organized crime but here deployed against a largely environmental and criminal justice-focused movement.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòGunboat diplomacy on steroids‚Äô: US signs security deals across Latin America
item.description:
Venezuela‚Äôs Nicol√°s Maduro warns Trump administration may ‚Äòdestabilise the entire region‚Äô amid rising tensions

While all eyes are on the four-month-long US military campaign against Venezuela, the White House has been quietly striking security agreements with other countries to deploy US troops across Latin America and the Caribbean.

As Donald Trump announced a blockade on sanctioned oil tankers and ordered the seizure of vessels amid airstrikes that have killed more than 100 people in the Caribbean and the Pacific, the US secured military deals with Paraguay, Ecuador, Peru and Trinidad and Tobago in the past week alone.

Continue reading...

item.title: Amazon blocks North Korean IT applicants
item.description: From the BBC World Service: Tech giant Amazon says it's blocked more than 1,800 North Koreans from trying to join the company in the past two years. Amazon's chief security officer said North Koreans often try to get hired, then send wages back to fund their government's weapons programs. Plus, "oshikatsu" is a Japanese term referring to fervent fan subcultures surrounding things like sports teams, pop stars, or anime ‚Äî¬†and it's helped pull Japanese retail sales out of a slump.
item.source:markdown: _From the BBC World Service:_ Tech giant Amazon says it's blocked more than 1,800 North Koreans from trying to join the company in the past two years. Amazon's chief security officer said North Koreans often try to get hired, then send wages back to fund their government's weapons programs. Plus, "oshikatsu" is a Japanese term referring to fervent fan subcultures surrounding things like sports teams, pop stars, or anime ‚Äî¬†and it's helped pull Japanese retail sales out of a slump.

Across the United States, citizens say they have started carrying their passports with them through their daily activities as widespread immigration raids create a pervasive climate of fear, and reports of citizens being detained circulate in the media.

The Guardian talked to people living this reality.

item.title: First Thing: Number of people in ICE detention hits record high
item.description:
Administration has arrested 328,000 and deported 327,000 people. Plus, Bethlehem in the Israeli-occupied West Bank celebrates Christmas again

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

The number of people in immigration detention in the US has hit an all-time high, according to data published by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).

What are the demographics of people the administration is targeting for deportation? In one of the biggest changes in immigration enforcement policies, immigrants with no criminal record continue to make up the largest group in US immigration detention, despite the administration‚Äôs rhetoric about focusing its anti-immigration efforts on ‚Äúthe worst of the worst‚Äù criminals. (Being undocumented in the US is a civil not a criminal infraction.)

How are ordinary people fighting back? As Trump carries out his mass deportation operation, Julia Carrie Wong reports on how residents are banding together to block raids and distribute groceries.

What did Trump say about Clinton? ‚ÄúI like Bill Clinton,‚Äù Trump said after he featured prominently in Friday‚Äôs cache of photos. ‚ÄúI hate to see photos come out of him but this is what the Democrats ‚Äì mostly Democrats and a couple of bad Republicans ‚Äì are asking for, so they‚Äôre giving their photos of me too.‚Äù

Meanwhile, what‚Äôs happening on the Hill? The Senate Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer, said yesterday he will introduce a resolution directing the Senate to take legal action against the justice department ‚Äì over its incomplete release of files.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Administration has arrested 328,000 and deported 327,000 people. Plus, Bethlehem in the Israeli-occupied West Bank celebrates Christmas again
- [Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here](https://www.theguardian.com/info/2018/sep/17/guardian-us-morning-briefing-sign-up-to-stay-informed)
Good morning.
The number of people in immigration detention in the US has [hit an all-time high](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/22/ice-detentions-record-immigration), according to data published by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
**What are the demographics of people the administration is targeting for deportation?** In one of the biggest changes in immigration enforcement policies, immigrants with [no criminal record](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/21/deportations-us-government-shutdown-ice-data) continue to make up the largest group in US immigration detention, despite the administration‚Äôs rhetoric about focusing its anti-immigration efforts on ‚Äúthe worst of the worst‚Äù criminals. (Being undocumented in the US is a civil not a criminal infraction.)
**How are ordinary people fighting back?** As Trump carries out his mass deportation operation, [Julia Carrie Wong reports](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/18/ice-raids-fighting-back) on how residents are banding together to block raids and distribute groceries.
**What did Trump say about Clinton?** ‚ÄúI like Bill Clinton,‚Äù Trump said after he featured prominently in Friday‚Äôs cache of photos. ‚ÄúI hate to see photos come out of him but this is what the Democrats ‚Äì mostly Democrats and a couple of bad Republicans ‚Äì are asking for, so they‚Äôre giving their photos of me too.‚Äù
**Meanwhile, what‚Äôs happening on the Hill?** The Senate Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer, said yesterday he will introduce [a resolution](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/22/schumer-doj-epstein-senate-legal-action) directing the Senate to take legal action against the justice department ‚Äì over its incomplete release of files.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/23/first-thing-number-of-people-in-ice-detention-hits-record-high)

item.title: ‚ÄòUn club d‚Äôici‚Äô: FC Supra turns to a Bilbao-style model to keep Qu√©bec talent at home
item.description:
By representing its region‚Äôs distinct culture and players, the Canadian Premier League team aims to boost the province‚Äôs undoubted soccer potential

Boulevard Saint-Laurent is one of Montr√©al‚Äôs great arteries, a throughway for gourmands coveting smoked meat sandwiches or proper pizza at one of a dozen different joints in Little Italy. It‚Äôs also home to Evangelista Sports, a shop that has doubled as a shrine to the city‚Äôs soccer-obsessed for more than 40 years and is every bit a part of Montr√©al‚Äôs cultural fabric as poutine or lamenting the cold.

It‚Äôs also where FC Supra du Qu√©bec opted to announce their first-ever signings last week. The Canadian Premier League (CPL) expansion team is looking to become part of the city and province‚Äôs cultural identity, hoping their commitment to recruiting a full roster of Qu√©bec-born or raised players, inspired by European clubs like Athletic Bilbao, will go a long way in helping to build a pathway which has so often seen talent slip through the cracks.

Continue reading...

item.title: US sees surge in violence against journalists under Trump, report says
item.description:
The US press have suffered about as many assaults this year as in the previous three years combined

The United States has seen a dramatic increase in violence against journalists since Donald Trump again took office.

Most of the reporters and photographers who were allegedly attacked by law enforcement officials were covering protests over the Trump administration‚Äôs efforts to deport undocumented immigrants, according to the Freedom of the Press Foundation, a non-profit that tracks such incidents.

Continue reading...

item.title: Why Big Tech leaders aligned themselves with White House politics this year
item.description:
In January, we saw a who's who of tech leaders front and center at President Donald Trump's inauguration.


Since, the White House has advocated for the build out of AI infrastructure and put a moratorium on state-level AI regulation. But the Trump administration also added a $100,000 fee to petitions for H-1B visas, which are widely used in the tech sector.


To review the year in tech and Trump we called up Suyash Pasi, a research analyst and editor at the nonprofit Human Rights Research Center, who‚Äôs been following this shift.
item.source:markdown:

Since, the White House has advocated for the build out of AI infrastructure and put a moratorium on state-level AI regulation. But the Trump administration also added a $100,000 fee to petitions for H-1B visas, which are widely used in the tech sector.
To review the year in tech and Trump we called up Suyash Pasi, a research analyst and editor at the nonprofit Human Rights Research Center, who‚Äôs been following this shift.

item.title: Brock Purdy throws career-high five touchdowns as 49ers roll over Colts
item.description:
• Purdy throws career-high five TD passes

  • McCaffrey stars again in versatile role

  • Rivers‚Äô return can‚Äôt halt Colts‚Äô slide

Brock Purdy threw a career-high five touchdown passes and Dee Winters returned an interception of Philip Rivers‚Äô final pass 74 yards for a score to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 48-27 victory over the Indianapolis Colts on Monday night.

Purdy was 25 of 34 for 295 yards with one interception, plus his five TD throws. Christian McCaffrey rushed 21 times for 117 yards and caught six passes for 29 yards and two scores. George Kittle had seven receptions for 115 yards and one TD.

Donald Trump has broken his silence on the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files, complaining that people who ‚Äúinnocently met‚Äù the convicted paedophile could have their reputations destroyed.

In his first comments since the justice department began releasing the materials on Friday, the US president on Monday expressed sympathy for prominent Democrats who have come under renewed scrutiny over their associations with Epstein.

item.title: US regulators approve Wegovy pill, first oral medication to treat obesity
item.description:
Food and Drug Administration‚Äôs approval hands drugmaker Novo Nordisk an edge in the race to market an obesity pill

US regulators on Monday gave the green light to a pill version of the blockbuster weight-loss drug Wegovy, the first daily oral medication to treat obesity.

The US Food and Drug Administration‚Äôs approval handed drugmaker Novo Nordisk an edge over rival Eli Lilly in the race to market an obesity pill. Lilly‚Äôs oral drug, orforglipron, is still under review.

item.title: Trump administration plans to promote loyal diplomats after recall of 30 ambassadors, sources say
item.description:
Move comes as union representing US diplomats said it was ‚Äòdeeply concerned‚Äô by the process, which could ‚Äòpoliticise‚Äô foreign service

The Trump administration has quietly recalled nearly 30 ambassadors and other senior overseas diplomats as the Trump administration plans to promote appointees loyal to the new administration to higher levels of the state department, according to diplomatic sources.

The recall of the ambassadors or heads of mission, which were confirmed by several current and former senior diplomats, was unusual for targeting career foreign service officers heading embassies overseas who are generally left in place after a change in administration because they strive to be apolitical.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Move comes as union representing US diplomats said it was ‚Äòdeeply concerned‚Äô by the process, which could ‚Äòpoliticise‚Äô foreign service
The Trump administration has quietly recalled nearly 30 ambassadors and other senior overseas diplomats as the Trump administration plans to promote appointees loyal to the new administration to higher levels of the state department, according to diplomatic sources.
The [recall of the ambassadors or heads of mission](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/21/trump-administration-recalls-diplomats), which were confirmed by several current and former senior diplomats, was unusual for targeting career foreign service officers heading embassies overseas who are generally left in place after a change in administration because they strive to be apolitical.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/dec/23/trump-administration-recalls-30-ambassadors-promote-loyal-diplomats)

item.title: Trump announces plans for new navy warships to be known as ‚ÄòTrump-class‚Äô
item.description:
President says the ships will be bigger, faster and a hundred times more powerful than any previous US-built warship

Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water. Donald Trump has announced plans for the US navy to build a new generation of warships ‚Äì known as ‚ÄúTrump-class‚Äù.

The ships will be bigger, faster and a hundred times more powerful than any previous US-built warship, the president said on Monday. The project will begin with construction of two such battleships and eventually be expanded to 20 to 25 new vessels.
